PROCTEXT.PARA: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator C. R. Maunsell) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: REPRESENTATION OF THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to inform the Senate that, consequent upon the death of Senator Knight and pursuant to the provisions of section 9 of the Senate (Representation of Territories) Act 1973, I have notified His Excellency the Governor-General that a vacancy has happened in the representation of the Australian Capital Territory in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KEEFFE

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 54 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the construction of a uranium enrichment plant in North Queensland and the mining of uranium on the Herveys Range area should not be proceeded with on the following grounds
(1) No safe method has yet been devised for the disposal of nuclear waste.
(2) The mining of uranium ore exposes workers to considerable danger from radon gases.

(3) The danger of poisoning chemicals seeping into surface and underground water supplies as a result of uranium ore mining and refining of uranium ore could pose serious health hazards for persons living in the Townsville region.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should take all possible steps to abandon or postpone indefinitely the mining of uranium in the Herveys Range area, and the construction of an enrichment plant in the Townsville region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARTIN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 528 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Concern over the proposal to terminate the payment of Unemployment Benefit to persons under 18 years of age.
Your petitioners, therefore, most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will not allow this proposal to be effected.
Furthermore, your petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will recognise the proposal that Unemployment Benefits be increased for persons under 18 years of age.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHIPP

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from nine citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilisers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognize that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian Nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAJOVIC

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 28 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That due to higher medical and hospital insurances, the Voluntary Health Insurances Contributors are finding that their weekly buying power is greatly reduced. The contributors are actually subsidising the non-contributors. The contributors are greatly disadvantaged by the present taxation system. We therefore call upon the Commonwealth Government to make the Health Insurance Contributions tax deductible.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will take immediate steps to bring about the wishes expressed in our Petition.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Patients' Medical Records
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are gravely concerned by the invasion of privacy caused by Government agents seizing patients' medical records:
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should-
Legislate to protect the private and confidential nature of medical records from scrutiny except on the express and informed consent of the patient or an order from a presiding judge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Breeders' Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilisers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian Nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia,

PROCTEXT.PARA: Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to human rights.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Racial Discrimination Amendment Act 1980 by substituting references to the Human Rights Commission Act 1981 for references to the Human Rights Commission Act 1980.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Has he yet made up his mind whether he agrees with the Minister for Transport in challenging the veracity of the three members of the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares, namely, Mr Warwick Holcroft, Dr Harold Bell and Professor Warren Hogan? Does he accept that the members of the inquiry were not warned that the inquiry was to be curtailed and a report produced by 31 January? If he does not accept that statement by the three members of the inquiry, can he explain why no public hearings were held in Victoria, South Australia or Queensland and no evidence was taken from Ansett Transport Industries Ltd, Trans-Australia Airlines or the Department of Transport?

—In respect of the first matter raised by Senator Button I certainly do not agree that the Minister has been challenging the veracity of the members of the Holcroft inquiry. With regard to the second aspect-Senator Button's allegation that the members of the Holcroft inquiry were not warned that the inquiry was to be curtailed-it is quite clear from the letter of 14 November 1980, which I believe Senator Button would have seen by now, that it was fully intended that the Holcroft inquiry understood that it would be reporting by 31 January 1981. The letter, of course, sought an extension of that time. The Government took a decision which indicated that it would expect a report by 31 January 1981. It must be realised, I think, that the inquiry itself was concerned with the matter of air fares; it did not cover the matter of the two airlines agreement. Consequently, the Government sought an early reply on that matter. Therefore, the rest of the points raised by Senator Button in his question, I believe, fall on that account. I have no further information on any other matters on which he might be seeking information.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Irrespective of what the Government intended, is it a fact that the Holcroft committee was informed that the inquiry would be curtailed and that the report had to be produced by 31 January? I further ask the Minister: Irrespective of whether the Holcroft committee had to deal with the two-airlines agreement, is it not a matter of concern that an inquiry of this nature received no evidence from Ansett Transport Industries Ltd, Trans-Australia Airlines or the Department of Transport?

—I believe the letter of 14 November 1980-I take it Senator Button has seen it-clearly states that 31 January 1981 was the agreed date. Of course, that date having been stipulated in the first place, it was not changed or the subject of change by the Government. I believe that is the key question, and it has been answered quite clearly.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It was reported in the Northern Territory News of Monday, 3 March 1981, that the Portuguese Government, through the Dutch Embassy in Jakarta, is refusing to issue passports to East Timorese trying to reach Lisbon. As this avenue of immigration and the reuniting of families is now closed to East Timorese, can the Government advise the present position regarding East Timorese entering Australia? Will the Government consider extending the bounds of the present policy to offset the move by the Portuguese Government?

—Under Portuguese law people born in East Timor are Portuguese citizens and are entitled to Portuguese passports. The referral of passport applications to Portugal is associated, at least in part, with the preparation for the provision of accommodation and social welfare requirements of returnees from the former colonies. I am advised that there is nothing at this stage to suggest that applicants in Jakarta will not eventually be granted Portuguese passports and enabled to travel to Portugal. Australia's provisions for the resettlement of Timorese are generous and involve significant relaxation of normal migration policies. The issue of passports by the Portuguese Government is not preventing movement to Australia by Timorese.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Is it true, as reported in the Press this morning, that domestic air fares are to rise again? Will the Minister undertake to ensure that the recommendations of the Holcroft inquiry are carefully considered before any new fare increases are approved?
—I am not aware of any Press reports in regard to any increase in domestic air fares. I will refer the question to the Minister for Transport and obtain a reply.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIA-NEW ZEALAND TRADE: HORTICULTURAL AND DAIRY PRODUCTS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. In view of the growing concern of both horticultural and dairy industry interests in Australia regarding the proposed closer economic relations with New Zealand, will the Minister for Primary Industry use his best endeavours to have horticultural and dairy products removed from the general list and rely on discussions and agreement between producers on both sides of the Tasman, in line with the arrangements which have worked so well for nearly 20 years with the pea and bean panel?

—I think most honourable senators will be aware that last year the Prime Ministers of Australia and New Zealand agreed upon a framework for the detailed exploration and examination of possible arrangements for a closer economic relationship between Australia and New Zealand. I think that agreement was made in March 1980. The examinations which were requested by the Prime Ministers are still proceeding, as are consultations with industry and State governments. I am sure that the ideas put forward by Senator Archer in his question will be explored thoroughly in the context of the detailed work which the Prime Ministers have sought. I am equally sure that the Minister for Primary Industry will use his best endeavours to forward the best interests of Australian agriculture and particularly those of the dairy and horticultural industries in the course of the ongoing discussions on a closer economic relationship with New Zealand. I will certainly make sure that the Minister is aware of the import of the honourable senator's question and that he is able to take it into account.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to the Minister for Transport's recent answers to questions in which he said that it was always his intention that the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares would report by January 1981. If that is so, why was it necessary for him to announce on 26 November last year that he had asked the chairman of the committee to conclude his report by 31 January?

—The honourable senator has asked a rather strange question insofar as 31 January being the latest date on which such a report would be obtained. I see no point in debating particular times with Senator Robertson. The letter dated 14 November 1980 from Mr Holcroft to the Minister clearly stated that a report was expected to be produced by that committee by the end of January 1981.

—I ask a supplementary question. I do not agree with the Minister. There seems to me to be an anomaly. If the Minister had said that the committee would report by January 1981, why did he ask the chairman to conclude his report at the end of January?
—I have nothing to add to the point which I have made.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister or, if more appropriate, the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. It concerns the important advantages of retaining the Australian Development Assistance Bureau as a separate entity in the Department of Foreign Affairs, an issue which has been the subject of very wide public concern. Can the Minister confirm that the Prime Minister, through Cabinet, has now removed ADAB from the action list of the so-called razor gang in its reviewing of government functions? Can the Minister also confirm that to dissipate the integrity of ADAB as the main thrust of Australia's overseas aid would, without any significant gains, diminish the effectiveness of that aid, harm the credibility abroad of the Government's aid program and damage Australia's international standing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not able to confirm or comment on any matters that may arise with regard to committee work of the Cabinet. I am not able to confirm statements the Prime Minister may have made to a committee that is doing work for the Cabinet. The remainder of the question relating to the aid program, I will refer to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. I think it is well known that the aid program of the Australian Government has been given priority and has wide support within government and, I believe, within the Australian community. I will see whether there is any comment that it is appropriate for the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs to make on the question raised by the honourable senator.

—I direct my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. In view of the many unsubstantiated and conflicting statements being made concerning the input of salt to the River Murray, I ask: Will the Minister provide to the Senate the most up to date information available as to the actual amount of salt input to the River Murray by each of the three States adjacent to it, namely, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, together with information as to the reason for the input? Further, will he provide statistics on the amount of salt entering New South Wales from Queensland through the Barwon River, which flows into the Darling River which, in turn, flows into the River Murray?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been some controversy, as Senator McLaren acknowledged, regarding the actual amount of salt flowing into the Murray River and the origin of that salt. The estimate of 2 per cent which has been cited by New South Wales authorities as deriving from New South Wales rivers is based on a water quality analysis in the Maunsell report on river flows and diversions by the States during the 1967-68 irrigation season. That is quite some time ago. This analysis excluded flows released from storages under the control of the River Murray Commission, and flows in the Darling were also excluded as they represented mainly releases from the Menindee Lakes storage on the Darling River which is controlled by the Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: South Australia, in arriving at its estimate of 28 per cent of salt in the River Murray being contributed by New South Wales, has updated the Maunsell analysis on the basis of available information on river flows during the period October to December 1980. However, salt coming down the Darling River, including that in releases from Menindee Lakes, has been added to the updated analysis. The estimates I have referred to are not comparable in that they relate to different times and to different bases of computation. In any event, it should be recognised that some of the salt coming down the Darling, including that in water released from Menindee Lakes in New South Wales, has its origin in Queensland tributaries of the Darling River.

It appears that there is no clear or authoritative answer to the precise question. The question has been troubling me very considerably. I will see whether we can get more scientific information. Fundamentally, all South Australians are motivated-I am certainly motivated as Minister-to ensure that the minimum of salt gets into the river and into South Australia. That is the real factor that is occupying my mind. However, if there is statistical or other information that can add to what I have said, I will get hold of that and will let Senator McLaren know.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer to the public inquiry into zone allowances and the problems of people in isolated areas. When does the Government expect that it will receive the report of the inquiry? Does the Minister consider that the proposed timetable provides adequate time for preparation of public submissions, careful preparation of the inquiry's report and its consideration by the Government in time for the 1981-82 Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will need to refer that matter to the Treasurer for information on the timetable and the adequacy of the time that has been allowed for submissions. I think it is understood that it is important to consider the matter. It was felt that an inquiry was required. But, as far as the timing of reporting and dealing with the matter are concerned, I will need to seek information from the Treasurer.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I remind him of the concern he expressed and the promise he gave to provide information about the case of a number of citizens in Greece charged with alleged offences under the Australian Social Services Act. Has he any further information? In particular, has he any information about the role of the Australian police or any other public servants in this country in this action taken in the Greek courts?
—I thought I provided Senator Grimes with an answer to a question on notice on the matter. If it has not been received as yet, I must apologise.
—It has been received but it does not give any information.

—I am sorry, it does give information. That statement is quite incorrect. I think I should check the actual position of proceedings in Greece in order to give an answer. I will make inquiries about that matter and ascertain what is the present position in Greece. As I mentioned earlier, the cases were with the Council of Magistrates of the Court of Appeals for decisions on whether charges were to proceed or to be referred back to the investigating magistrate. That was the position a week or two ago. Whether there has been any movement in the position I do not know.

—I ask a supplementary question. Has the Minister or any other agency of the Australian Government had any correspondence or discussions with the Greek Government about this situation of people in another country being charged with offences against legislation on our statute book?

—As I have already advised Senator Grimes, I have taken up the matter with the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The channels of communication between Australia and Greece are through the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The matters about which he and I are concerned have been communicated through him to the appropriate authorities in Greece. I, in conjunction with the Department of Foreign Affairs, will keep the matter under consideration and will endeavour to ensure that such matters are kept in mind by the Greek authorities. The decisions in such matters are made by the Greek authorities, not by us.

—No doubt the Minister representing the Treasurer is aware that in some countries a personal income tax return is required to be submitted only once in every two years. The income tax paid in the second year is based upon the tax paid in the first year and an adjustment is made when the next return is submitted. No doubt the Minister is well aware that Switzerland is one such country. It is a country whose economy and inflation rate Australia could well attempt to copy. Will the Minister therefore ask the Treasurer to consider implementing a similar system in Australia with a view to the obvious economies it would bring within the Australian Taxation Office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer the matter raised by Senator Townley to the Treasurer and seek comment from him.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport to two answers which he gave me earlier this morning. The first was that the Government had always expected the Holcroft inquiry to complete its deliberations by 31 January and report by that date. The second was that the Holcroft inquiry did not cover the matter of the two-airlines agreement. I ask the Minister: If those two answers are true why did the Minister for Transport on 26 November put out a Press release on the point? The Press release reads:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government has asked the Chairman of the domestic air fares inquiry . . . to conclude his report by 31 January next year so that the Government and the Parliament will have the benefit of the recommendations of this inquiry before proceeding to enact legislation to give effect to a new two-airlines agreement . . .
Does that statement not announce the truncating of the Holcroft inquiry? Does it not announce the relevance of the Holcroft inquiry to the two-airlines agreement?

TALK.START.PARA: —The brief that I have on this matter indicates confirmation of the point that I made earlier in relation to the letter of 14 November 1980 from Mr Holcroft to the Minister for Transport and his reply dated 26 November, to which Senator Button has referred. In relation to the Press release to which Senator Button has referred and the desire of the Government to have a reply from the Holcroft inquiry by 31 January, I believe it is entirely consistent with the aim of considering the new two-airlines agreement that this information should have been available to the Government. Obviously it was not necessary for the inquiry to consider the whole question of the two-airlines agreement itself. As I understand it, there was no intention that the Government should receive advice from that inquiry on that broader matter. It became relevant when people were giving advice in relation to air fares to the Holcroft inquiry; that is, making submissions to it. Obviously those questions were relevant to the broader one and needed to be taken into account.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. If the Minister's answer to my earlier question is correct, I ask him why the Press statement of the Minister for Transport dated 26 November 1980 went on as it did. It stated:

QUESTION.PARA: This decision--
The decision to terminate the inquiry-
followed discussions between the Prime Minister, the Minisster for Transport, the Western Australian Ministers, parliamentary members and senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it from the line of questioning which Senator Button is adopting that he is trying to establish some inconsistency between the answers he is getting from me and the answers which he might be seeking to get in another place from the Minister. I have nothing further to add in relation to that Press statement. The point is quite clear. The arrangement was that the Holcroft inquiry would report in respect of domestic air fares by 31 January 1981 so that that matter could be taken into account in considering the two-airlines agreement.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CODE OF CONDUCT FOR AUSTRALIAN COMPANIES IN SOUTH AFRICA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the codes of conduct relating to apartheid and employment practices adopted by different countries whose companies have active operations in South Africa. In particular, the existing codes are the Sullivan code relating to United States of America firms, the European Economic Community code, the Urban Foundation Saccola code and the Canadian Government code of conduct. In view of the fact that at least 35 Australian companies have active operations in South Africa, has the Australian Government considered adopting and applying one of these codes in relation to Australian-South African operations or developing its own code giving practical operation to our clearly expressed principles on apartheid and other racial discriminatory practices?

—The Australian Government is, of course, implacably opposed to the apartheid policies of the South African Government. The Government believes that apartheid is manifestly unjust, discriminatory and exploitive. The Government has made its opposition to apartheid widely known in Australia and elsewhere. I inform honourable senators that the codes of conduct suggest measures to improve the working and living conditions of the black African employees of foreign firms trading in South Africa but are limited in their effect by South African law. The Government has investigated the various codes of conduct which the honourable senator mentioned in his question but has not moved to adopt such a code for Australian businesses. We hope, however, that those Australian firms operating in South Africa will be guided by the Government's overall policy on apartheid. In this connection I point out that those codes of conduct adopted by other countries are not mandatory on the firms concerned. They merely ask for the companies' co-operation in implementing the code. The question is significant. I will arrange for it to be brought to the attention of the appropriate Ministers.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Will the Government give further consideration to adopting a code, even if it is not an existing code?
—I would be happy to refer the supplementary question to the Ministers concerned-presumably the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister-and to ask for their consideration of it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. By way of preface, I refer to the frequently made statement before the high powered Estimates Committee C by Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs officials that delays in the issuing of tourist visas are often due to an effective security probe. In view of that assertion, can the Minister give any explanation as to how a recently apprehended West German terrorist was able to circumvent those security procedures?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and ask him to provide an early reply.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. Does the Government accept that a knowledge of the arts is an essential part of an educated person and therefore must be a core part of our education system? Is it a fact that the former Chairman of the Schools Commission, Dr McKinnon, gave great drive to the implementation of the recommendations contained in the joint Schools Commission-Australia Council report 'Education and the Arts'? Can the Minister assure the Senate that Dr McKinnon's successor, Professor Tannock, shares his views on the importance of this education and the arts project and will give it similar drive?

—The Government certainly accepts that knowledge of the arts is an important part of children's education. As specific illustrations of this interest, I refer to the activities of the Schools Commission and of the Curriculum Development Centre. The Schools Commission has continued to support projects as a follow-up to the education and the arts study which was published at the end of 1977 and which was carried out jointly by the Schools Commission and the Australia Council. The Curriculum Development Centre included 'participation, expression and appreciation through the arts and crafts' amongst the basic learning tools identified in its discussion paper which is called 'Core Curriculum for Australian Schools' and which was published last year. Dr McKinnon was a member of the Australia Council as well as being Chairman of the Schools Commission and he took a keen personal interest in this area of education. The Schools Commission has been maintaining its interest and I expect that it will continue to do so under Professor Tannock's leadership.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Recently the Farmers and Stockowners Association of South Australia expressed a real concern over the purchase of rural land by foreign investors. The members believe that a situation may develop whereby it will be impossible for young Australian nationals to become established on land in their own right. Will the Minister consider introducing legislation similar to that of New Zealand where it is stipulated that foreigners must live in the country for at least two years before purchasing rural land, or to the legislation of the United States where foreigners are prevented from owning more than 0.405 hectares of land?

—I think all honourable senators would be interested to ensure that Australians have optimum opportunities for the acquisition and development of land on this continent. But essentially Senator Elstob's question highlighted the difficulty involved here in that land, its ownership and the terms of its transfer in Australia are essentially State government matters. I make the point in the first place that it would be essential for the States themselves to direct their attention to what Australians would regard as a matter of significant interest. It is true that under the Foreign Investment Review Board provisions, the Commonwealth Government has a responsibility and applies that responsibility. I am not aware as yet whether the condition of purchase by foreign interests of land in Australia has caused any considerable difficulties. Nevertheless, to the extent that it is partly a Commonwealth matter in that it involves foreign investment guidelines, I will refer the question to the Treasurer in the first place and presumably to the Prime Minister and ask them to give it consideration, in the knowledge, however, that any primary action must come from the State governments because they have sovereignty over the land.

—My question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister is about the unequivocal direct threat made by the Soviet Ambassador to Australia that Australia could become one of the nuclear targets of the Soviet Union. I ask: Has His Excellency, Dr Nikolai Soudarikov, Soviet Ambassador, been given a detailed explanation of the Australian Government's position in relation to the Soviet Union as a result of the threat to world peace caused by the Soviet invasion and continued occupancy of Afghanistan? Was the Ambassador's statement delivered through the medium of selected journalists on Tuesday, 3 March, previously presented to the Government through formal and normal diplomatic channels? If not, are the statement and the method of delivery not so provocative and so in breach of diplomatic protocol as to justify withdrawal of Dr Soudarikov's accreditation to this nation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is important to reply to some very significant aspects of the question by Senator Lewis. I have seen Press reports of the Soviet Ambassador's conversation with a group of Australian journalists. His comments, as reported, indicate a complete failure to understand the Australian Government's position despite the fact that this- -
—Who does understand it?

—It would be interesting if I were given to understand that Senator Primmer disagrees with our stand that the Soviet Union should get out of Afghanistan, where it is an intruder and an aggressor. Let me say that the distancing of the Australian relationship with the Soviet Union in recent months has been essentially because of the Soviet Union's invasion of Afghanistan and its continued aggression there.
—So we are punishing the Russians by selling them our wool.

—Mr Deputy President, all the interjections of the Opposition supporters seem to suggest that they do not have the same view as we have. I would have thought that they would have joined virtually every country of the free world, every Middle East country, in seeing the Afghanistan invasion as a serious matter and would have wanted to express, as we have done--

—I raise a point of order. Senator Carrick knows full well that in the Senate members of the Opposition unanimously joined the Government in supporting the United Nations resolution on Afghanistan. In answers to questions he cannot, I submit, deal so lightly with the truth.

—Mr Deputy President, since we have experienced the unique situation of the Leader of the Opposition intervening to help in an answer, let me say that I was very accurate with my words. I said I would have thought that members of the Opposition would take a certain stand. Indeed, I accept the assurance of the Leader of the Opposition that they do so. The fact of the matter is that the present strained state of Australia-Soviet relations is the direct result of the Soviet invasion and occupation of Afghanistan. Following the invasion of Afghanistan the Australian Government condemned the invasion in the strongest terms and took a series of measures in concert with its allies. These measures remain in force. If we were wrong in those, we were wrong in very good company indeed. Improvement in relations between Australia and the Soviet Union would be possible if the Soviet Union were to change its policies, which have been widely and vigorously condemned by the international community. Regrettably, apparently the Soviet Union has revealed no intention either to change its policies or to withdraw its forces from Afghanistan. There are 85,000 Soviet troops still in Afghanistan attempting forcibly to suppress Afghan resistance. While the Soviet Union's policies and activities in relation to Afghanistan remain unchanged, Australia's relations with the Soviet Union cannot be normalised.

ANSWER.PARA: A Soviet Embassy official is reported as saying to journalists that the Government has ignored a request by the Soviet Union to expand the Embassy's trade section. No formal request in that regard has been received by this Government. There is a proper and an improper way of conducting business between governments. Accusations made to journalists regarding inaction by the Government on a request that has not yet been made formally to the Government represent an improper way of conducting business. I note that the Ambassador is reported as referring to Australia as a possible nuclear target. For the Ambassador to make such a grave threat would belie the image of peaceful Soviet policy that he usually seeks to convey and would add to the grounds for concern felt increasingly in the international community regarding Soviet expansionism and militarism. Those Soviet policies further underline the vital importance of Australia's alliance with the United States of America. Finally, Australia could be a nuclear target only if the potential aggressors of this world sought to make it a nuclear target. Indeed, I know of no aggressors within the free world. Unfortunately, I think the reported remarks of the Ambassador have been made in poor taste and judgment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that the document quoted from by the Minister be tabled.

—The document from which I read is one of the documents I receive from the Prime Minister's Department every day. It is the Prime Minister's brief. I received this in anticipation of questions that might be asked. I would be happy to table the document.
—For Dorothy Dixers.

—Yes, in anticipation of a Dorothy Dixer from Senator McLaren. Let me make it perfectly clear that this morning I was able to answer the question asked by Senator McLaren on the salinity of the River Murray because Senator McLaren had paid me the compliment of letting me know he was interested in the matter. I table the document. I will table any document willingly at any time when requested if the honourable senator concerned acts in a controlled and honourable way.

—I ask a supplementary question. I think the Leader of the Government in the Senate failed to answer the last part of my question. Will the Government consider withdrawing Dr Soudarikov's accreditation to Australia?
—I have no knowledge of any such intention by the Government. I will refer the question to the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister.

—I direct my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I was very concerned to read in two issues of the Melbourne Age dated 3 and 4 February this year that the shale oil deposits known as the Rundle Twins in Queensland will not come into production until some time in the 1990s, well over 12 years after discovery. As the multinational Exxon company appears more concerned with the financial well-being of its shareholders than it is with the living standards of Australian people, will the Minister give consideration to: Firstly, relieving Exxon of what seems to be an onerous and embarraising obligation; or secondly, calling for a declaration of interest from others with the necessary technical expertise; or thirdly, advising the Government to set up its own organisation that would be responsible for the development and production of all shale oil in Australia? Is the Minister aware that shale oil is produced in large quantities in China, at Fushan in Manchuria and Maoming in Kwangsi Province? Is the Minister also aware that Estonia produces approximately three and a half million gallons of fuel oil daily from its shale deposits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whenever an undertaking is made to develop a mining and retorting operation involving shale oil, for example, inevitably, along the journey, changes in timetable may occur because technical problems may emerge. There is no doubt that in any undertaking of a mining project of such magnitude timetables may well be varied. The Rundle project involves a co-partnership in which 50 per cent of the co-partnership is held by Australians and the other 50 per cent is held by Exxon which is acknowledged throughout the world as having a world leadership in the knowledge of the development of liquefaction of shale. So Exxon has high technical efficiency.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware that throughout the world a number of countries produce oil from shale. I am well aware that there are opportunities for other projects to develop in Australia, notably in Queensland, and there is a lively interest in them. I have no doubt that, in the near future, as more knowledge occurs of the details of the mining operation the Rundle partners will make public any knowledge about timetables that is necessary.

My understanding was that there would be two stages and that the first stage would be virtually a demonstration plant. I understood that phase one would be available about the mid-1980s and that the second stage would be available at the beginning of the 1990s. There may well be some variation or slippage in years in that regard. Nevertheless, because of the size of the plant, that would be understandable.

If further information can be given to the honourable senator regarding the technical details I will seek the information from the companies and make it available to him. As to the specifics, Exxon has world acknowledgement of its expertise. Other companies in co-partnerships in Australia are available to come forward and develop shale. I have no doubt that in the 1990s coal liquefaction and shale synthetic crudes will become a vital part of Australia's energy balance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. I do so following reports that the Commonwealth Government is to build a Commonwealth building in Adelaide. Can the Minister say when it is proposed to construct this building? Why has it taken so long for such a decision to be made?

—I am advised that in September last year the Commonwealth announced its intention to proceed with the documentation of a proposal to construct Commonwealth offices in Adelaide, but it has to submit this proposal to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works before it can go much further. The decision to get the proposal ready was reached after an Australia-wide review of all Commonwealth accommodation needs. This was necessary before a full list of priorities and overall needs could be put together. It is expected that the proposal will be ready for submission to that Committee in August-September this year. That is about six months from now.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs will be aware that honourable senators have been circularised by a United States of America agency putting a view on the situation in El Salvador such as would justify United States aid of both civil and military character. I ask: So as not to leave honourable senators at the mercy of the propaganda machines of foreign powers, will the Government, as a matter of urgency, circulate to us its own assessment of the causes of the present conflict in El Salvador; the degree and timing of any manipulation of or intervention in that conflict by nations such as Cuba or Russia on the one hand, or the United States on the other the origins and status of the present Government of El Salvador and the nature and success of its social reform program; and the Government's view on the propriety of any nation's sending members of its armed forces into El Salvador?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate has raised important questions and sought the response of the Government to them. I will refer the matters to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to see what information or papers he may feel it is appropriate to circulate to honourable members and honourable senators.

—I direct a question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to the alarm in South Australia following the most recent death from amoebic meningitis-that of a 10-year-old boy in Whyalla earlier this year. Has the Minister received any approach from the State Government with respect to providing financial assistance to enable the State Government to install filtration plants to deal with water quality in that area? If so, can the Minister say whether the Federal Government will give urgent consideration to providing that financial assistance?

—I have no personal knowledge of any such approach. I will certainly check to see whether an approach has been made either at Prime Ministerial level or at other departmental level. I have not received any approach at all. In the normal course of events expenditure for town water supply would be regarded as a State matter and, indeed, the national water resources program that I administer does not specifically deal with it. However, it may be that the South Australian Government which would make such an approach would do so seeking some special loan or special application in another direction. I will look at the matter, refer it to the Prime Minister and let Senator Jessop know if any further information is available.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of the publicity regarding the sudden infant death syndrome which names Tasmania as the State with the highest incidence in Australia, and possibly the world, and which has caused widespread alarm in Tasmania? Is the Minister aware that the infant mortality rate in Tasmania is higher than the national average and that of most other States and second only to that of the Northern Territory? What funds have been allocated both nationally and in Tasmania to research the traumatic incidence of the sudden infant death syndrome? Is the Minister aware of the criteria laid down by the National Health and Medical Research Council, which will make grants only for established research work which has been extensively published, thus precluding new areas of research? What assurance can the Minister give to the people of Tasmania that the Government is aware of the situation and will take action?

—I am well aware of the concern about the sudden infant death syndrome-a condition which many people know by the old name of cot death-and of the tragic consequences it has for many families. I have actually been involved, as some friends had this happen to them. I can understand the distress it brings. I will have to get answers for the honourable senator to a number of the questions of detail. I will ascertain exactly what funds have been allocated for research and certain details about the infant mortality rate. It is not correct to say that no research projects have been carried out. A program of research into the sudden infant death syndrome has been undertaken over previous years in a number of centres in Australia and by a number of different research workers.
—Including Tasmania.

—Including Tasmania. A great deal of information about the condition is emerging from that research. I do not know yet that there is a strong thrust as to what should be done to prevent the condition occurring. The honourable senator made one comment about the provision of research grants by the National Health and Medical Research Council. My understanding is that these awards are made on a competitive basis among all people who apply. They are not necessarily made on the basis of published work; they are said to be made on the basis of the quality of the submission made. I understand also that the National Health and Medical Research Council has a highly developed assessment program whereby each new proposal is assessed independently by a team of assessors who allot a mark and who then attempt to fund the proposal on a national priority basis. I think this does include a number of original projects and it could well include research into the sudden infant death syndrome.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. Has the Minister noted in the new publication issued by the Commissioner for Community Relations an item which deals with discrimination in education? The article states that 16 teacher education institutions across Australia will participate in analysing the text books most commonly used in upper primary schools to learn about Aborigines and three recent immigrant groups. The article also states that some children encounter devaluing treatment from not only their peer groups but also teachers who unthinkingly accept the verdict of text books that perpetuate racist slanders against Aboriginal Australians. Accepting the argument that children can be wrongly influenced by the text books and teachers, will the Minister institute an analysis of the text books in regard to the possible political bias being perpetuated by them?

—I have not seen the report referred to in the honourable senator's question although I have learned of it second-hand. The matter is one that should primarily be considered by the Schools Commission. I will refer the matter to the Minister for Education with the suggestion that that be done. Equally, it may be that the Curriculum Development Centre, which has the task, in conjunction with the States, of looking at the material circulated to students, should also look at the matter. I am not aware of the text books concerned but I will invite my colleague in another place to direct his attention to the question. He may wish to seek out the text books and put them under study.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, concerns an election promise made to the Australian people by the Prime Minister in Launceston on 15 October last. The Prime Minister was then quoted as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: If there is a significant increase in revenue from the oil levy, this will be returned to Australian families through taxation reductions or family allowances.

I ask the Minister: Have not significant increases in oil levy revenues resulted from petrol price rises imposed by the Government last month? If so, when and how will this money be returned to the Australian family?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the Prime Minister's policy statement. I have no doubt at all that it will be implemented. Of course, it would be a matter for budgetary implementation and therefore, no doubt, will be considered in the present process of putting the Budget together. In regard to whether there have been significant increases in the oil levy, two things have happened. There has been a very significant decline in oil levy revenue due to industrial unrest and due to the failure to produce oil from the rigs.

—That would be a matter for Cabinet policy. I will refer it to the Prime Minister to see whether he wishes to comment. I referred to two relevant matters. One was the wording and the plain meaning of the increase in the money accrued from the oil levy. It is significant for the honourable senator to know that there has been a significant decrease because of industrial activity. That point must be made and understood. I will refer the substance of the question to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer for comment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I was prompted to seek leave to make a short statement on this paper largely by the question that Senator McLaren asked today and the answer to it from Senator Carrick. The paper, a copy of which has been supplied to me by way of an intermediary from Senator Carrick's office, lists the specific projects in four States for which Commonwealth financial assistance has been given. One of the major areas of expenditure in both New South Wales and Victoria itemised in the paper is that of salinity monitoring and control in the Murray Basin. It has been clear for some time, of course, to those who have taken any interest in the subject that an environmental problem of major proportion has already shown up in the Murray Basin and indications are that it is likely to get very much worse unless massive changes are made to both the intensity and the extent of irrigation. Although irrigation is not the only cause of land and water salination in the area, it appears to be without doubt the major cause of the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The question asked by Senator McLaren today and the answer given by Senator Carrick illustrated that our factual knowledge is quite deficient in this area and that there is no definitive information on the contribution to the total salt load in the water from the various tributaries of the Murray. There is, of course, variability, both within and between years, in the amount of water contributed by each of the tributaries and in the salt concentration in that water. So, monitoring would have to be conducted on a continuous basis and over a considerable period before a definitive answer could be given to even so basic a question as the amount of salt coming from each of the tributaries of the river system.

On the information given by Senator Carrick it is quite clear that the claim being made by the Water Resources Commission of New South Wales-that only 2 per cent of the salt load which finally gets to Lake Alexandrina originates in New South Wales-is highly misleading. I think it is also clear from the technical knowledge available, incomplete though it is, that it would be prudent, to say at least, to be cautious about any further expansion of irrigation works, particularly in the Murrumbidgee-Murray River and tributaries in that part of the system but also in the other areas of the system, because of the ultimate effect which the expansion of irrigation anywhere in the entire Murray catchment area will have on the quality of water which finally reaches South Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will recall that a decision has been made by the members of the Commonwealth to set aside the second Monday in March each year as a day on which the purpose and achievements of the Commonwealth would be duly marked. As this is the last sitting day before this year's Commonwealth Day I would like to take this opportunity to make a brief statement to that end.

SPEECH.PARA: This year's Commonwealth Day is especially note-worthy for Australia in two respects. First, it marks the 50th anniversary of the Statute of Westminster, an Act of the British Parliament which gave birth to the Commonwealth. Second, this year Australia will host the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting for the first time.

To an exceptional extent the history of the Commonwealth has been one of gradual evolution, marked by continuity and subtle modifications rather than abrupt change. But if there is one event which constitutes a decisive step in that evolution, it is surely the passing of the Statute of Westminster in 1931. That event marked the decisive transition from Empire to Commonwealth. By establishing the principles of autonomy, equality and free association among members, it created the conditions for the Commonwealth to grow, diversify and establish a distinctive role in an era of far-reaching changes. Thus as decolonisation proceeded with great rapidity, most of the newly independent countries found it natural and advantageous to become members of it.

A leading Australian authority on the Commonwealth, Professor Bruce Miller, has referred to the Statute as 'a masterpiece of ambiguity', and no doubt in legal and constitutional terms it was that. But politically it pointed clearly in one direction. The time when discussion of the Commonwealth tended to be clouded by rather dubious metaphysics and the search for the definition of an essence is long since past. The contemporary Commonwealth is confident enough to take itself for granted, to define itself in terms of what it does. Its form is flexible and accommodating; its bent is pragmatic and problem solving; its atmosphere is informal and unpolemical.

No one who is aware of the recent record of the Commonwealth would be foolish enough to characterise it as a 'talking shop' or an anachronism. At the two Heads of Government meetings the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has attended we have agreed on an effective declaration against apartheid; we have made a substantial contribution to progress on a common fund for commodities; we have initiated an inquiry into factors inhibiting economic growth and structural change; and we have made a major contribution to the solution of conflict in Zimbabwe. We have shown a capacity to make progress on problems which major powers and global groupings have found intractable. Organisationally, we have initiated regional Commonwealth meetings of Asian and Pacific members.

At the time the Statute of Westminster was passed the Commonwealth had six members. At this year's conference in Melbourne over 40 heads of government are expected to attend and it will be the most important international conference ever held in Australia. The agenda will cover a wide range of issues, but I anticipate that North-South issues-that is issues concerning relations between developed and developing countries-will be of prime importance. These issues are of vital importance for the future peace, stability and prosperity of the world. Yet at present it is proving difficult to have them addressed with the urgency and commitment which their seriousness demands. In these circumstances the Melbourne Commonwealth meeting assumes a special significance. The composition of the meeting ensures that North-South questions will be seriously addressed there, in practical and constructive terms. I hope, therefore, that in September we shall seize the opportunity to contribute towards the removing of some of the roadblocks to a progress on these issues and help generate a momentum which will carry over to other forums.

Mr Deputy President, the Commonwealth is important to Australia as a link with our past. But it is even more important as an instrument which we, along with others, can use to help shape the future, to strengthen the forces of moderation, co-operation and good sense in a world which badly needs them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I wish to make very brief comments about this statement. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the statement begins with the announcement that a decision has been made to set aside the second Monday in March each year as a day on which the purpose and achievements of the Commonwealth will be duly marked. I do not know what on earth that statement means. Is the second Monday in March each year to be a day on which achievements are to be marked by waffling statements such as the one which has just been read by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner)? I ask the Minister not to take any personal offence. I appreciate that he is not the author of this waffly statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —He could have been though.
—He could have been but he is not and we must be fair about that. Really, what does it all mean? Is the day to be a public holiday, Senator Lewis? Are you pushing that?
—Not at all. I am asking what is waffly about the reference to the Statute of Westminster being a masterpiece of ambiguity?
—I rhetorically ask: What is the point in a government saying that the second Monday in March will be marked as a day to consider the achievements of the Commonwealth? Marked for whom?
—The Government did not say that. The Government said 'the members of the Commonwealth'.

—I fully understand that. Pursuant to the expressed intention of the members of the Commonwealth, surely the Government could have produced a more adequate response than this flimsy scrap of paper. If this is the way that we in Australia mark a decision of the Commonwealth countries--
—What is the matter with it being flimsy? Should it be on 56 lb of quality paper?

—I am sure it would not have been flimsy if you had had anything to do with its writing. It would have run to about 100 pages of the same quality-inferior! The point I am making is to ask rhetorically what is the point of this exercise. Of course the point of the exercise is for the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to start grandstanding already in respect of the September Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting which is to take place in Melbourne. That is what it is all about. It is the Prime Minister setting up a forum for himself at the September meeting where the various issues which are dealt with later in this statement can be raised. If the Government were serious about marking nationally and acknowledging the decision of members of the Commonwealth that a day be set aside for this consideration it would have been incumbent upon the author of this statement to say how we in Australia are going to do that on the second Monday in March. There is nothing in the statement about that at all. I am saying that the statement really is about--
—Are you suggesting we have a holiday?

—No, I do not suggest that at all. I am strongly against increased public holidays. I would like to see fewer of them. The point is that for a government which is so grand on monuments, so addicted to monument building, it is extraordinary that this statement should be the entire response to a decision by the members of the Commonwealth about this matter. I also find it extraordinary that the Commonwealth countries have made such a decision because it is rather--
—Some of them have a degree of loyalty.
—Loyalty to what?
—Loyalty to each other.
—Order! Senator Button, you will address the Chair.

—Mr Deputy President, I will let those honourable senators opposite work it out. They are very confused about what they are being loyal to. But if they can discuss it in a phone box at some subsequent time they will not delay the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is an extraordinary statement to bring down, an extraordinary response from the Government to a decision of the heads of the Commonwealth governments if such a decision is taken seriously and is not yet being used as the platform from which this sort of statement can be pronounced and grandstanding can take place. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Davidson Sen G.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am very glad that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), on behalf of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick), has made a statement in this place in relation to Commonwealth Day. If my memory serves me correctly, it is the first time that the Government has put down in this place a statement in relation to Commonwealth Day. As one who is interested in the practical nature of this institution, I take this opportunity to make observations on the last sitting day before Commonwealth Day. I am very glad that a statement has been put down in this place prior to the observance of Commonwealth Day, which is to take place next Monday. To some extent I share the view of Senator Button in relation to the statement that 'achievements of the Commonwealth would be duly marked'. I do not propose to go through a whole list of items which might be described as achievements but I think it would have been of value in future years had reference been made in the statement to the achievements that take place within the Commonwealth of Nations. There is a wide range of areas of Commonwealth achievement in education, health research, the law, broadcasting and recreation. A whole range of agreements existing between Commonwealth countries have been brought about simply because they are part of the institution that we know as the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to refer very briefly to one which I will be bold enough to call an achievement and that is the achievement of the institution of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, which has been in existence for some years and which adds to the effectiveness of the Commonwealth in world affairs. This institution provides for a relationship between the countries of the Commonwealth, between the States of this country and enables matters of parliamentary, political or legislative importance to be the subject of appropriate discussion. I refer to the highly successful and beneficial conference on delegated legislation which was sponsored and financed jointly by the Commonwealth of Australia branch of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association and the headquarters secretariat in London. Some money also came from the capital fund to which a generous contribution was made by this country. This conference was held in September and October last year in this Senate chamber. It was opened by the Governor-General and chaired very ably by our colleague, Senator Missen, who presided at most of the sessions. It related to an area of legislative process, including regulations and ordinances, in which Australia has played a leading part for a good many years. The delegates came to that conference from the Commonwealth parliaments in Africa, Asia, the United Kingdom, Canada, Australasia and the Pacific. The debates and the discussions were of a high standard and of special benefit and proved the value and the achievement-if I may borrow the word-of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association in the effective functioning of Commonwealth legislatures.

Regional conferences and regional seminars held in this part of the world at regular intervals are also part of the contribution of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. Last September the branches in the Commonwealth, the States and New Zealand combined to sponsor a most effective occasion. Later this year the annual general conference of the Commonwealth-wide organisation of the CPA is to be held in Fiji. This will be the first occasion on which the conference is held in Fiji. The Commonwealth of Australia branch and the branches within the States are all giving substantial support.

All of these activities and very many other activities strengthen the Commonwealth heads of government meetings which are held in various parts of the world. A major meeting this year will be held in this country. The meetings also strengthen the parliamentary institution. They add a worthwhile dimension to the observance of Commonwealth Day. I put this information into the record as one who has had a long association with the CPA and one who has some knowledge of the contribution which it makes. I hope that next year, when a statement is made in the Senate on Commonwealth Day, space will be given to the listing of some of the achievements of the Commonwealth which cover every discipline and every range of human and public activity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to speak very briefly on this matter. The statement begins by stating:

SPEECH.PARA: Senators will recall that a decision has been made by the members of the Commonwealth to set aside the second Monday in March each year as a day on which the purpose and achievements of the Commonwealth would be duly marked.
I confess openly to the Senate that I do not recall that decision being made. It may be that I was not present when that information was relayed to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Withers did relay the decision in 1977 when he was the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It was a decision of the Commonwealth heads of government prior to that.

—Thank you. The importance of it did not grip me at the time. I rise to question the attitude which the Australian Government took when it decided that the second Monday in March would be the day on which to celebrate the achievements of the Commonwealth. The second Monday in March has a particular significance for people in Victoria; it is Labour Day in Victoria. I think that it would have been appropriate for the Commonwealth, unless there were very important considerations, to avoid a clash of interests on that day. I do not know why the second Monday in March has been adopted. The second paragraph of the statement reads:

SPEECH.PARA: This year's Commonwealth Day is especially noteworthy for Australia in two respects. First, it marks the 50th anniversary of the Statute of Westminster, an Act of the British Parliament which gave birth to the Commonwealth. Second, this year Australia will host the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting for the first time.

The second reason advanced in that statement is a non-sequitur because it has nothing to do with the second week in March. The first reason is somewhat doubtful because, in fact, the Statute of Westminster was assented to not on 9 March 1931, but on 11 December 1931. So, frankly, I do not know what this statement is all about. I am interested to know what attitude the Commonwealth Government took when this matter was raised at, presumably, the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It might help Senator Harradine if I supply him with that information in a letter. It seems to me that the problems of individual States of Australia would not receive the attention of all those heads of government from across the British Commonwealth who decided on this issue. No doubt other countries have the day set aside for Commonwealth Day clashing with other important dates on their calendars. Nevertheless, I will undertake to obtain a fuller reply for Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-as indicated by the former Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, Senator Missen, when giving notice of motion for the disallowance of the Nature Conservation Ordinance, notice was given on the last available day for giving notice in order to preserve the rights of the Committee while it concluded its inquiry. The Committee was concerned to secure a balance between the laudable objectives of the Ordinance and the preservation of the rights and liberties of individuals affected by its provisions. Matters of concern to the Committee included: The unfettered discretion conferred by the Ordinance on officers to exercise certain powers; the unduly wide conferral of powers of search and entry under paragraph 77 (2) (a) of the Ordinance unconfined to matters in connection with the Ordinance and the further implication of the admissibility in court of evidence so gained; the automatic forfeiture of any animal or plant which is the subject of an offence or of any substance or any thing used in or in connection with the commission of an offence; restrictive provisions concerning the keeping of pets and the importation of live fish into the Australian Capital Territory; and the possibility that prosecutions could be launched, under various provisions of the Ordinance, for offences which might reasonably be regarded as trivial.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) has undertaken to amend provisions of the Ordinance to ensure that powers of officers will be exercised on reasonable grounds and that search and entry powers will be confined to matters connected with the Ordinance, and to leave the forfeiture of plants, animals or goods to the discretion of the court. The Minister also gave assurances to the Committee with respect to the keeping of pets and the importation of fish, and has satisfied the Committee as to the reasons for retention of the prosecution provisions in their current form. The outstanding matter raised by the Committee, which it does not intend to pursue in the context of the Nature Conservation Ordinance, is the admissibility of improperly obtained evidence. The Committee will, however, take up this general principle with the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and the Law Reform Commission.

In the light of the explanations and assurances given by the Minister, the Committee has decided to take no further action in relation to the Ordinance. I therefore withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in the name of Senator Missen, in accordance with notice of intention given on Tuesday. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will have noted that I withdrew the notice of motion standing in the name of the former Chairman, Senator Missen. May I, on behalf of the Committee, take this opportunity to acknowledge publicly his contribution to both the Committee and the Senate since he was appointed Chairman in 1978. Happily, his services have not been lost to the Committee as he remains a member and, following the successful Conference of Commonwealth Delegated Legislation Committees held in Canberra last year, will continue his involvement in the field of delegated legislation at the international level as Chairman of the Commonwealth Delegated Legislation Committee.

The Committee also wishes to acknowledge the contribution of Senator Evans during his two years on the Committee. In particular, his concern for civil liberties enhanced the Committee's work. Finally, on behalf of the Committee, I wish to pay a special tribute to our former secretary, Mr Harry Evans, who has taken up other duties within the Senate. His vast knowledge, dedication and efficiency have been of inestimable value to the Committee in its performance of its role as the watch-dog over untrammelled, executive, regulation-making power. Members of the Committee congratulate Mr Evans on his advancement and look forward to his further progress as an officer of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Deputy President has received a letter from the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) nominating Senator Withers to be a member of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. The Deputy President has also received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) nominating Senator Robertson to be a member of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Messner)-by leave-agreed to:
That Senator Withers, having been duly nominated in accordance with standing order 36AA, be appointed a member of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations.
