PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Messner)-by leave- agreed to:
That Senator Robertson be appointed a member of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I inform the Senate that following the practice of previous years the Opposition Whip has agreed to grant the equivalent of pairs from last Tuesday for the two vacancies existing on the Government benches caused by the resignation of Senators Sheil and Rocher. I understand that under this agreement in the two divisions held last Tuesday Senators Bishop and O'Byrne refrained from voting in the first division and Senators McAuliffe and Button refrained from voting in the second division. I thank Senator Robertson, the Opposition Whip, and honourable senators opposite for their co-operation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I express some concern about what has transpired over this matter. When we resumed on 24 February Mr President made a statement concerning the resignations of Senator Sheil and Senator Rocher. In a division in this chamber on Tuesday of this week the names of Rocher and Sheil were listed as pairs. Yet on the page of the Senate Hansard on which the members of the Senate are listed neither name, Rocher nor Sheil, appears. I am concerned about whether, when we have further divisions, we will still see the names Rocher and Sheil appear, in view of the fact that yesterday in the House of Representatives Mr Rocher was sworn in as a member for Western Australia. That is a matter that I think needs to be corrected. I am pleased that the Acting Government Whip has made the statement he made today. I hope he follows the precedent set by ex-Senator Poyser in similar, but not the same, circumstances due to the death of Senator Milliner whereby after every division a statement was made so that the reason why members of the Opposition did not take part in the division was on the record.
—That is the purpose of raising the matter this afternoon.

—I know that is the purpose, but I hope that a statement is made each day as Senator Poyser did after Senator Milliner passed away. Then it is on the record. Whilst we in this chamber know what it is all about, people who pick up the Hansard-particularly our own party members-might be wondering why certain members whom they have elected to this place did not take part in a division. Senator Kilgariff has said that he will make a statement and I am happy with the arrangement.

SPEECH.PARA: The thing I want to see corrected is that after each division the names of these two people, whom the President has notified have resigned from the Senate, do not appear as pairs. We will have to come to some other arrangement when there are pairs, if they are in regard to vacancies for the two States of Western Australia and Queensland and an Australian Labor Party senator is paired against such a vacancy. The names of two people who have officially resigned from this place should not appear. One person is now a member of the House of Representatives. In my view these people's names cannot appear in two Hansards at the same time. I hope that some method can be found to rectify that anomaly.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Messner)-by leave- proposed:
That after 8 p.m., following the consideration of General Business, Notices of Motion Nos 4, 26 and 30, Government Business shall take precedence of further General Business.

TALK.START.PARA: —In every session we must oppose Government Business taking precedence of General Business on the one night in the week when it is possible to bring up General Business. During the week we heard a grievance expressed by Senator Chipp that we had no time to consider the Holcroft report and the matter was listed under General Business. The limited time made available is now to be further eroded by Government Business. This is the fourth week of this sitting. For four weeks we have sat in this place with the Government having nothing to do and no business to bring on. Now there is some urgency and the Government wants its business brought on tonight. I do not know why. At least some explanation should be given. It should be only under special circumstances that we agree to the precedence of Government Business thereby taking away from us the very short time we have to discuss General Business.

—I join with Senator Cavanagh in voicing my protest at the Government, so early in the sitting of this autumn session, now moving that Government Business take precedence of General Business on Thursday night. This could quite possibly be the forerunner to the same motion that Government Business take precedence of General Business each Thursday night from now until the Parliament rises for the winter recess. I note that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) has moved that after the introduction of the three private members' Bills we go on to Government Business. Of course, that will mean the deliberation of Bills that are already listed on the Notice Paper and if there is time we will go on to debate the Address-in-Reply. Senator Cavanagh has related to the Senate that Senator Chipp complained recently that many matters, particularly those relating to reports, are introduced into this Parliament and honourable senators adjourn debate on them. The matters are listed on the Notice Paper and if the Government continues with this practice those reports will never be brought back into the Senate for discussion. That is of great concern to both Senator Cavanagh and me and to other members of the Opposition side. Like Senator Cavanagh I seek some explanation from the Minister as to why this practice is being introduced in the second week of the first parliamentary sitting for 1981. Is it the Government's intention to continue with this practice each Thursday or can we have an undertaking that it is only to be for tonight, that the usual procedures will prevail after tonight and that we will be given the opportunity to discuss General Business each Thursday night for the remainder of this session?

—in reply-I wish merely to indicate to Senator McLaren that of course the Government has no intention of changing the normal arrangements in this matter. I am sure he, like other honourable senators on both sides, would be aware of the special circumstances of this week.
—The question is that the motion be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye, on the contrary no.
—No. I wish to have my objection recorded.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADVISORY COUNCIL FOR INTER-GOVERNMENT RELATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 March, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this matter was being discussed on Tuesday night I was referring to a statement that had been issued by the Mayor of Gladstone. It concerned the tremendous problems that have occurred in that town as a result of policies pursued by the national Government and implemented by the State Government and the inability of the local government authority in that region of Queensland-Gladstone is a very big provincial city-to meet the infrastructure and community needs arising from the major resource development which is taking place. Of course, that highlights the importance of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations. Clearly, if there is to be a continuation of the resource development about which the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, has been so outspoken, some assistance and forward planning becomes essential for the States and for local government so that the requirements which our citizens demand in respect of their living conditions can be adequately satisfied.

SPEECH.PARA: The Mayor of Gladstone has indicated that the area is suffering very gravely from the lack of resources, particularly financial resources and community facilities, because of the influx of citizens. That, of course, will be repeated in many parts of the Commonwealth. The role of this Council becomes more and more important. If those policies are to continue a lot more co-ordination and forward planning will be an absolute essential, otherwise people will be living in intolerable housing conditions. There will be shortages of water, housing, roads, schools and all the other community facilities that are the responsibilities of other arms of government.

The Prime Minister promised, when in opposition in September 1975, that if he were elected to government he would introduce a new form of federal financial relations. As we know, Senator Carrick in this place has continually praised this Government's efforts and continually expressed the view that the new federalism policy of the Fraser administration would, in fact, solve all of the problems that the States have had in fulfilling their responsibilities. We have to say, however, that whilst Mr Fraser put this in a rather grandiose setting-he talked about protecting the rights of individual citizens and individual freedoms and the need to provide an effective barrier against authoritarian centralist control-his view has not been realised. Some six years after that statement was made the conflicts between the States and the Commonwealth have not lessened but, in fact, have been aggravated by the policies pursued in Canberra.

Mr Fraser tried to convey the impression that this new form of federal financial relations would enable the States to be freer of central control than was previously the case. To those ends he promised, firstly, to give the States a share of income tax for revenue purposes and, secondly, to allow the States to impose an income tax surcharge or, in theory, to give a rebate, depending upon their own needs, to their taxpayers. Mr Fraser, in his policy document issued in 1975, said that these measures would:
. . . ensure that the States will have substantially the financial capacity to meet their responsibilities.

Leaving aside that rather clumsy syntax, he was clearly saying that the new kind of financial relationships would enable the States to be better able to look after themselves financially than had previously been the case. The Opposition believes that the policy has been a fraud. What this Government has sought to do can be epitomised in the following way. A central part of this Government's approach has been firstly, to chop back funds to the States to force them to raise taxes and reduce expenditure; secondly, to manipulate the composition of funds going to the States in accordance with the Federal Government's development phobia; and, thirdly, to seek to control even more tightly the economic policies of the State governments. Why is this so? When comparing the figures for the years 1975-76 with each succeeding year we see the various changes that have taken place in the types of payments made to the States and the way in which the States fared under various headings.

Let us look at general revenue funds. It is true that they have increased by 74.6 per cent, which is well ahead of the rate of inflation. Of course, that is the area that has been protected by the Whitlam formula. It has to be surely acknowledged that, in fact, the States have had to seek relief from the financial policies of the Commonwealth by the maintenance of the Whitlam guarantee. The continuation of that guaranteed the States that they would get no less than they would have under the Labor Government's formula. That is the reason for the 74.6 per cent rise in that area.

The general purpose capital fund figures show an actual reduction in money terms of 3.6 per cent. So with that reduction and with inflation up by 48 per cent since the Fraser Government has come to power, obviously there has been a very severe cutback in real terms. That leaves aside the additional responsibilities which the States have to meet in respect of the development proposals which have been encouraged by the Federal Government. It will be argued, of course, that they are decisions which the States themselves make, but unless they are matched by financial help in one way or another the States are put in a subsidiary and secondary position. Special purpose recurrent payments have gone up in money terms by 43 per cent, which I will concede is marginally less than the actual inflation rate. Nevertheless, the sum total of those changes has been to reduce the amount of funds going to the States. Special purpose capital payments have gone down in money terms every year under the Fraser Government. For this current year they are 25 per cent less in money terms than they were in the 1975 Budget which was brought down in the last year of the Labor Government. Overall, including the Loan Council borrowing, this amount totals 33.6 per cent. We must compare this with the 48 per cent inflation rate. We have to come to the conclusion that the States have been badly affected. The only area of growth has been in the area of general revenue grants. That is one of the attributes-even this Government would have to agree-of the continuation of the Whitlam guarantee.

As we know, this Bill for an Act to amend the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations Act of 1976 is not a major Bill; it is more a machinery Bill. I draw the attention of the Senate to details in some sections of the Bill. For example, section 4 (1) of the principal Act states that the Council was established with the object of improving inter-government co-operation. It states further that it shall, in accordance with directions given at the Premiers Conference, inquire into and keep under consideration and review matters relating to inter-government co-operation. The Bill leaves untouched the substantive provisions of the principal Act to which I have referred.

Of course, as we know there is considerable disquiet in each of the State governments at the way in which financial relations between the States and the Commonwealth have deteriorated. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the Senate itself is supposed to be a States House. It is part of the Senate's mandatory obligation to protect the rights of the States. Despite all the rhetoric and all the millions of words we have heard in this place from Senator Carrick about co-operative federalism, we find ourselves in March 1981 with six States, regardless of ideological and philosophical differences, ranged together against the Commonwealth.

I referred earlier to the role of federalism in the Government's overall policy. It is the Fraser Government that has pushed the State governments into providing the infrastructure for the development projects it hoped would revive the economy in 1980. We heard a lot during the 1980 elections about the resources boom being on the horizon. The average person and the average member of parliament would have lost any sense of what the boom represented except as it was measured in terms of many billions of dollars.

Just how fanatical the Prime Minister is on the topic of resources development and foreign investment is shown by the fact that even his Treasurer (Mr Howard) thinks he has gone too far, as was revealed recently in a leaked document. The document revealed how far the Prime Minister has gone in using so-called infrastructure loans to the States as an off-Budget channel for dispensing favours. We know, of course, that the States have been forced into huge borrowings to meet infrastructure costs relating to resources development. In fact, this has had a tremendous effect on our domestic interest rates. It is the principal factor causing local government to suffer and to experience great difficulty in meeting loan borrowing commitments. Interest rates in the money market are so competitive as a result of semi-government and State government borrowings that local government cannot get into that area at all. In fact, this is a contributing factor in pushing up the rates of interest in this country.

The leaked document I referred to suggested that the Treasury, whose advice on budgetary and wages policy the Government usually accepts, is out in the cold when it questions development. The document is a submission made to Cabinet by the Treasurer in preparation for the recent Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting. In the document Mr Howard and his Department warned of the danger to the economy of too rapid growth in infrastructure borrowings and argued against several of the projects. Fortunately, we have seen a continuing public debate by economists and newspaper writers about the matters that I am referring to. There has been discussion on not just one of the projects but on the combination of projects and what effect they have on the domestic economy. The Treasurer's submission reveals the depth of Treasury concern at the spate of resource projects and the pork barrelling that goes with them. The Treasury might have expected its arguments to be well received by a government that pretends to understand the causes of inflation and which sells itself as having a hard-line attitude towards demands on the public purse. Of course, its arguments have been rebuffed.

The resources boom is placing pressures on our domestic economy in respect of interest rates, State government responsibilities and local government capacity to meet community needs. All of these matters are surely ones that we ought to be discussing in more detail in the national Parliament. We believe the most important aspect of Fraser federalism is its weakening of controls over business, especially the big resource-type development companies, most of which are in the multinational arena. Just at this time of crisis when more than ever governments need to be able to meet, to negotiate with and to understand what these foreign companies and major corporations are doing, unfortunately the States, because of policies pursued by the Fraser Administration, are forced into competing with each other over who can give the biggest hand-outs to business and who can get industry here, there and everywhere else throughout the Commonwealth.

These are the sorts of matters to which the Parliament ought to be giving much more consideration. These are matters central to the success of the Advisory Council, yet clearly they are not receiving sufficient cofsideration in any of the areas I have mentioned. The arms of government at the lower end of the scale-those on the second and third tiers-are placed at considerable disadvantage as a result of policies pursued by the Commonwealth. Therefore, there is need for planning and development of these projects. There is need for consultation with State and local governments on where these projects are to take place. There is need to examine the impact that it will have on our economy and the spin-off effect it will have upon our housing industry and on our manufacturing base. It is necessary to examine also whether it is desirable that the total effect be the establishment of another major export-type development which will place considerable pressures on our Australian dollar and whether there are other implications which I believe and which we on this side of the House believe will have tremendous consequences for the fight against inflation. Clearly, these matters need to be considered by the Government and the inter-government Council which this Bill seeks to amend. They are matters which ought to be the subject of much more public debate and be better understood so that the Council itself can be informed and be able to convey to the national Government the consequences of the economic policies pursued. To the extent that it operates as a process for consultation and dialogue the Opposition will not oppose the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am the newest member appointed to the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations and I have just attended my first meeting. In that capacity I would like to express a word of appreciation for the fact that Senator Kilgariff has served two terms on the Council. I believe it is only right and proper that we should record the appreciation due to him for the time he has given and the service he has provided in the formative years of the Council.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a considerable concern for the charter of the Council and all that is involved with it. I think it is quite well known that I am a federalist at heart. I believe very much that the benefits and responsibilities of the three tiers of government should devolve to their respective places. This responsibility concerns finance, administration and performance which should all be administered in their rightful places. The Advisory Council has a big job. I think Senator Gietzelt tends to underestimate it somewhat. The Council members may select for attention the areas which they consider to be of greater importance. They are not directed as to whether they should or should not deal with matters. The members have the right to determine their own priorities.

The Council has shown that it is capable of looking at matters in considerable depth. Already it has provided valuable advice. Recently it concluded what I understand to be a most valuable report on roads and road funding and is currently taking up consideration of an area of financing. I hope that it can eliminate areas of duplication and improve relationships. Let us get down to the task of making government work better. At present I am unable to comment on how the Council works because I have attended only one meeting. I was impressed with the aura of harmony that seemed to pervade the meeting which I attended. It provided the sort of atmosphere in which problems can be discussed and looked at all round. As has been explained, the Bill is purely machinery. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank all honourable senators for their remarks, and wish the Bill a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Sitting suspended from 12.53 to 2.15 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: LONG SERVICE LEAVE (COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 February, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I suggest that it may suit the convenience of the Senate if this Bill and the succeeding Bill, the Commonwealth Teaching Service Amendment Bill, are considered in a cognate debate.
—There being no objection, that course will be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will devote my remarks exclusively to the Commonwealth Teaching Service Amendment Bill. The purpose of this legislation was indicated very clearly in the second reading speech of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner). Basically, it provides for the transfer of personnel from the Commonwealth Teaching Service to the teaching service of the Northern Territory. This matter has taken some time to negotiate following the transfer of self-government to the Northern Territory and in the course of those negotiations a number of difficulties have emerged which have now been resolved. That is to the credit of the Commonwealth Department of Education and the Government. However, I want to make one or two comments about the nature of the transfer and the difficulties which we think may be inherent in it which should be looked at at a later stage.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister's second reading speech points out, the Northern Territory Government has established the Northern Territory Teaching Service. It will introduce complementary legislation in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly so that teachers, henceforth, following the passing of legislation in both chambers, formerly employed by the Commonwealth Teaching Service will be employed by the Northern Territory Teaching Service and will work under the direction and control of that Service. It is quite a sensible and practical arrangement. In drawing attention to the bones, as it were, of the arrangement, I wish to make one or two comments about the problems of teaching in the Northern Territory, whether one be employed by the Commonwealth Teaching Service or by the Northern Territory Teaching Service. Very considerable problems arise for teachers in the Territory form the remoteness of schools, language problems, the high number of Aboriginal children in many schools in the Territory, the consequent cultural and language problems and the isolation of many teachers from the possibility of the exchange of views and experience and so on with other teachers such as exists in the more settled areas of the Commonwealth of Australia. I raise those matters because the 3,000-odd people involved in teaching in the Northern Territory have very special problems which probably are not being catered for adequately in terms of both training and retraining of teachers.

If a teaching service in the Northern Territory is to have impact, for example, on the many language difficulties which Aboriginal children have, being subject to diverse cultural and language influences and, particularly, if difficulties are to be overcome in teaching Aboriginal children in their own languages, then there is a need for much greater attention, whether it be by the Commonwealth Government or by the Northern Territory Government, to the training of teachers who, I hope, will do that sort of work. In a sense, the Commonwealth has washed its hands of these problems by transferring the responsibilities of the teaching service to the Northern Territory. The Commonwealth Government has responsibilities in respect of Aboriginals throughout Australia-constitutional responsibilities-and one would hope that the expression I used, 'the Commonwealth has washed its hands of these problems', would not prove to be correct and that the Commonwealth will continue to maintain a careful interest in the operation of the Northern Territory Teaching Service, particularly as it relates to the teaching of Aboriginal children and also to the problems of remoteness and isolation which I mentioned earlier.

The legislation provides provisions for teachers to transfer from the Commonwealth Teaching Service to the Northern Territory Teaching Service. There are also provisions in the legislation for transfer back from the Northern Territory Teaching Service to the Commonwealth Teaching Service. As the Minister pointed out in his second reading speech, a Re-appointments Review Committee is to be established to determine eligibility for re-appointment to the Commonwealth Teaching Service under conditions specified in clauses of the Bill. I think it is of the utmost concern that the Commonwealth continue-if I may use this expression about the Commonwealth-to apply its mind to the question of the needs of teachers in the Northern Territory. One particular need may well be to ensure that the Northern Territory Teaching Service does not stagnate in the sense that the 3,000-odd teachers do not have any opportunities for the exchange of views and experience with teachers outside that Service and that the Northern Territory teaching service is not deprived of the capacity to take teachers from elsewhere and, in turn, to send its teachers into other systems.

The point I make is that I hope that in the future the question of transferability of teachers in and out of the Northern Territory Teaching Service will be looked at with a little more imagination and flexibility than is apparent in the present legislation. I make that as a constructive suggestion because of the importance of the teaching service in the most multicultural part of Australia, the Northern Territory. The problems of that Service are likely to be very considerable. Those problems could only benefit from the capacity for exchange, new experience and new blood coming into the Service. I hope that those matters will be taken on board by the Government for further consideration because, in launching the Northern Territory Teaching Service, there is a very real danger that the Commonwealth will say: 'It is no longer any concern of ours'. We in this chamber will know if the Commonwealth abdicates its responsibilities, particularly in respect of Aborigines, as it has in some States of the Commonwealth, and the standards, which I hope the Commonwealth Parliament insists on, tend to decline. That can be seen-not to put too fine a point on it-in the States of Queensland and Western Australia, for example. Let us make sure that in regard to this legislation that sort of possibility does not arise. Having made those comments, Mr Acting Deputy President, I otherwise commend the Bill to the Senate as a sensible and non-controversial machinery measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not oppose this Bill, for the reasons which have been outlined by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Button) and which are reinforced by the Northern Territory Teachers Federation. I have discussed this matter with the Federation and it is quite happy that both of the Bills should go forward. I take the opportunity to mention briefly one or two matters which the Government might care to look at. A couple of these have been alluded to by my leader, but I will still go through them. I am pleased that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) is at the table. A couple of the matters that I wish to raise are relevant to his portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall comment initially on the provision for re-entry into the Commonwealth Teaching Service, which is provided for by this Bill. When the CTS was first established some years ago there was an exodus from Darwin to Canberra. I think this was understandable. Many people had spent many years in the outback and welcomed the opportunity to move to Canberra. That movement has slowed down over the years. Whilst that early exodus was understandable I, and I am sure my colleagues in the Northern Territory-I was in the Department of Education at that time-saw it as unfortunate. Yet there needs to be-I make this point very strongly-an ease of movement in and out of the Teaching Service to allow the movement of people from the Australian Capital Territory into the Northern Territory, from the tertiary and further education colleges into the Northern Territory and so on. Teachers need to get to the Australian Capital Territory to attend the Australian National University and other institutions to upgrade their qualifications. Children need to get to the Australian Capital Territory to undertake university studies and so on. So there is a need for people to be able to move in and out.

There is another real need. If teachers who are thinking of going north see that they might not be able to get back to the Australian Capital Territory they will be reluctant to take that step. So we want an ease of movement from the north to the Australian Capital Territory and from the Australian Capital Territory up to the top. There have been machinery measures in the past to get specialists into the Northern Territory. I refer to art specialists, physical education specialists, music specialists and so on. These movements were originally covered by a secondment provision. In fact, in 1964 I went to the Northern Territory on secondment from Western Australia. There are disadvantages connected with secondment, but I do not think I have to go through them at this stage. Let me reinforce the point that in the Northern Territory we need to get the sort of cross-fertilisation which comes from experienced teachers moving there from the south. I think we can say without being criticised for it that there are some advantages in people from here going north, gaining experience with Aboriginal children and then returning with their experiences having been broadened.

I wish to draw the Minister's attention to a couple of areas of concern upon which he may care to comment and a couple which he may prefer to refer to someone else. I refer firstly to the Guidance and Special Services Section of the Northern Territory Department of Education. There is a particular need in the Northern Territory for a service such as the Guidance and Special Services Section. The Northern Territory has a comparatively large population of servicemen. As we all know, a ridiculous situation exists in the Services whereby personnel are moved every two years. I have criticised this practice previously in the Senate. A large number of the children of servicemen become clients of the Guidance and Special Services Section. They develop social, emotional and other problems, not the least of which is educational, because of this constant movement. We can do nothing about that. I have raised the matter with senior officers in the Services and they are not prepared to change this policy. What we must do, therefore, is to cater for these children. So we must have a good Guidance and Special Services Section to cater for them.

There are a number of disadvantaged families in the Northern Territory. Of course I do not again have to go through the problems of the Aboriginal families living in towns. I refer to the problem of English as a second language, the problem of lack of experience in that vital nought to five years of age for which parents, through no fault of their own, have not been able to provide the sort of experiential background on which they can build later education. There are deprived non-Aboriginal families. These have basically the same problems as urban Aboriginal families have. They have been described by quite a number of terms, but culturally deprived might be one of the best. So we have a strong need for guidance and special services particularly in the remedial reading area.

I have some sense of achievement in saying that there was a good Guidance and Special Services Section some years ago. I think it is a pity that in the last five years there has been a change of direction in the way in which this section operates and that there has also been a shortage of funds to enable it to operate effectively. Many of us have made the point that a small system needs basically the same infrastructure as a large system does. We have to look at the Northern Territory as being a State and having many of the States' requirements. We have to have a body to meet these requirements. If one person handles them in New South Wales we need the same one person in the Northern Territory.

Whilst the responsibility lies with the Northern Territory some assistance is needed. Senator Carrick, when he was Minister for Education, said that in the Northern Territory he would set the standard for the rest of Australia. Certainly, he took some steps in that direction, but it is fair to say that the bulk of Australia would not want to follow some of the standards in the Northern Territory at the moment. This is not the Northern Territory's fault. I understand that the Northern Territory has asked for additional funds. The particular project I have in mind is the Aboriginal outstation movement. The Territory has asked for funds for this movement, and its request has been denied. I take particular exception to that because the Federal Government allowed the outstation movement, or the homelands centre movement, whatever it may be called, to be established. It must not desert the movement at this stage, by withdrawing or withholding its finance. It is too much to expect the Territory Government to carry the whole exercise by itself. It is beyond what any State government would be expected to do. I put it to the Minister that he give some thought to providing extra finance to that most valuable outstation movement.

A similar situation is occurring in relation to the Batchelor Teacher Education Centre. Some honourable senators will know that the Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory are trained over three years and that those three years are interpersed with work in their schools. They spend their time at the Teacher Education Centre at Batchelor. Because of government policy relating to finance and staff ceilings, the people who move away from their schools to go to Batchelor for this vital extra training are not replaced. So initially there is some reluctance to let people go. When a headmaster sees that these people must not be denied this opportunity he is left with one, two or three people short on his staff. This is just not good enough. Schools, children and the whole community are deprived when the people, firstly, are denied the opportunity to go or, secondly, are not replaced if they get that opportunity.

Aboriginal teachers are vital. We do not have to debate this matter. All honourable senators who have been connected with education in the Northern Territory would like to see the Aboriginalisation of the whole of the system up to the Director. This will not happen unless we see a steady growth of teachers. Aboriginal parents also see the need for their people to be trained. I was advised that on Tuesday of this week, the parents in the Maningrida, Milingimbi, Goulburn Island and Galiwinku communities all kept their children at home in protest at the fact that the Department was not replacing Aboriginal teaching assistants who were going to Batchelor.

Another area to concern is migrant education, both adults and children. I think it is fair to say that the Northern Territory has probably the most cosmopolitan group of people in Australia. There is a variety of ethnic backgrounds. There is a continual influx of people from European countries. Many of the local children who were born in Darwin come to school at the age of five or six years with no knowledge of English. So there is still a problem even with children who are born in the Territory. There are Timorese children in the Territory. Unfortunately, there is only a slow dribble into the Territory. Nevertheless they are continuing to come to Australia and they need to be looked after. There is no need for the sort of school that was established in 1975 to cope with the large numbers who came out at that time, but ongoing help is needed. I am sure that Senator Kilgariff, who opened the Tamarind Centre recently, will support the proposition that the Vietnamese population-both children and adults-need some assistance.

Senator Davidson is not in the chamber, but we could not mention education in the Northern Territory without mentioning the Davidson report on education of isolated school children. I commend the recommendations in this report to the Government. I will not go through them again. Several senators, including Senator Davidson, have been through them. They are still relevant. I would like the Government to give a clear indication of what it intends to do. Those of us who were fortunate enough to go to the Canadian High Commission recently to see the Telidon demonstration appreciate just what opportunities are available for isolated people, including isolated children through this form of technology. That is another avenue for the Government to look at when it is thinking of facilities to be provided for isolated children. This sort of thing cannot be provided simply by a State; there will have to be some federal assistance also.

While on the subject of communications, I trust that when the Dix committee brings down its recommendations they will include some which will enable the children of the Northern Territory to have school broadcasts the year round. We might even get some of our own instead of taking them from Queensland when it is convenient for Queensland to let us have them.

At the tertiary level the students' living accommodation problem that I have mentioned previously in this place has now been partially overcome with the setting up of the Young Men's Christian Association-Young Women's Christian Association hostel. I hope that the Government will look at further campus accommodation and let the Darwin Community College do the job for which it was established. I hope that wise counsel will prevail and that we will not see a university in the Northern Territory. I know that there has been a change in the basic thinking of the university. The concept is now of something special and not of just another Flinders or another Murdoch. Without pursuing this very far, let us get to the point of saying: ''We will build this university and set it up if the Federal Government gives us money'. The Federal Government, through its Tertiary Education Commission, has made it quite clear that it does not intend to give us money. So we might as well direct our energies in the Northern Territory to making sure that the Community College does the job for which it was set up and that we do not divert funds which are vitally needed in other areas to setting up something which was, let us face it, only a political gimmick at the time it was introduced.

I have spoken previously of the uniqueness of the Northern Territory situation. I will not dwell on it again. I simply remind Ministers of the particular problems of the Northern Territory and ask them to consider ways of providing finance to assist. In conclusion I make the point that we do not oppose either of the two Bills which are before us at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank both honourable senators who have taken part in this cognate debate on two associated Bills, the purpose of which has been set out by the speakers who preceded me. It is good to hear honourable senators with specific professional knowledge bringing that knowledge into debates in the Senate. I acknowledge that the speaker who preceded me has a professional background in this area which makes his contribution particularly apposite. I understand that these Bills are the result of an approach made to us by the Northern Territory itself and that this approach has the support of all the appropriate authorities there, including the Teachers Federation and other bodies which would have been involved in the discussions which led to the Bills. For that reason I do not think it is really appropriate to use the phrase that was used by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) when he said that the Commonwealth was washing its hands. The Commonwealth is in fact responding to an approach from within the Northern Territory to take a step really to overcome an inconsistent situation in which the Northern Territory had responsibility for the teaching function but did not have the responsibility to employ its own teachers or to have its own teaching service.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senators who spoke in this debate made a number of specific points, and I will just take a moment to respond to some of them. The Commonwealth will maintain its membership of the Bilingual Education Consultative Committee. A Department of Aboriginal Affairs committee is responsible for allocating funds, certainly in the area of education. Some concern was expressed that there may be some kind of diminution in effort or involvement in Aboriginal education. I think that point is worth making. The Commonwealth has already had discussions at officer level with people in the Northern Territory and has offered the Northern Territory the opportunity to make use of existing Commonwealth Teaching Service expertise, particularly in the early stages of the operation of the Northern Territory Teaching Service which, as I think all honourable senators will know, was created this week or last week by legislation of the Northern Territory. That arrangement, of course, could be extended or continued as an ongoing arrangement, as seems suitable to the parties as time goes on.

Another matter raised by Senator Robertson was the situation which occurred on, I think, 3 March at Maningrida, Millingimbi, Galiwinku and, I think, Goulburn Island, where students were kept at home as a protest at the failure of the Department of Education to replace teaching assistants who were attending courses at the Batchelor college. Of course, this is appropriately a matter for the Northern Territory but it is of interest to the Senate in the context of what we are discussing today. The Northern Territory Government is finding it difficult to respond to immediate Aboriginal needs at all communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because they are short of money, that is the reason.

—We have been informed that, whilst the Northern Territory Administration is attempting to overcome the situation, it may take some time before the backlog is fully met. It has not been possible to provide replacements at all schools in all cases, but it is not true to say that there have been no replacements in any situations. In fact some replacements have been made already. I understand the Northern Territory Teachers Federation has criticised the Education Department for the situation that has arisen in the areas that were mentioned by name. I understand that an approach has been made to my Department in Darwin seeking assistance in the form of extra grants. There is a proposal that there should be funding of 20 extra positions of assistant teachers during the 1981-82 program. That proposal is currently being evaluated. I cannot say how it will be resolved, but it is currently under consideration. A number of other matters were raised. I will just mention one of them. The Northern Territory has already put in an application to the Commonwealth Grants Commission for special funds, which would include extra funds for outstations. That was another point raised by Senator Robertson in his contribution. That application is still under consideration and the total amount being sought is approximately $52m.
—Over five years?

—I do not know. I can obtain an answer to that for the honourable senator. Having made those observations in response to matters raised by those who contributed to the debate, I thank honourable senators for their contributions and commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 26 February, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
