That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, may I suggest to the Senate that the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill 1981 and the Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill 1981 be taken in cognate debate? The questions will, of course, be put separately at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the Senate that that course be followed? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill is quite an important and significant piece of legislation for two reasons: First, it highlights the hypocrisy of this Government on the whole issue of a national police force. Honourable senators will recall what was said during 1972-75 when the then Opposition rejected attempts by the Whitlam Labor Government to set up a national police force-Australia Police. One has only to look back at the debates at that time to see the arguments that were produced and the slanderous statements that were made about the endeavours to rationalise our police forces that were operating in the national centre. Of course the then Senator Murphy was traduced and harassed about those proposals as was his successor in the other place, Mr Enderby. It is incredible that, after raising various spectres of a vicious super-police apparatus, we now have the same forces, the same group, the same conservative coalition proceeding in government to carry out the thrust of re-organising the two police forces into the Australia Police. It is also adopting a number of the propositions of the Whitlam Government in respect of complaints against police.

SPEECH.PARA: More generally, the Bill is significant in that it purports to deal with one of the greatest problems in our society-the misuse of power by those in authority. As we know, all the States are following, as the Commonwealth now is, procedures which establish a process by which citizens can seek remedy for the misuse of powers by those in authority, in this case, the Australian Police. All States have now found it necessary to establish an Ombudsman service by which citizens can seek relief against the activities of public authorities. This Bill seeks to provide a means by which citizens can seek some relief from the actions taken against them by members of the Australian Police. It has to be stressed here that one needs to be a very courageous sort of person to lay an information against someone in authority, particularly someone in the police force. One needs not only courage but also some resource and some strength of character to do so because, inevitably, it is a case of a citizen taking on a goliath. So often many citizens who have justifiable complaints against the police do not avail themselves of the processes available to them.

The Commonwealth Ombudsman's report which was presented to the Parliament just recently reveals a number of instances in which the Commonwealth Ombudsman has had complaints referred to him relating to the deficiencies in, attitudes of and complaints about the behaviour of the police, some of which can be said to have been justified and, of course, some which were found to be unjustified. The Opposition takes the view that the rights of the citizen are paramount in these matters. We do so because we believe the citizen is put in an invidious position, a secondary position, in our society. Taking into account the way in which our society is structured the citizen is at a disadvantage compared with those in authority.

In saying that, I do not wish to smear the police force because it, too, is in a difficult position. It is very difficult for police officers to make an on-the-spot value judgment in respect of many of the borderline cases that they have to deal with. We concede that the vast majority of police officers carry out their duties in a fair, proper and quiet way. Nevertheless, we are concerned for those citizens who feel, rightly or wrongly, that their rights have been abused. They seek, therefore, to have their complaints dealt with in a fair and reasonable way. From the point of government, it is important that those processes are seen to be fair and to operate fairly because the credibility of the police force itself is at stake. If people do not know that they have rights and are not in a position to exercise them without fear or favour, the police could easily fall into a position of disrepute.

My position is one of some bias towards the citizen because I believe the citizen so often is placed in a position where he is subject to actions which, in his view, often are not properly carried out by the arresting officer. I think there is plenty of evidence of that in the various reports that have come before us. There is certainly plenty of evidence of that in the States to the extent that the governments in the various States have seen fit to pass legislation similar to that which we are now discussing in order to protect the rights of citizens.

Having made those remarks, let me say that my party does not oppose the Bill. We have been persuaded that the Bill is a very important step forward in providing a process by which citizens can seek some relief. Nevertheless, we still say that it is far from perfect because all the recommendations that were made by the Australian Law Reform Commission have not been adopted, although the Government does seem to have adopted a great proportion of the recommendations of that Commission. However, we still believe that the Bill has some deficiencies. We would like to see this matter re-examined in a couple of years to see whether the procedures which are outlined in this Bill are working in the best interests of the citizen.

Let us look at what these deficiencies are as the Opposition sees them. The first is the general weakening of the role of the Ombudsman as opposed to that set out in the Law Reform Commission report 1978, a report, which, incidentally, is now just over two years old. The main issue I would like to discuss is why the Government did not take steps to give the Ombudsman the power to make a formal recommendation that charges be laid. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) referred to this in his second reading speech, at page 171 of the Hansard. On this issue the Law Reform Commission said:

It appears to the Commission that where such an extreme circumstance arose the Ombudsman, as an external and independent guardian of civilian rights, should have the right to ensure that charges are brought so that they can be fairly determined. Clearly it is open to the Ombudsman to express his view on a matter to the Commissioner without making a formal recommendation to charge. In all but the most exceptional case it is envisaged that there would be accord between the approach of the Commissioner and the approach of the Ombudsman. If a situation arose where the Commissioner had good reasons for not accepting the Ombudsman's suggested course of action, these should be made known to the Ombudsman. If a difference still existed, it remains appropriate, in the Commission's view. This right would supplement the Ombudsman's existing rights of report to the Prime Minister or Parliament.

There are many other matters about which the Opposition is concerned. I should like to discuss one or two of them. One is the uncertainty that is caused by that part of the legislation which deals with the role of the Ombudsman. We are now to have two legislation Acts covering the role of the Ombudsman in this area as the Bill before us duplicates the existing provisions in the Ombudsman's Bill. I ask the Minister to clarify this point when he replies. We of the Opposition did have some misgivings about this area of the legislation but as we were persuaded that the legislation was an improvement on some of the processes which exist in the States we decided to give our support to the legislation.

Nevertheless, we were concerned that the role of the complainant, as difficult as it is-I am sure that will be conceded by honourable senators-has been reduced. There is a great danger that, in unscrupulous hands, the procedures laid down in the legislation could denegrate into a charade. I am not suggesting that it will. Much depends on the way in which the Disciplinary Tribunal works and much depends upon the personality of the Commissioner. My view is that one way to avoid a degeneration is to have the complainant involved as much as possible. The legislation imposes some restrictions in that respect.

I stress that it is vital that the procedures for investigating complaints be as flexible as possible. From all the evidence that is available to us and certainly from the Ombudsman's report the impression is that the present Commissioner takes a fair-minded approach to the rights of citizens. But of course much depends upon the personality of the person who holds that important position. As far as is practicable, the legislation should be designed to create an inflexible position in respect of the way in which these matters are handled. We would like, for example, to see a regular review of the processes so that the mechanism does not rust and trap a citizen between the cogs as so often happens in these sorts of matters because of the way in which bureaucracy works generally.

I do not suggest that in the future the Ombudsman will take an action which would remedy the problem of defective administration relating to personal property but one cannot help feeling very strongly about the rights of the person who on arrival in Australia was arrested on a narcotics charge, and subsequently convicted and imprisoned, and the difficulty he had in respect of his return airline ticket. Whilst the Ombudsman has clearly stated that the Australian Federal Police acted properly throughout the incident, the fact is that the person who was charged and found guilty paid the penalty of being imprisoned and also suffered a financial loss in respect of his airline ticket. It might be argued that ultimately the Ombudsman will find a means by which some relief may be granted to the complainant. But in the view of the prisoner it was the members of the Australian Federal Police who were responsible because they were the ones who arrested him and they were the ones to whom he made the complaint to get some compensation for the loss of his return airline ticket. I do not believe that citizen should be penalised twice for the one crime. The fact is that the matter has not been cleared up satisfactorily from the point of view of the citizen. Other cases show that citizens from time to time feel that the Australian Federal Police have not acted in the best interests of the force or protected the basic civil rights of the complainant.

The Opposition could have proposed a number of amendments to this legislation. We in fact considered moving amendments. It is interesting that the Government proposes to bring forward an amendment to the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill in relation to the appearance of the complainant or his legal representative before the Disciplinary Tribunal. The proposed amendment is a very useful alteration to the procedures. It does take up one of the points at issue which the Opposition did look at.

The Opposition is glad to note that under the Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill vicarious liability is to be granted to police. This move also is long overdue and I am sure that all members of the Federal Police will be glad that this move is being made. The Australian Law Reform Commission recommended this change two years ago. It is pleasing that this recommendation has been taken on board by the Government. It has acted in respect of complaints that were certainly prevalent in the States against their forces following the demonstrations against the war in Vietnam. Many members of the State police forces removed identification badges from their uniforms and proceeded to act in a manner which reflected upon their own incapacities to deal with the public indignation at Australia's involvement in the war in Vietnam. It was finally determined by the State authorities that at all demonstrations policemen should wear their identification badges. We are pleased-this is a factor that has led us to support the legislation-that this is provided for in this legislation. In those circumstances, the Opposition will neither oppose the legislation nor oppose the proposed amendment which has been circulated today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill 1981 and the Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill 1981. These are two parts of the Government's reform legislation and are an excellent carrying out of the recommendations made by the Australian Law Reform Commission in its report in 1975 and its subsequent report in 1978. I listened with almost agitation at first to Senator Gietzelt's original blast which appeared to suggest that he had severe reservations about the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill. But it was not long before, in the ebb and flow of his speech, he made it clear that he regarded the Bill as an important step forward in providing relief for citizens, but that it was far from perfect. I suppose that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) could not expect to get a commendation for the Bill's being perfect. I do not suppose that we have ever passed a Bill in this Parliament that was perfect. But I think this Bill has been the subject of a great deal of examination and consideration and it is a very worthy tribute to the efforts of the Attorney-General and his staff.
—A tribute to his speed, too.

—Senator Evans said the legislation is a tribute to the Attorney-General's speed. Speed has not been altogether easy to achieve in this matter. One realises that over a period there have been considerable changes to the Australian Federal Police. A new structure was created. Since then discussions between the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police and the Commonwealth Ombudsman have led to the introduction of some of the clauses in the Bill. At first sight they may appear complicated but the various responsibilities of these bodies have been worked out and a system created which may work, I think, quite effectively. This justifies a certain amount of time being taken in achieving that result.

SPEECH.PARA: We do have a problem in this community, which Senator Gietzelt referred to when he spoke about the need for individuals to be courageous in lodging complaints. No doubt there are risks in lodging complaints against police. Here I speak of complaints made against police throughout the country, not so much in the Federal sphere. I think that very few complaints are made against the Australian Federal Police. But there have been many more problems and inquiries into police forces in the various States of Australia. I am particularly familiar with the Beach inquiry in Victoria and the Beach report and subsequent dealings with that report. I realise that some people who complained found that they suffered very considerably and were embarrassed. Accordingly, they had to show much courage in coming before the commissioner, now Mr Justice Beach, with complaints which often were found to be thoroughly justified. The inquiry was helpful not only in Victoria but also in other States because it was a fearless inquiry and resulted in a fearless report. The report, I think, has helped in making people throughout Australia understand that although this is a democratic country things can happen. In a police force in which there is a majority of sincere, conscientious, hard-working policemen, there always will be a number of bad hats. It is therefore important that complaints be examined properly and that justice not only be done but appear to be done and that people have the opportunity of being heard in regard to complaints which they make about police misconduct. This Bill offers such a system and is therefore worthwhile.

I will not go into the details of what is achieved by this Bill at great length because the second reading speech by the Attorney-General gives an admirable summary of the effective things which this Bill does. It states:

. . . its purpose' 'is to establish a system which permits just and thorough investigation of complaints against police, while at the same time upholding morale and discipline in the difficult work police have to do'.

The second aspect of that has led to the delicate arrangement between the work which will be done under the provisions of this Bill by the newly created Internal Investigation Division, which is in operation by administrative action and which will be regularised by this Bill, and the efforts which the Ombudsman will make in the consideration of complaints. I believe that the Ombudsman has a very substantial role to play. Senator Gietzelt complained about duplications in this Bill and the Ombudsman Act. Indeed, I was puzzled by that complaint because I think that the Bill does the opposite. One variation recommended by the Law Reform Commission which has been accepted is that separate powers conferred in the Ombudsman Act are not to be maintained when the Ombudsman is dealing with complaints against police. In fact, the powers of the Ombudsman have been written into this Bill so that these powers can be seen clearly by people who want to check the rights of individuals in dealing with complaints against the police force.

When complaints have been made about practices and procedures of the force-that is, the more general complaints that may be made about more than one individual's problem-these ordinarily will be investigated by the Ombudsman. By and large, other complaints about an individual officer's work or action will be investigated initially by the Internal Investigation Division. Thereafter, if the Ombudsman is dissastisfied with the investigation by the Investigation Division, he can ask for a further investigation to be carried out or carry out an investigation through his office. He is in the position of being able to second guess, to try to elucidate further facts. In addition, under special circumstances, the Bill provides special procedures for the Commissioner and the Ombudsman to agree to either the Ombudsman or a person outside making some initial investigation of a complaint. There is also a provision, where they cannot agree, for the Minister for Administrative Services to make a decision.

I think a complaint was made by Senator Gietzelt that one recommendation from the Law Reform Commission's report that was not accepted was that the Ombudsman should be able to make a formal recommendation that charges proceed. There is, of course, recognition that the taking away of the formal responsibilities of the Commissioner could be damaging to his standing and be damaging to morale in the police force. It is provided, however, that if there is disagreement on whether charges should be lodged then the Minister will make the final decision. He has a responsibility to Parliament. These matters will be reported to Parliament. Therefore, provision has been made for a third party to make a final decision on whether a charge is to be lodged against a policeman after investigation.

There are, of course, substantial provisions in the Bill for the setting up of a Federal Police Disciplinary Tribunal. The Tribunal may in many cases, be constituted by a judge of the Federal Court of Australia or of the Supreme Court of a State or Territory, or in some cases by a magistrate. When the Tribunal is constituted by a judge, the penalties may be imposed by him. Different provisions apply in relation to appeals whether the Tribunal is constituted by a judge or a magistrate.

I suggest, that the variations from reports of the Commission are seen, on reflection, to be very minor ones. They are usually matters of judgment which, I think, in all cases, are sound judgments. They are set out in detail in the second reading speech of the Attorney-General. I think they are worthy of justification. One, which I will refer to later, is the subject of an amendment of which the Government has given notice and which I strongly support. The Bills demonstrate that very careful consideration has been given to the needs of the public and also the needs to maintain a police force in which the substantial power of the Commissioner are not in any way vitiated or destroyed.

The second Bill, as we are aware, amends the Australian Federal Police Act and provides for vicarious liability in the case of civil claims concerning the Commonwealth. It applies in cases where police are involved in civil claims and it overcomes an anomaly which has existed for many years. It also provokes the provision in regard to the identification of the police.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does 'vicarious' mean in this sense? Please explain the word.
—Second hand.

—It means second hand, as my colleague says. It concerns the liability of the Commonwealth for the actions of a second party-of one of its servants-and the liability which that servant engages, he also being responsible. If he has no assets or no means whatsoever it is very important that the Commonwealth, as employer, should accept that responsibility. It does in most other areas of activity in the Public Service, but curiously it does not in a policeman's action. Of course, this could mean that in court judgments against policemen-perhaps for substantial damages or for damages for assault-if the policeman is worthless financially it is quite wrong that the person should not be able to recover those damages. I think this provision is a very useful alteration of the law.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of the consideration of this Bill there have been many discussions, I know, between the Commissioner and the Ombudsman. These discussions have resulted finally in the scheme which is set out in this Bill. I am aware that there have also been discussions between the law and government committee of the Government parties and the Attorney-General and his officers. I thank him for the assistance he has given to the members of that committee in the consideration of this Bill. In the recess that committee put up quite a number of proposals which, in almost every case, have been accepted by the Attorney-General. I think they have added to the clarification of the Bill and the way in which it may be effective.

A further matter arises in the amendment which will be moved in the Committee stage and which I should say a little bit more about. I shall say something on that matter now so I will not need to repeat my remarks when the amendment is actually moved. I refer to the situation which arises when a complainant would not, under the Bill as originally drafted, have any right to appear and be represented by counsel in proceedings before the Tribunal. Anyone who has read some of the reports in the States will realise that not always is an investigating policeman all that anxious to proceed to look into a complaint. Some complaints are not looked at thoroughly and the complainant has a just cause to complain about that. Perhaps his credit is affected. He wants to see justice done and if he is merely a witness before the Tribunal he may find himself without any strength in pressing his case.

In the Australian Law Reform Commission report of 1975 reference was made to this proposal. A number of people had given evidence before the Commission and had suggested that they should be entitled to be represented. It was not suggested and it is not proposed, of course, that the complainant should be an actual party or that the mistake should be made of such a polarisation of police and citizen interest that they would be seen as being opposite parties to each other, but there should be a right for a representation by the complainant so that he can be protected and his views can be properly expressed. In the first report the Law Reform Commission gave on this subject, at paragraph 175, it stated:

At the same time, the special interests of the complainant and the policeman concerned have to be recognised. It would be unreal to suppose that they have insufficent 'interest' to support an appearance. In the Commission's opinion the hearing can be prevented from becoming outright litigation between the complainant and the accused member of the police.
The report went on:

The just rights of the policeman and member of the public can be protected by ensuring that the policeman charged has a right to representation and the complainant a privilege to seek leave of the Tribunal to be represented.

The Commission's putting it in that lesser way is, of course, a recognition that generally speaking witnesses in litigation do not have any rights. In a prosecution of some person a witness is protected by the Crown and does not generally have a right of appearance. Nonetheless, in these complaints and these types of proceedings that witness may have a very considerable interest.

In the second report, which came about after the setting up of the Australian Federal Police, the Commission considered and then reported to the Attorney-General on the matter of complaints against police. In paragraph 115 of the report of 1978 the Commission stated:

The Complainant The complainant is not a party to proceedings before the tribunal. In the Commission's first report it was proposed that the complainant might, by leave of the tribunal, appear before it on the hearing of a charge arising out of his complaint. He might be represented but should only take such part in the proceedings as the tribunal permits. Normally, the carriage of the charge will remain with the police. Within the discretion of the tribunal, there may be good reasons why it should be possible for the complainant to be represented and otherwise to participate, where that is appropriate. The success of the adversary system depends in part upon vigorous, motivated adversaries. The facility to permit the complainant an active role will be a security against half-hearted prosecution on the part of police. In most cases the complainant will be simply one witness and the need for representation of his own would in such circumstances not be established without more. If leave to appear is granted provision should be made for financial assistance by the Commonwealth towards costs and expenses.

The amendment of which the Attorney-General has give notice today makes it clear that it should be only special circumstances that justify the Tribunal's allowing a person to be represented. To give that right and to enable the Tribunal thereby to judge the circumstances and grant that right under such limited terms as it may think fit is, I think, a useful amendment and one which I trust the Senate will support.

I wish to refer to one other matter. Government members who were considering this matter had some doubt about the fact that there was no recognition in the Bill of the standard of proof that would be required before the Tribunal in its hearing of charges. It has been clearly pointed out that this matter has been fairly decisively determined by Mr Justice Fox in Scanes v. Wilson which is reported at page 262 of the 1974 Federal Law Reports. I would like to quote from that judgment because I think it is important to realise that in the hearing of these disciplinary charges the standard of proof is very clearly not the criminal standard of proof beyond reasonable doubt but the civil standard. The judge, in his judgment dealing with appearances before a board and the standard applying, said:
The proceedings were of course disciplinary and not criminal-
I will leave out the case to which he then referred. He went on to say:

The standard of proof in disciplinary proceedings against legal practitioners is on a balance of probabilities . . . The board was of the view that it was following precedent established in the States, but I have made inquiries and I find that the Crown Employees' Appeal Board in New South Wales, which deals with police appeals, among others, applies the civil standard, of proof on a balance of probabilities . . .
The judge also said:
The gravity of a charge is of course always a matter which influences the mind when applying that standard.
He made reference to Mr Justice Dixon, as he then was, and his judgment in Briginshaw v. Briginshaw. That noted judge said:

Except upon criminal issues to be proved by the prosecution, it is enough that the affirmative of an allegation is made out to the reasonable satisfaction of the tribunal. But reasonable satisfaction is not a state of mind that is attained or established independently of the nature and consequence of the fact or facts to be proved. The seriousness of an allegation made, the inherent unlikelihood of an occurrence of a given description, or the gravity of the consequences flowing from a particular finding are considerations which must affect the answer to the question whether the issue has been proved to the reasonable satisfaction of the tribunal.

It appears fairly clear that the standard of proof of this Tribunal is reasonably fixed and does not require to be set out in the Bill. I believe that this Bill is an excellent contribution by the Government to the law reform program. It is important that we carry out, where possible, the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission. I hope that the same will apply to criminal investigation which is to some extent a neighbouring and very significant area. It is not that we see or have seen at present or in the past examples of mistakes or a great deal of objectionable action by Commonwealth Police. It is important that we have a system in operation which effectively deals with the area and which means that citizens can approach if they wish the Ombudsman, in this case, or sometimes the police, and make their complaints and know that they will be dealt with. They know that in making complaints-one has to be realistic-great dangers are involved. A policeman or other person against whom a charge is made can be vindictive and can do damage to the complainant.

It is important, therefore, that a proper system shall exist in our law which enables these complaints to be properly investigated. It may be that this particular system does not work perfectly and will need changes. No doubt those concerned with law reform will keep watching it. I believe that this will be a good system and will work effectively. Some of the States have experienced complaints, reports and detailed investigations. The Lucas reports about police activity in Queensland are one example. It has been stated that complaints have not been properly investigated. Judges also have complained in recent years. I do not pick that example out as one that is in any way unique. We know that proper methods do not exist in Queensland and other States for investigating complaints against police.

I trust that the proposals which the Government has put forward will be accepted by this Parliament. I trust that they will be used by all those concerned, including the police, the Ombudsmen and the public in a very reasonable and sensible way, and that they will be vigilant to see that their rights are used. I support this Bill and the amendment of which the Attorney-General has given notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been an unconscionable time coming, but I welcome the introduction of this legislation very much. It is the first major set of recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission to be picked up and embodied in Commonwealth legislation. It amounts to an important set of institutional safeguards which will go a long way toward rebuilding public faith and confidence and maintaining that confidence in the conduct of our national police force. It must be said that confidence in the national police force and its components, the old Commonwealth Police and the Australian Capital Territory Police, has never been quite so lacking as it has been so conspicuously in respect of the Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australian and, on occasions, Northern Territory police forces. But, at the same time, there are instances and have been instances in recent times-I mention the Low affair in Western Australia and the conduct of the Commonwealth Police in the social security fraud case raids of not so long ago-where the conduct and credibility of our national police force and its component elements have been put in issue. It is crucially important for the maintenance, as I say, of community faith in the national police force for the future that there be a credible mechanism for the resolution of complaints of the kind that is embodied in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic structure of the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill, which is the major of the two Bills now before us, has been well articulated by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in his second reading speech and adverted to both by Senator Gietzelt and Senator Missen in their contributions. The Bill putting it simply creats a three-tier mechanism, each element in which has a significant component of independence. First of all, there is a more or less independent investigative unit established within the Australian Federal Police itself; secondly there is the Ombudsman and thirdly, there is an independent disciplinary tribunal presided over by a judge. Within that mechanism it is clear that the ombudsman's role is absolutely central and crucial to the success and credibility of the whole institutional structure.

The Ombudsman constitutes neutral territory for the receipt of complaints if a potential complainant should be intimidated, as is so often the case in practice, from going to the police themselves with the complaint. The Ombudsman monitors the role of the internal investigative squad, and in this sense is also an investigator of last resort if he, himself, is not satisfied with the conduct of the investigation by that internal unit. I am pleased that the Ombudsman's jurisdiction has ended up in this Bill now before us, after what has obviously been a fairly extended period of negotiation in almost the original form recommended by the Australian Law Reform Commission. It is in this respect that I cannot help noticing-more it is true in sorrow rather than anger, because this is the only State where the Law Reform Commission recommendations have been taken seriously at all-that the New South Wales Government, in picking up and purporting to apply the Law Reform Commission model to the development of its own complaints resolution machinery, has not gone as far as has the Commonwealth in accepting the terms of the Law Reform Commission's recommendations.

Under the Commonwealth Legislation, but regrettably not elsewhere, the Ombudsman does have the power to investigate, at the point of receiving complaints, and the general authority to monitor the conduct of the internal investigative unit. Furthermore, again unlike New South Wales, there is a procedure in this Bill by which the Commissioner can be directed to institute disciplinary proceedings even if he disagrees with the Ombudsman as to the merits of such proceedings. This latter point, however, in the form in which it appears in the Bill, amounts to a variation from the precise letter of the Law Reform Commission's recommendation. It appears to be perhaps the only significant looking variation from the recommendations of the Commission.

The Commission's recommendation, it will be recalled-this has been mentioned both by Senators Gietzelt and Missen-was that in extreme or exceptional cases where the Commissioner of Police and the Ombudsman disagreed as to whether a disciplinary charge should be brought, the Ombudsman's views should prevail. The Commission recommended that the Ombudsman should be empowered to make a formal recommendation which would, in fact, institute such a proceeding. What has been adopted in this Bill is not that, but a variation upon it in which, in a situation of conflict between the Ombudsman and the Commissioner of Police, the Attorney-General comes into the picture and plays referee to determine whether or not the charge shall be instituted. On balance, this seems to me to be a fairly sensible accommodation of the differing interests involved in what is obviously a very sensitive and potentially quite difficult area. I accept it on the basis that the Attorney-General is, under these circumstances, accountable to Parliament for his actions should he misconstrue the nature of his duties in these situations or misapply them.

I am also moved by the consideration that the Minister involved here, namely the Attorney-General, is not the Minister otherwise involved in the day to day administration of the Act; that remains with the Minister for Administrative Services. The latter Minister could perhaps be expected to have a close, perhaps too close, relationship with the police to be able to exercise proper judgment in these matters.

Another variation which has attracted attention on both sides of this chamber as amounting to a variation from the strict letter of the Commission's recommendations is that concerning the attendance or role of the complainant at proceedings of the Disciplinary Tribunal and in particular, the role of the complainant as a party, in a sense, to those proceedings. I note the terms of the amendment circulated by the Attorney-General and, like my colleague Senator Gietzelt, have no objections to the terms in which a compromise seems finally to have been effected on this matter. Indeed, I congratulate the Government for again showing some sensitivity to the substance, if not in every respect the form, of the Commission's recommendations.

There are some other variations from the Law Reform Commission's report but essentially they are of a minor or technical character and will not attract my critical attention in any way. I say all these things because I am used, in this place, to attracting some very critical remarks periodically from the Attorney about my obsession with the observance of the letter of these Commission reports. I want to indicate to him that I do, deep down inside, have a largeness of spirit about these matters which sometimes makes itself evident. However, I cannot let the Attorney-General off the hook entirely in respect of this legislation because there are some matters of which I am highly critical. They relate to the time it has taken to get this legislation enacted.

Let us recall for just a moment the saga involved here. Back in 1975 the Australian Labor Government decided for the most rational of reasons, which clearly subsequently were accepted by the present Government, to amalgamate the Commonwealth Police, the Australian Capital Territory and Northern Territory forces and the ill-starred Narcotics Bureau into a single national police force-Australia Police. It was in the context of that amalgamation proposal and the concern quite legitimately felt on our side of government that there was a necessity to accompany such a move by equally significant moves to delimit and identify and codify the powers of the new police force and to create the machinery for the resolution of complaints made about it. For those reasons we did send the reference to the Law Reform Commission which resulted in the first two reports of the Commission on complaints against police and criminal investigation generally. That was in 1975.

In 1976, of course, after the change of government, a decision was made to abandon the amalgamation proposal and with it, unfortunately, for the moment the Law Reform Commission's reports went into limbo. However, in 1977 the Government, with the then Attorney-General, Mr Ellicott, determined to reactivate both the criminal investigation and the complaints reports and in respect of the latter directed the Law Reform Commission to reconsider and rewrite as necessary its recommendations about complaints so as to make them applicable to a force still divided into its original components. The Law Reform Commission duly did that in its ninth report which is the one on which, clearly, the current legislation is based.

In 1978, however, at roughly the same time as the Law Reform Commission was reporting an appropriate structure for a disaggregated police force, the Government, in one of its more spectacular changes of mind which have characterised its progress since 1975, decided that amalgamation was not such a bad idea after all.

TALK.START.PARA: —That shows flexibility.

—The honourable senator uses the word 'flexibility' but there are other words and descriptions that spring more readily to mind. However, I do not think they are appropriate ones to deploy in a chamber of the gentlemanly character that the honourable senator is contributing to. So, particularly in the light of the grotesque character of the opposition that was expressed to the almost identical Labor Government proposals in 1975, hypocrisy seems to be an indispensible concomitant to this Government's decision making, even when it is heading in the right direction.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1979, the decision having been made to amalgamate the Commonwealth Police and the Australian territorial forces into what is now the Australian Federal Police, a Bill, of course, was introduced to accomplish this and it came before this Parliament in June 1979. The Bill lacked any accompanying set of provisions about complaint resolution machinery. In an endeavour to rectify that manifest deficiency the Opposition moved what may be remembered as one of the longest sets of amendments ever moved in this place, which amounted in effect to a proposal to embody within the parent Australian Federal Police Act the complaints resolution procedures specified and recommended by the Law Reform Commission. The Government rejected those amendments. Senator Chaney, then the relevant Minister, said that a separate complaints Bill would be brought before the Parliament 'later this year'-that was in June 1979.

On 6 November 1979 I rather churlishly asked Senator Chaney in this place what had happened to his promise to bring forward a separate complaints Bill by the end of the year. Senator Chaney's reply on 6 November was that he did not recall having made any such commitment but that he would let me have a reply in due course, which reply, in fact, was never forthcoming. In July 1980 a Press release issued by the present Attorney-General stated that he would in fact introduce a complaints Bill in the Budget session; that was the Budget session last year. Not until this year, on 26 February 1981, did we at last get such a Bill. This was five years after the basic draft was done by the Law Reform Commission; two and three-quarters years after the second draft of the re-write of that basic model was prepared by the Law Reform Commission in its subsequent report; 21 months after the Opposition introduced into this Parliament amendments which in their substance, if not in their actual form, were almost identical in every significant respect with the legislation brought on for debate today. I make the point that there is just no excuse for this kind of delay. This Government's commitment to lethargy in government seems to be almost ideological in character. It is a disappointing state of affairs.

I will make just two further points, both of which pick up matters mentioned very much in passing by Senator Missen. The first of them is simply this: I hope that this legislation will prove to be model legislation for the police forces of the Australian States and, indeed, for the Northern Territory as well. I have noted that its terms, embodying as they do the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission, have been adopted in part by New South Wales. I hope that New South Wales will now go the rest of the distance. Even more fervently I hope that the other States which have not adopted this essential model with its tripartite components of an internal unit, an Ombudsman and an independent tribunal will pick it up and apply it to their own circumstances. As I have already indicated I hope that this is done particularly in Queensland as was demonstrated by the Lucas report, particularly in Victoria, as was demonstrated by the Beach report, and particularly in Western Australia where there have been no official reports but where there has been ample demonstration in newspaper accounts of the character of police misbehaviour. Indeed, in almost every other jurisdiction in Australia there is a need for formal, sensitive and sensible machinery of the kind contained in this legislation.

The other and remaining point that I make is simply this: The complaints legislation before us today represents only half of the job. Back in 1975, as I have already indicated, when a new national police force was set in train and an amalgamation proposal was advanced, the then Government always envisaged it as being necessarily a two-pronged exercise so far as the accompanying legislation was concerned. It was envisaged that there would have to be complaints resolution machinery establishing effective disciplinary procedures and it was envisaged also that inextricably connected with it there would need to be legislation laying out a code of conduct in relation to criminal investigation powers generally-that is, the powers of police with respect to such things as arrest, interrogation, the right to silence, search and seizure, electronic surveillance, identification procedures and entrapment. In fact, as I have mentioned, the Law Reform Commission produced in its second report in 1975 not just a complaints model which was the subject of its first report but also a very detailed set of recommendations governing all these matters. I refer of course to the report on criminal investigation.

That report not only set out a code of behaviour under all those various heads and others as well but also indicated the kind of sanctions that were appropriate for breaches of that code of behaviour. One such sanction was an evidentiary one, that is to say, the potential loss of evidence illegally obtained by police when they brought their case to court. The other accompanying sanction related to disciplinary procedures being applicable to police officers who breached the basic ground rules. It was with that in mind that the disciplinary procedures involved in the independent police tribunal that is being created by this legislation was originally foreshadowed.

One of the saddest chapters in the application of what I have described elsewhere as Durack's law, that is the law that the affirmative response to reports of bodies such as the Law Reform Commission varies in inverse proportion to the importance of the subject matter and the quality of their supporting argument, has been in respect of that very same criminal investigation report. A Bill was introduced by Senator Durack's predecessor, Mr Ellicott, back in 1977. I do not seek to speak ill of the politically dead. In fact, I congratulate Mr Ellicott on producing that Bill, which did bring forward in very substantial part the recommendations of the Commission even though, in the Labor Party's view, there were spectacular inadequacies in respect of at least one part of that Bill. That Bill was subsequently withdrawn without ever being properly debated.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not withdrawn.

—It lapsed with the election at the end of 1977 and has not subsequently appeared. There has also been a very obvious resistance by this Government to any lingering temptation it might have had to pick up particular segments of those recommendations when it has had the opportunity to do so with the narcotics legislation and with the initial enactment of the Australian Federal Police Bill. I hope that now there will be at last some sign of energy and enthusiasm on the part of this Government for bringing forward proper criminal investigation legislation. I understand that the mills have been grinding slowly, that there is some redrafted version of this Bill now in existence deep within the bowels of the Attorney-General's Department and that it will perhaps appear at some future stage. I ask the Attorney-General, in his reply to the second reading debate, to give a clear and accurate indication of when we might expect that Bill to be brought forward. I urge him most strenuously to get on and complete the job that has been at last so splendidly begun with this legislation here today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to speak very briefly on the complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill 1981 and the Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill 1981. I do not intend to take up 20 minutes, as Senator Evans has done. For 20 minutes he spoke a lot of garbage. In any event, let me say that even the reluctant approval of the Opposition is something for which we are thankful and that congratulations from Senator Evans are high praise indeed. I would like to point out to the Senate very simply that these Bills constitute the implementation of another promise made by this Government and that the implementation of promises made by this Government always fail to get recognition by Opposition speakers and the media.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the attention of the Senate and the public at large to the effectiveness nowadays of the back bench committee system, which has produced an amendment which is acceptable to the Opposition and the chamber. Discussions which have taken place between the Attorney-General and a backbench committee, or Government members committee as some people like to call it, we have produced a Bill which, as I said, has received somewhat reluctant approval from the Opposition and congratulations from Senator Evans. It is not that I consider that the approval of Senator Evans is a criterion upon which the Government should consider introducing its legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —There must be something wrong.

—As my colleague Senator Hamer reminds me, that is perhaps an indication that there may be something wrong with the legislation. However, I praise the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) for his approach in this matter. He listens to what his colleagues have to say. He co-operates with us when possible and he shows a considerable understanding of our feelings in the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to relate to the Senate some of the things that are happening in the Australian Federal Police at present. As an introduction let me say that at the time the Labor Government introduced into the Parliament a Bill for the purpose of amalgamating the police forces of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory and the Commonwealth Police. I was the Minister for Police and Customs. I was transferred from another ministerial portfolio, I think, only for the purpose of trying to stop some of the opposition in Australia to the proposed Australian Police Bill. The Bill was introduced as a result of one of Whitlam's policies in the 1972 general election. One body which was in opposition to the Australian Police Bill was the Council for Civil Liberties, which is an Australia-wide organisation. The Council was firmly of the belief that the Government intended to set up a type of Federal Bureau of Investigation in Australia which would inquire and pry into the private life of every citizen in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: It was never our intention to do that. I had been a member of the Council's New South Wales branch before the South Australian Council was formed and I had been a member of the Council since its formation in my State. It was thought that, because of my record with the Council for Civil Liberties, this charge could not be sustained and would not be proceeded with. At the time of considering the Bill we had before us a report by Alan Carmody, who at that time was the head of the Department of Police and Customs. He had travelled the world on a government assignment to study the various police forces around the world. He came back with the suggestion of an Australian police force along the lines of the Canadian Mounted Police Force, which is not a mounted police force at present. There was also a proposal for the introduction of what was called Division 10, which was a Scotland Yard innovation, for the purpose of inquiring into complaints against the police. Of course a special division of men would have needed training for the purpose of inquiring into complaints. That would have been their main job.

At that time we had before us the report of an outside investigation and Mr Justice Kirby's report, one feature of which was that there was a role for the Commonwealth Ombudsman. From those reports we formulated the Australian Police Bill which was presented to the Parliament. Immediately the Bill was made known together with the results an outside investigation, the complaints of the Council for Civil Liberties ceased and the complaints of all Australian police forces commenced. I had deputations daily from both the Australian Capital Territory police and the Commonwealth Police, protesting about that legislation. A protest was made that there was some snobbery in the Australian Capital Territory Police and that because they were professional policemen they did not want to be associated with the Commonwealth Police. They did not want to be associated with those who guarded embassies and whom they called night watchmen. The Australian Capital Territory Police did not want to be associated because their opportunities for promotion in a bigger force would be fewer.

There was condemnation from both forces. All State police forces, through the federation of police, voiced opposition to the proposal that an investigation into complaints against the police be carried out by an outsider. Their argument was that there would be an investigation carried out by unqualified people who did not possess the investigative capabilities of a uniformed policeman or a detective. I received an invitation to speak to policemen in a club at Canberra where there was plenty to drink. The police were hostile and I had to be brave in standing up against most of the policemen of Canberra when I had to implement something to which they were opposed. However, because of the action in 1975 when the Government was dismissed, the legislation was never passed. In that election campaign an assurance was given to the Canberra police by the Liberal Party that it would not amalgamate the two forces, and for some years it did not. I believe it was some time after the Hilton Hotel bombing that an expert from England dealing with terrorism recommended that there should be one police force. Then the Government acted.

To stop the opposition of the police, no investigation provisions were incorporated in the enabling Bill. The Bill was introduced for the purpose of amalgamating the police forces, with promises of advantages to the police. My information is that those advantages were not provided. There are two sections and two wage rates within the police force today. Some personnel in the police force, who do exactly the same job as others, are on a lower rate of pay on some occasions. Examples can be seen at Adelaide airport. An officer who begins work at 4 o'clock to take over the duties of an officer who has been on duty all day may get paid a lower rate. The morale in the Australian Federal Police in the capital cities is very low. The members feel dissatisfied and disgruntled. There is the belief that there are still two police forces. The members of the Australian Federal Police, who perform and are paid for protective services, are not accepted by members of the old Australian Capital Territory police. There is a feeling amongst the officers of those forces that they are not getting the same treatment. There is a different rate of pay and there are different interpretations of the relevant Acts by deputy commissioners throughout Australia.

After two years, the Australian Federal Police still do not have adequate uniforms. If one goes to Adelaide airport one will see three uniforms-for instance, three different hats. There is no insignia which indicates rank; stripes cannot be provided. Many uniforms do not fit and there is no possibility of obtaining more uniforms in the foreseeable future. Australian Capital Territory police get a higher rate of pay than those in the capital cities. Woomera is identified in the policemen's industrial award as an isolated area, and that entitles officers serving there to an extra day's pay. The deputy commissioner in South Australia has taken away that extra day's pay, without an alteration being made to the award, because a sealed road to Woomera has been built. How one can convert an isolated area into an area which is not isolated by building a road is hard to visualise. Whether there is justification that the award rate should not be paid, nevertheless it is in the award and it should be paid; but it is not. This, apparently, was the decision of the Deputy Commissioner of Police in Adelaide. Whilst policemen are now permitted to wear beards, provided they have three weeks growth-that was the stipulation of the Commonwealth Commissioner-the deputy commissioner in South Australia has insisted that they sport a beard only if it is five weeks old. Therefore, those who desire to grow a beard during their holiday period are prevented from doing so.

At Pimba, the station leading to Woomera, there is a guard house which is manned by Commonwealth police. The guard house is built, I think, of timber from islands north of Australia. This timber is so full of wood lice that they fall onto the tables in the canteen where the men dine. They lie so thickly on the floor that they are tramped over every time somebody goes in or out. They have been sprayed a couple of times but it has achieved nothing. There is nothing to indicate that a guard house will be built from some other materials that do not attract these wood lice. Those are the conditions that the police officers are working in at Pimba, with no extra pay and with no extra consideration.

There are complaints amongst the police against their seniors. They are concerned at being called before disciplinary tribunals, having no representation and being compelled to answer questions which may or may not be incriminatory. This legislation does not alter that practice. Whilst the legislation provides that an answer which may incriminate a person cannot be used in a court of law against that person, nevertheless he is forced to answer. His future may depend on the results of that investigation. He may be disciplined, demoted or dismissed. Therefore, he would at all times be in the position of a defendant facing the possibility of some penalty if the investigation finds that his service was not satisfactory. The only proof of a complaint may be the confession of the accused.

I do not wish to be accused of wasting 20 minutes of the time of the Committee-I am not as bad as Senator Evans-but let me say that complaints are made. Corruption may exist in some sections of any large body of people. It happens in all big groups or organisations. The police associations recognise that this corruption exists and are greatly desirous of cleaning it up. In the main the police do a valuable and thankless job. One cannot avoid acknowledging that there is ample evidence of justifiable complaints that nothing eventuated from the previous investigation, the police having kept the inquiry within their own ranks. When I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs there were allegations of serious action, unlawful action, by the police at Skull Creek in northern Western Australia. Sir Charles Court called for a police inquiry, and all the police involved were exonerated. After pressure was placed upon Sir Charles Court a royal commission was established. Sir Charles selected two of the commissioners which suggests that he, having made the decision, knew there was no need for the Commission, which would support the police. The royal commission found that, as had been alleged to me, there had been serious, improper conduct by the police. I think the result of that finding was that one policeman received a promotion and another policeman had his promotion deferred. Nobody cared.

When I became Minister for Aboriginal Affairs I appointed an ex-policeman from Victoria to travel Australia to inquire into accusations of police brutality. His report, although it finally came to me, was never published. As he went from State to State he found that the policemen would not talk to him, as he had no standing. In his finding he could only repeat the accusations that the Aboriginals had made to him about police behaviour. I thought it would do more harm than good in the relationship we were trying to establish with the police to publish the report.

Whilst there is justification for such an inquiry, as is provided for in this Bill, into allegations against police and-I hope the Bill will rectify the present situation-there is also a case for the policemen. They are not all corrupt. They have a difficult job to do. There are occasions when the bad handling of a person by a policeman may be justified. I refer to an incident at the Exchange Hotel at Port Adelaide when a large number of Aboriginal people resented the action of a policeman over three seamen who had assaulted an Aboriginal, and they immediately ganged up. The situation appeared to be very serious.

When I was Minister I received many complaints about police brutality. One such complaint involved an inspector who attended a riotous situation which could have got out of hand at any time. The crowd was told over the loud hailer to disperse and go home, but they did not. The policemen were instructed to break the crowd up into small groups. One cannot break up an angry demonstration by a large number of people into small groups without some innocent people among them perhaps being pushed aside and suffering a mishap.

These matters should all be considered. I hope that the tribunals will be reasonable in their considerations. At least we will not have another situation like the one at Skull Creek when not only the police were exonerated but also after the establishment of the royal commission the Government supported the police and allowed to continue the action which the royal commission found was unlawful and brutal to the Aboriginals at Skull Creek.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats strongly support these Bills and, equally strongly, commend the Government, particularly the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and his Department, for introducing the Bills and for following so closely the Australian Law Reform Commission's recommendations. I have never been a champion of the Australian Federal Police, nor could I be accused of ever having said too many good things about the former Commonwealth Police. In fact I believe quite often I had good reason to be highly critical of them. Indeed, at the time the most effective, insidious, internecine knife job ever done on a group during my time in Parliament was done against the Federal Narcotics Bureau, I had some rather cruel things to say about certain people, certain departments, particularly one former senior officer of the Commonwealth Police. That is past now and, happily, those people who head or are involved in million dollar illegal activities in the narcotics or cannabis trades and in illegal gambling have as their main opponents at a federal level the newly formed Australian Federal Police. I wish the force well in the enormous task that it has in front of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not been accused of praising the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) too often, but I do so now. In the last several months Mr Newman has, to my mind, achieved several significant breakthroughs in this area for which he should be commended. I commend him now. I give notice, without rancour, that the question of the involvement of the Federal Narcotics Bureau and its alleged leaking of documents concerning the Wilsons and the criminal role played by certain members of the Queensland police force in that incident is not over. I know that several members of the Senate-Liberal, Labor and Democrat-have been persuaded that the full truth was not told. It will be told.

Having said that, I am particularly impressed by and pleased with the Attorney-General, his Department and the Government with regard to these Bills. I am very pleased, for example, that they give the Ombudsman the right of separate investigation of complaints against the Federal Police. Without taking away from the Attorney-General or any members of his Department in any way, I believe the Bills are also a tribute to the open-mindedness of Sir Colin Woods, the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, who over the years in former capacities has shown a genuine concern for the public image of the police and has not been prepared, and, quite obviously, is not now prepared to protect them at all costs from the results of their own misbehaviour. The attitude of Sir Colin Woods and the Federal Government with regard to this matter makes the mind boggle when one looks at the similar behaviour of the Queensland police, its police commissioner, its senior officers and the politicians in the Queensland Government who control the Queensland police. Therefore, it gives me great pleasure to commend the Government and Sir Colin Woods on this issue. I will read into the Hansard two quotations which, I think, represent the whole of the spirit of these two Bills. The first quotation comes from the report of the Law Reform Commission on complaints against police. It stated that the purpose of the legislation:

. . . is to establish a system which permits just and thorough investigation of complaints against police, while at the same time upholding morale and discipline in the difficult work police have to do.
Although those are simple words they eloquently describe what the proper situation ought to be. The second quotation is as follows:

The second element is establishment by statute of a special unit of the Police Force titled the 'Internal Investigation Division' with a specialised and independent function of investigating complaints by members of the public against police. Investigation of complaints against police will normally be carried out by this unit . . . a unit of this nature has already been established by the Commissioner by administrative action.

That is another commendable act by Sir Colin Woods and the Attorney-General and his Department. These Bills are the first part of a two-part package recommended to the Parliament by the Law Reform Commission. I hope that the Government will take a similarly enlightened view to the second part, which relates to police investigation procedures. The rumours that I have heard are that the Government has looked at those recommendations favourably and that there is every likelihood that the Commission's recommendations will be accepted. I hope that the rumours are true. I commend the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the Senate and in particular those honourable senators who have participated in this debate for the support they have given to this measure. I listened very carefully to what those honourable senators who have spoken had to say, and I really do not think I have ever had such a short list of notes for a reply. However, I do not propose just to sit down after having thanked the Senate, as I usually do in such cases, because this is a very important measure. There are one or two matters that I would like to add to the debate although I do not propose to detain the Senate for any length of time. First of all, I take up the final point that Senator Chipp made. I think he very properly made reference to the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, Sir Colin Woods. Sir Colin Woods has made an outstanding contribution and impact, and I think he has already overcome many of the matters about which Senator Cavanagh expressed concern.
—He is no quicker than the Government; that's the complaint.

—No doubt he needs some co-operation as well, but I think he has already made a mark and will continue to enhance the morale of the Force greatly. The only subject to which I need reply is the time which this legislation has taken to come into the Senate. The fact is that the processes of consultation and the efforts to meet very firmly held and differing points of view take time. It is all very well to complain, as Senator Evans did, about delays and about the time the Government has taken, but this legislation, and legislation of this kind, is such that it will benefit from consideration, discussion and compromise. The fact that this legislation has been so well received in the Senate is a very good example of the benefits to be derived from that approach, but the price one has to pay is delay. To my mind that is a very small price to pay for the very large benefits that are derived from obtaining a broad consensus.

SPEECH.PARA: There are conflicting interests. As Senator Cavanagh said, one must have regard to the job the police have to do. They are not always in the wrong. These days when one sees on television incidents in which the police are involved a good deal of sympathy is engendered for the person being arrested and perhaps in many cases a lot of unnecessary concern is engendered about the way the police proceed. But the police have a very difficult job to do. They do not always get the sympathy and support they deserve. Therefore, it is always very important, when looking at these sorts of measures, to make sure that the police, and the citizens, are given a fair go.

In the course of the development of this legislation a major report of the Law Reform Commission had to be looked at by an interdepartmental committee and the police had to be heard so that weight could be given to their views. The very important role recommended by the Law Reform Commission for the Commonwealth Ombudsman is now enshrined in this legislation, and the Ombudsman himself has been prepared to make some compromise as well to get a broad consensus. I commend the Ombudsman for the way in which he participated in the discussions in an attempt to obtain the broad consensus which has now resulted in very strong support for this measure. The Administrative Review Council was also asked to comment on it and did so.

Finally, of course, as Senators Missen and Lewis have mentioned, the draft Bill was considered by the Government's law and government committee which also made a valuable contribution. I turn now to what has been called the other part of the package of reform measures in this area, namely, the proposed criminal investigation Bill. With regard to that proposal there are similar divisions of opinion, and questions have to be faced wherever strongly differing views are held. I came to the conclusion that it would not be possible to obtain a consensus in relation to the measure introduced by my predecessor and that it was worth while having another go and starting again, so to speak. That is why I asked the consultant draftsman, the former First Parliamentary Counsel, Mr Comans, whether he would redraft the Bill. Mr Comans, as a consultant, was very busily engaged on behalf of the Government with other major pieces of legislation and it took him some time to do the job that I asked him to do. However, he completed that draft just before he retired from the consultancy that he had been engaged in. I have that draft and I am considering it. There has been a good deal of discussion about the whole matter within another interdepartmental committee, so I hope that in due course we will be able to obtain a measure of consensus. I do not know whether we can get a complete consensus, but we might get a much better measure of consensus about this proposal than we thought was possible. I am not prepared to give any undertakings as to when the Bill will be completed or when it will be brought forward, but I am able to assure the Senate, as I have done on a number of occasions, that I have not by any means shelved the proposal. I am seriously pursuing it and I will continue to do so, but I cannot give any guarantee as to when it will be brought forward. I am aware of the very strong views that are held in relation to some aspects of the matter.

Senator Lewis, although he did not raise this in his speech in the second reading debate, asked me what the additional cost to government of the proposals that are before the Senate will be. It is very difficult to put a figure on it because the members of the Investigation Division are already members of the force. Those who will serve on the tribunal, whether they be judges or magistrates, will be doing so as part of their ordinary judicial work. The figure of about $100,000 per annum is the best estimate that I can make.

I again thank honourable senators for the very great interest they have shown in this measure, for their recognition of its importance and for the most encouraging support which they have all given to it.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter I raised concerned a member of the police force being investigated by the Investigation Division. Clause 7 (5) of the Bill states:

A member of the Investigation Division may, for the purposes of the investigation, direct a member of the Australian Federal Police to furnish information, produce a document or other record or answer a question, being information, a document or record or a question that is relevant to the investigation.

It appears to me that there may be an occasion when the defendant in a case, the person being investigated, is asked to give the only source which can provide information which will prove him guilty of the complaint, and suffer a penalty as a result. Whilst provision is made that his answer cannot be used in a court of law-he can seek privilege on the grounds of incrimination-the investigating officer reports to the Commissioner who takes the appropriate action. I think it is against the system of justice that a man can be penalised for an offence which can be proved only on his own evidence. I would like the Attorney's opinion in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —It happens all the time.
—No, it does not happen all the time. A man is innocent until he is found guilty.
—Yes, but he can be asked questions.

—Yes, but as a result of answering the question he can be penalised. Under most legislation he is not compelled to answer a question that may incriminate him. Under this legislation, when he answers a question from the investigating officer, the effect of his answering that question is to make him subject to discipline-the penalty imposed by the Bill. Therefore he is convicted. He is found guilty by no other evidence and no other proof than his own statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in the Address-in-Reply debate may I first of all congratulate my Tasmanian comrade, Senator Jean Hearn who, in this same debate last week, made her maiden speech and presented her ideas and ideals in a clear, lucid and reasoned way.
