SPEECH.PARA: In supporting the amendment moved by my colleague, Senator Button, I would like to confine my remarks this afternoon to this year, 1981, which is the International Year of Disabled Persons. I think it is the most appropriate time that I can find in the parliamentary timetable to talk about my ideas and the Opposition's view on what should happen this year and some of the trends that should occur in the development of the legislation for disabled persons in the future. IYDP, as it is known, is a potential turning point in the lives of disabled people in this country. It should not be so much a year I believe, as the beginning of an era. Even the cynics are hopeful that this international year will set in motion a process that will continue long after the end of 1981. The Honourable Alf Morris, who introduced the Chronically Sick and Disabled Persons Act in Britain and who was, later, the first Minister in the world who had specific responsibility for the disabled, when introducing the legislation, talked of a society in which there is a genuine respect for the handicapped, where understanding is sincere and unostentatious. If this is the goal in Australia I suggest that we have a long way to go.

The International Year of Disabled Persons is essentially about coming to terms first with the sheer size of the disabled population in this country; nearly 1.5 million Australians are chronically disabled in some way. Secondly, it is about coming to terms with the unpalatable fact that their lives are different, separate and more restricted than those of the rest of the community. Above all it is about coming to terms with the fact that there is no real justification for their relegation to second class citizenship. Having come to terms with all of this, we are, of course, obliged to do something about it. But I believe that it would be a mistake to underestimate the magnitude of this first step.

Rethinking our collective and individual attitudes to disabled people will involve many awkward questions and uncomfortable truths. Above all, it means that we must consult with the disabled in a practical way. If we believe, to quote a United Nations document, that disabled people are 'not a special group with needs different from the rest of the community but ordinary citizens with special difficulties in getting their ordinary needs fulfilled,' how do we explain the way in which we have treated them until now? If I do not want to live in an institution, why should a disabled person have to? If I do not want to travel in a guard's van of a train or a labelled bus, why should a disabled person? If I want to go out for dinner or go to the theatre instead of watching television, does not this also apply to a disabled person? It is not good enough to answer these questions just in terms of disability, although I suggest that is what we have done for decades.

Simply because people are disabled we have made the fact of their disability the focus of all our thinking about them. In community planning this concentration on difference instead of similarity has resulted in separate and special education, separate and special employment, recreation and accommodation-what is being termed 'disabled apartheid'. This is not too strong a description of the situation which exists in many cases. We as a community have got away with it. We have got away with it because we did not want to get too close to a painful subject. We got away with it because many of the caring bodies in the community cared deeply and sincerely but did not question their methods enough. But more than anything, we got away with it because the consumers of all our programs and services-disabled people themselves-were silent and invisible. They were silent because they felt powerless, dependent and totally lacking in choice. They were invisible because the community was so full of barriers, physical and otherwise, that they could not get out and could not be seen.

The International Year of Disabled Persons should, and I believe will, change all this. One thing is certain; there is now a strong and identifi- able consumer movement and things will never be the same again. Disabled people are no longer prepared to be what Rob McNamara, a disabled Victorian, called in the recent Victorian Council of Social Services newsletter, 'the last significantly patronised group of adults living in the community'. They are telling us that our attitudes are wrong and that they want equal rights as citizens. Sympathy, pity, patronage, overprotection and low expectations are out. It is all summed up in the slogan 'your attitude is our greatest handicap'. IYDP is firstly about changing attitudes, about coming to grips with our own and taking a fresh look at disabled people, seeing what they can do and hearing what they want to do. Every time I use the phrase 'disabled people' as a short cut, I am conscious of the enormous diversity of disabilities that are involved. The point must be made that it will be easier to change attitudes to some disabilities than to others.

There is, I believe, a danger that IYDP will lead to great strides in accepting physical disabilities at the expense of mental handicaps and that, even among physically disabled people, those who are articulate, intelligent and attractive, will make progress while those who are not will be bypassed by this year of opportunity. Consider the human interest stories in the media and notice the tendency to highlight accident victims who are leading active lives minus this or that faculty. We hear much less from, or about, people who have been disabled from birth, who are disfigured or misshapen; people who have never developed the physical, mental or social confidence to stand up for themselves. Acceptance of these kinds of disabilities will be the real measure of change in our attitudes. IYDP is secondly about legislative change which can both stimulate and consolidate changes in attitudes. The importance of legislation was explained recently by Suzanne Jobson, a member of the New South Wales Anti-Discrimination Board. She said:

Past experience has shown that progress by minority groups in gaining the right to have their special needs recognised and met is slow and marginal without a legislative base. You cannot rely solely on the goodwill of the community. The very existence of legislation affects people's conduct in that it brings into focus the circumstances surrounding the lives of the people it aims to support, and encourages the community to more closely examine their attitudes and priorities in relation to those people.

Two States of the Commonwealth, South Australia and New South Wales, propose introducing or extending anti-discrimination legislation to include physical handicap. This legislation will outlaw the denial of equal rights and opportunities to physically handicapped people in employment, education and the giving of services and accommodation. Whilst the States are to be congratulated on their initiative, the nature of this legislation is, in itself, a comment on the state of community attitudes. It is essentially protective and designed to advance the situation of disabled people, only so far as equalising their chances alongside the non-disabled. Furthermore, despite its social significance, we should remember that this legislation is no more self-executing than any other. It merely provides a means of redress for those who are aware of its existence and prepared to engage in fighting for their rights. Legislation that takes account of the special needs arising from disability and provides for the development of programs is another matter. It is here that as legislators in the Commonwealth Parliament we have a direct responsibility for the quality of disabled peoples' lives.

This afternoon I want to concentrate on two major issues which should concern the Parliament and which, I have little doubt, would be considered central by the majority of disabled people. The first issue is income maintenance-how society should provide for people who are unable, by reason of their disabilities, to provide adequately for themselves. The second issue concerns the right of disabled people to independence and to management of their own lives. It has been said that the first defence for the disabled citizen against stigma is a guaranteed adequate income as a right. That sounds fine, but if we accept the implications of that statement and look at the Australian scene I suggest that there is little to be proud of. Here, as elsewhere, disability and poverty go hand in hand because of the double penalty of reduced earnings and extra costs.

In the words of Elizabeth Hastings, a disabled Victorian woman, disability is an expensive lifestyle. Yet we have done very little to acknowledge or tackle the financial problems of disabled people. I think one of the reasons for this, apart from the obvious one of concern with cost, is that until recently we have failed to understand that disabled people have special non-optional costs which distinguish their situation from that of other disadvantaged people in the community. Their costs can be broken down into, firstly, capital costs-for example, buying a wheelchair, modifying a house or a car-secondly, running costs to maintain the wheelchair, buying essential supplies for coping with things such as incontinence and for a special diet; and, thirdly, opportunity costs which are virtually impossible to quantify because they are made up of income lost and time given by others in assistance.

In the International Year of Disabled Persons especially it is absolutely vital that non-disabled people should stop and think about the reality of these inescapable expenses confronting disabled people. Valuable stimulus to this exercise has been provided by the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled in a recent discussion paper prepared by Mrs Becky Llewellyn from South Australia. This paper discusses the principles involved in income maintenance and examines seven alternative proposals.

The first proposal is to leave the invalid pension as it is at present. The second proposal is to have the invalid pension without an income test. The third proposal is to have a guaranteed minimum income scheme perhaps of the type suggested by Professor Henderson and the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty, but there are many models around. The fourth proposal is to have a disability pension as a substitute for the present invalid pension, sheltered workshop allowance, repatriation pension, et cetera. The fifth proposal is to have an attendant care allowance for people who need assistance at home or would need such assistance at home if they were to get out of institutions as they frequently want to do. The sixth proposal is to have a mobility allowance for those who have special transport needs-a common enough allowance overseas. The seventh proposal is to have a disability allowance as a supplement to other income which embraces attendant care and mobility as well as other needs.

The Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled paper discusses the advantages and disadvantages of these seven options and concludes that the last, a composite allowance that takes a range of needs such as attendant care and mobility into account, may be the most appropriate. This proposal is attractive because it is directly responsive to the extra costs of disabled living across a family-wide spectrum. However, it ignores, or perhaps it deliberately side-steps, the problem of the inequity which results from basing compensation on the cause rather than the severity of the disability. This may, in fact, be necessary in a conservative society in which any change is painfully difficult.

The fact remains that people with equally severe disablement receive dramatically different compensation depending on whether their disablement was caused in the workshop, on the road, in a theatre of war, in the kitchen or, indeed, in the womb. Accident victims who have access to damages through the legal system do immeasurably better than people disabled from birth or by disease who are dependent on the social security system, although the latter group comprises by far the greatest proportion of the disabled population. The only attempt in this country to devise a just and comprehensive scheme for compensating disabled people was, of course, the Woodhouse National Committee of Inquiry on Compensation and Rehabilitiation in Australia. It recommended replacement of the fault system of compensation with a single, earnings-related, automatic form of compensation for everyone.

Of course, there were problems. The immensity of the administrative restructuring required by this proposal, not to mention the opposition of those who were doing nicely out of the existing structure, was at the heart of the failure to take action on the Woodhouse inquiry. The constitutional difficulties were added to that but could be overcome. We must remember that in New Zealand, in Justice Woodhouse's home country, such a system is in existence and was introduced by a conservative government. We should learn from New Zealand's experience and build on its experience. The increasing costs, for instance, of workers compensation in this country may be the greatest stimulus to this reform being introduced. It is a reform which is believed necessary by many on both sides of politics.

The income maintenance options now before us have an additional urgency in this International Year of Disabled Persons. Whilst they warrant wide and careful discussion I believe this discussion must not be used as a substitute for action. The Economist Intelligence Unit, in its 1978 publication entitled 'Whose Benefit?', stated:

. . . handicapped people should not be the ones called on to 'pay' for their own unavoidable extra needs . . . if they are not given the resources to pay, the cost will nevertheless be extracted from the community in some other way.

It is easy to give moral support to the right of disabled people to live independently and to manage their own lives just as non-disabled people do. It is another matter to give practical support by legislating to provide funds to facilitate that independence. In this country the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act is the corner-stone of the provision of services to handicapped people. It was introduced in 1974 by a Labor government and at that time it was a step forward. It consolidated previous legislation and incorporated many of the recommendations of the 1971 report of the Senate Standing Committee on Health and Welfare.

The Act is now in urgent need of review-a review that was always intended by its authors. The kernel of the criticism of the Act and of the program is that it encourages institutionalisation by funding organisations and physical facilities and discourages independence by making no provision whatever for assistance to self-help groups or individuals. Disabled people benefit under the Act only if they participate in programs run by organisations. If they want to go it alone, good luck to them, but there is no official assistance in any form. If we had had a proper consultation process in 1974 it may not have happened. I believe the main problem was that attitudes were different then. Attitudes have changed and will change now. A recent Victorian Council of Social Service draft report based on the views of disabled people, speaking of the Act, states:

It enshrines a vision that is still caught in the charity mentality-a board of benefactors with the assistance of paid workers providing for and caring for disabled people in a specialised environment.

This is merely one more addition to the existing pile of informed and often outspoken criticism. The National Advisory Council for the Handicapped undertook a comprehensive review of funding priorities and, in its third report in 1979, concluded:

The fundamental concern . . . is that the Handicapped Persons' Welfare Program has, to date, given undue emphasis to the funding of physical facilities rather than the provision of services responsive to the variety of needs of handicapped people.
The South Australian Committee on Rights of Persons with Handicaps, chaired by Mr Justice Bright, noted:

It is perhaps the Commonwealth Handicapped Person's Assistance Act that stands most formidably in the way of a move towards funding that encourages normalisation . . . only organisations that provide services on their premises are eligible . . . a self-help group which pools its resources and distributes profits is ineligible. An organisation which wishes to help handicapped persons in their own homes would be ineligible.

In 1980 the Tasmanian Board of Inquiry into the Needs of the Handicapped called for a review as a matter of urgency. I believe that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and the Government need no more evidence of the shortcomings of this Act than exists in this and other reports from disabled persons in the community. I believe that the Government should be prepared to honour the observance of IYDP by announcing the revision of the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act to incorporate assistance for disabled individuals and self-help groups. We can all help by informed debate and by informing ourselves.

Finally, I believe that even our colleagues in the Press can help. I believe that they should make a more enduring contribution to IYDP than through a series of news stories and personal profiles. There is an example where they can help. In the United Kingdom the readers service of a mass circulation newspaper, the People, devised a form in plain English to supplement a complicated application for a certain official allowance. This form is now widely used and has had a direct bearing on the success rate for application and the ease of application by those who need this benefit. Is there any reason why the Australian Press cannot match this? It is often accused of inadequately informing the population and of trivialising and sensationalising issues. No paper has been accused of this more than the People in the United Kingdom. Could the Press, in this case, not make a positive contribution to the welfare of this large group of disadvantaged citizens?

I began my speech by referring to the IYDP as a potential turning point in the lives of disabled people, and that is exactly what it will remain-a potential turning point-unless the community as a whole gets down to the business of turning rhetoric into reality. Disabled people are already well away doing their utmost to capitalise on this once in a lifetime opportunity and to influence, as much as possible, what is supposed to be their year. It is up to non-disabled people, sometimes called the temporarily able bodied people, to show that disability does not have to hit them personally before they are prepared to match their verbal compassion with action. Action is needed now and now that we have come so far in developing awareness and, I consider, in developing the political will, I think the International Year of Disabled Persons is surely the most appropriate time to make a start in developing that action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking today to the Governor-General's Speech I should like to refer to the section in His Excellency's Speech dealing with unemployment and youth. The Governor-General said:

SPEECH.PARA: During the last five years over half a million Australians have received specific help through my Government's manpower and training programs. Nearly another quarter million will receive assistance during this year.

My Government has a clear and firm commitment to youth, exemplified by its announcement of new initiatives, including the introduction of a new allowance to encourage young unemployed persons to take advantage of training opportunities, the expansion of its work experience programs and the provision of improved counselling services.
All of these initiatives will be in place by February next year.
During 1981 my Government will take action to place increased emphasis on employment and training schemes.

A framework is being established within which the Government's training programs will provide a wide range of incentives and allowances to increase the supply of skills required for economic development, and to assist the unemployed, particularly the young and disadvantaged, to obtain employment.

Last year I spoke mainly on adult training and the limitations of intake due to the age limit. I also discussed the need for a continuous improvement of the knowledge and skills of the labour force due to the fast changes and new technological developments. I also mentioned the 1974 Australian Committee on Technical and Further Education-the so called Kangan Committee-and its criticism of the present apprenticeship courses. One of the problems highlighted in the report was the length of training. Today I would like to deal with that particular question and the way other industrial nations try to improve and facilitate training of young men and women.

The Australian apprenticeship system derives from that of the United Kingdom but other English speaking countries, for example the United States and Canada, do not have a strongly developed apprenticeship system as such. It is a different matter in Europe where most of the Scandinavian countries, Germany, Austria and Switzerland, have strongly developed apprenticeship systems but these frequently cover occupations which are not apprenticeable in Australia. For instance, in Germany young persons who are entering an occupation such as retailing, banking and insurance and clerical and service occupations are generally required to undertake an apprenticeship before becoming established in those industries. This is a different system from what we have in our country.

Broadly, overseas trends are toward incorporating greater flexibility in the provision of training arrangements. This may be seen in the following ways: Most countries either have or are in the process of abolishing formal restrictions on age of entry into apprenticeships and do not specify when apprenticeships must be completed, a fact which I believe is of very important consequence to our system. Nevertheless, in most of them apprenticeships begin at 15 or 16 years of age and end in the latter teenage years. Few young people over 20 enter apprenticeships except in Canada and the United States. In most countries adult workers who were trained through apprenticeship and desire or need to bring their skills up to date are given such courses outside apprenticeship. Again, I believe that this is not happening in Australia or if it is, it is restricted to very few trades.

Although age restrictions have been set aside on occasions when labour market shortages appeared to warrant training of older entrants as apprentices, the major thrust in adult training and retraining has occurred outside the apprenticeship system. I believe that when soldiers returned after the war they were able to train and become tradesmen in a very short period. I believe that provisions then were quite flexible and made it possible for adult men and women to become tradesmen without going through four or five years of formal apprenticeship.

The duration of apprenticeship is another question. There are different durations throughout the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, but the shortening of the training period has been opposed on two points. Firstly, the employers feel they would not recover their training costs in a shorter period and, secondly, the trade unions argue that training would be inadequate and that wage structures for apprentices would be upset. Let us look again at what happened after the war. Why was it possible to train people after the war when we needed tradesmen? Why is it not possible to do so today when we need tradesmen and skilled people in our industries? One of the objectives of shortening the period of apprenticeship is to attract young people who have resisted the longer training period because of consequent delay in achieving full pay as skilled workers.

There are questions in most countries about co-ordination of practical work and theoretical exercises. Particular problems have arisen in Germany where responsibility for training is on a federal level while the States control education. That division hampers co-ordination in spite of the efforts of Federal-State commissions. The apprenticeship system in Britain relates more directly to specific employment possibilities than does the system in Germany. In Germany where offers of employers are not planned and do not attempt to correspond to the needs of the labour market, a recent study found marked discrepancies between the occupational distribution of apprenticeship occupations. Furthermore, in Germany research has been most explicit in revealing the adverse effects on the costs and convenience of offering training when enterprises adopt more automated techniques and sometimes need fewer skilled workers. We in this country are approaching that situation as fast as all other developed industrial countries.

If we look to Austria we find that adults over 21 years of age who have acquired skills through work experience and education may take the final apprenticeship examination without going through apprenticeship. On the other hand, in New Zealand the problems are identical to our own. Although the New Zealand Act provides for adult apprenticeships the system is very youth orientated and few people over the age of 20 years enter apprenticeship contracts. Hong Kong has an ordinance which does not prevent employers from taking on apprentices over the age of 19 or apprentices in non-designated trades.

If we look at Japan we find that the system there is quite opposite to our own which I believe has become old fashioned because it was modelled on the trades and skills of 50 or 100 years ago. It is interesting to note that in Japan there is no period of formal training at the conclusion of which a person is regarded as a skilled tradesman. Persons may obtain training in vocational schools, public vocational training centres, company training centres, through on-the-job experience or a combination of these methods. A national trade skill test system provides the means by which persons trained by these various means can be assessed against a common standard and obtain formal certification of skilled status. In Japan there is also occupational capacity redevelopment training or job conversion training. Such a course, which is 6 months full time or one year part time, is designed to teach new basic skills to persons seeking to change their employment and to unemployed persons seeking employment. I feel that the Japanese system is the one which would be most suitable for our conditions and the demand for trade skills in our present boom.

In some trades in the Republic of Korea the upper age limit for an apprentice may be as high as 27 years. The Koreans have upgrading training courses designed to assist employed adult workers acquire higher skills. They have further refresher training courses designed to retrain workers by developing supplementary skills, and there is the possibility of undertaking change-of-trade courses designed to teach workers new skills necessary for taking on new jobs. Again, I feel that that kind of provision would be welcome in our economy at this stage of our development. It is interesting to note that in France teachers are divided on the issue of apprenticeships. For instance, those teachers allied to the Federation d'Education Nationale have called for the abolition of such schemes and most probably would favour something similar to what Japan has.

What is happening in Australia? At a conservative estimate Australia will need an additional 69,000 skilled people such as engineers, boiler makers, motor mechanics, tool makers, coppersmiths, sheet metal workers, fitters, instrument makers and so on. These skilled people will be required up to 1983. In the interim our present old fashioned apprenticeship system will have produced only about 47,000 additional skilled workers. Therefore, there will be a gap of around 20,000 workers. It is interesting also that the traditional training program provides 83 per cent of our tradesmen and only 2 per cent of the total requirement comes from migration and from Australian workers who have earned the title of tradesmen after six years' practical work. The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner) issued statistics which show that in 1980 46,152 young Australians took on apprenticeships; this figure is the highest since 1969-70. Mr Viner also said that there are now 136,628 apprentices in training, which is also a record. The number of newly indentured apprentices reached a record of 18,244 in New South Wales, showed a substantial growth in Queensland and a healthy growth in Victoria and Tasmania. It is interesting to note that if we add the figures relating to new indentures registered in the last three years the total number surpasses by 3.1 per cent the indentures taken out in the 1972-75 period.

I mention these facts for only one reason. Recently I read an article by the shadow spokesman on industrial relations in which he said that the socialists have a perfect plan to increase the training of young Australians. But in looking at the facts and figures for what happened under the socialist regime of 1972-75 we find that the Liberal Government has surpassed in the last three years the number of apprenticeships taken up under the Labor Government. For instance, in the electrical trades an increase of 9.1 per cent in the number of new indentures has been registered in the last three calendar years in comparison with those registered in the three years 1972-75. The total figure for all trades shows an increase of 18.6 per cent, which is a record figure for new indentures registered. There has also been a tremendous increase in the number of completed apprenticeships. During the period of the Whitlam Government there were 73,046 apprenticeship completions whilst during the last three years of the Fraser Government there have been 94,338.

There have been some encouraging developments in adult training in Australia. In Western Australia co-operation between the trade unions, employers and government authorities has enabled some redundant workers to be retrained in trades such as bricklaying and furnishings. This example was quoted by the Cochrane Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Training as evidence for its argument that controlled access to properly regulated training courses administered under a tripartite authority was preferable to the practice of informal upgrading on the job. Limitations on training opportunities for semi-skilled workers, the Committee argued, presented a major obstacle to improving the standards of tradesmen in general. The Committee warned against the development of inflexible training programs for adults, however, which are sometimes associated with apprenticeship education. The Kangan Committee, which sat a few years ago, urged as follows:

The acceptance of a mixed system in which the employer would transfer a greater part of his apprenticeship contract to the technical education authorities. If this approach was adopted it could mean a shift towards the European model of apprenticeship whereby there is an introductory period of full-time training off the job, to teach trainees the basic elements of their trade and proper working methods followed by a period of training and experience in industry.

The Kangan Committee also recommended that recurrent education be available to all individuals who wished to add to their knowledge and skills in order to upgrade their earlier education or change their occupation. I would say that in today's changing technology it is most important that a person who has been trained in one trade and one skill should be able to be retrained and learn a new trade even when he is 30 or 35 years of age and not precluded, as is the situation at the moment, because he is older than 16 or 17 years. If this system were adopted it would open the way for adults to enter not only the skilled trades but also other occupations. I feel that education in our system has to be changed in order to provide the situation in which young persons would be more inclined to take up skills and trades and not to have an academic goal as the be-all and end-all of their aims. I would like to quote from a newspaper article in which the views of the President of the Institute of Engineers, and Dean of the Engineering Faculty at Monash University, Professor Lance Endersby, were put forward. The article stated:
He thinks the problem stems from the Australian education system and that it can be rectified-for the long term-in the education process.
The Schools Commission report which dealt with the schooling of 15 and 16-year-olds made a recommendation which was set out in a newspaper article. The article stated:

'Schools underplay the role of work as an aspect of life, and ignore the way it might be made part of the central thrust of the curriculum. And yet it is essential for physical survival. Schools must help students to come to terms with work as a central element of society'.
The commission stressed that it was not saying it was the task of schools to teach specific work skills.
'But rather (it is their task) to foster a general understanding of work in ways which will help students cope with the myriad problems of an unforseeable future'.

Therefore I feel that education could play a tremendous part in giving young people the opportunity to enter the trades and to become skilled tradesmen instead of going on to some course at university which is completely unsuitable for our conditions today. The Minister for Education (Mr Fife), in answer to a question upon notice, stated:

On the question of consultation between industry and schools regarding academic requirements for apprenticeship, this is essentially a matter for the education systems and schools in the States to take up. The basic academic requirements for entry to apprenticeship in terms of attainment in school courses are laid down by apprenticeship authorities in each State and territory and these requirements would generally be well known to counsellors advising students who are seeking apprenticeships.
Further, regarding the matter of educational problems, I would like to quote the following:

The system of institutional education at the secondary level still furnishes an academic education largely directed at providing matriculation candidates for the universities. The need to prepare youth for careers at levels below those served by universities and colleges of Advanced Education constitutes a significant gap in the structure of Australian education and training.

This quotation dealt with education and how education could help young people to become more involved in apprenticeships and skilled tradesmen's professions. Let us look at what is happening and what the Government has done to try to rectify a bad system, an old system, which exists in our country. A conference was held between Commonwealth and State Ministers for labour which endorsed a plan of action which would improve the apprenticeship system, making it more flexible and adaptable to the needs of Australia in the 1980s. The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, Mr Viner, in his article regarding the conference stated:
That report is being followed up by me to ensure the implementation of its recommendations as quickly as possible.
These include:
Upgrading suitable semi-skilled workers in shorter periods than the normal apprenticeship indentures.
Expansion and introduction of pre-apprenticeship courses leading to trade occupations.
Encouragement of shorter indentures for people with appropriate education qualifications and experience.
Examination of awards to determine areas where greater flexibility should be introduced into trade training.
Support of group apprenticeship arrangements with industry associations.
Identification of spare training capacity in Government departments and instrumentalities for use in training workers in key occupations.

It is interesting to note that the South Australian Government has already changed some laws in regard to trades training. The South Australian Government introduced a new Bill to repeal the Apprentices Act and to establish an industrial and commercial training commission designed to oversee all aspects of training and to develop policies to meet demands for skilled workers. An article from the Australian of 13 February 1981 states:

One of the purposes of this bill is to co-ordinate the administration of all areas of commercial and industrial training, including apprenticeships, into an intergrated whole and to ensure that training opportunities will be available to men and women of all ages.

The fact is that there are moves underway by the Fraser Government to improve and to facilitate the apprenticeship system as such. I now refer to different ideas and thoughts which were expressed in regard to this system of apprentices. An article in the Australian states:
Australia's antique apprenticeship machinery needs an overhaul and quickly . . . it is virtually obsolete.
Further, it states:
There has been substantial growth in full-time vocational training outside the apprenticeship system in State technical and further education colleges.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the date of that paper, Senator?

—It is 15 September 1980. Ten years ago it was impossible to find enough apprentices to fill the vacancies. Today the situation has changed dramatically. By 1978 there were 36 apprentices for every registered unfilled vacancy. The 1980 ratio eased somewhat to 19 for every job. The responsibility for the administration of apprenticeships lies with individual State and Territory governments resulting, of course, in the usual patchwork quilt of different laws, different standards and different rates. It is therefore necessary that something be done on a nation- wide basis and that action be taken by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs calling a conference of all State labour Ministers. The achieving of a standard or a united approach to the apprenticeship system is of great value. I hope that it is only the first step which will help to achieve something which is much more adaptable and much more attuned to this age and not to an age which has long passed. Co-ordinated national programs must be introduced to encourage further apprenticeship and manpower development and to improve education and training facilities. Finally, Mr Acting Deputy President, I congratulate the Government on a splendid program, as outlined by His Excellency the Governor-General. I commend the Speech and oppose the amendment proposed by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's Speech and an amendment which has been moved by Senator Button, the Leader of the Opposition. The amendment moved by Senator Button states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government-
(1) Has failed to adequately respond to:
(a) record unemployment;
Of course, every time we look at the figures, we know, despite what Senator Lajovic has said, that unemployment is increasing. The amendment reads further:
(b) a high and worsening level of inflation;

The level of inflation has not been reduced to 5 per cent, as was promised by the Government when first elected. If one looks at the Budget figures one will see that it is about 11 per cent at this stage-more than double what the Government said it would be. That is another broken promise. The amendment reads further:
(c) reduced and falling family living standards;
That is borne out by the cost of living. I will refer to that matter later, particularly in regard to my own State of South Australia. The amendment reads further:
. . . and
(d) the highest taxation burden in the nation's history.
(2) Allows unsatisfactory administration of foreign investment guidelines which permit an uncritical and open-door policy to the takeover of Australian industry and resources to continue; and

(3) Makes no long-term provision for assistance to manufacturing industry and farming industries, which are likely to be severely disadvantaged as a result of successive exchange rate revaluations and substantially increased imports in the context of resources development.

Senator Lajovic, in his speech, and Government speakers before, made very little attempt to try to rebut the words of that amendment. They resorted to statistics, some of which caught out Senator Lajovic when he was referring to the apprenticeship training scheme. Near the end of his speech he quoted an article from the Australian of 15 September 1980. He stated that apprenticeship needs a massive overhaul. He spent about 10 minutes or more telling us what the Government has done during its term of office to provide a better apprenticeship training scheme in Australia. The Government having been in office for nearly five years, Senator Lajovic tried to bolster his argument and quoted an article from the Australian which states that apprenticeship matters need a massive overhaul. Of course, he is defeating his own argument by saying that, and the figures prove it.

He talked about South Australia, too, and about some apprenticeship scheme which the Tonkin Government has introduced or proposes to introduce. It is beyond my comprehension to know how Senator Lajovic would be fully informed on what the Tonkin Government is doing, particularly in regard to apprenticeship schemes. He may not be fully informed of what it is doing in regard to other measures. I invite Senator Lajovic to remain in the chamber while I tell him, during the course of my speech, what the Tonkin Government has done to South Australia during the 18 months that it has been in office. It has done a terrible thing to the State. I now refer back to the apprenticeship training scheme, in case Senator Lajovic leaves the chamber and does not want to learn something about the tragedy of South Australia. I shall quote from a list for apprenticeships full time training in South Australia. This was brought to my attention by a person who has conducted a panel beating business in my home town of Murray Bridge for as long as I have been there, and that is over 30 years. Just recently he employed two apprentice panel beaters. He applied, under the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training Scheme, for a rebate for the employment of these apprentices.

This scheme has been greatly publicised over the length and breadth of Australia. Senator Lajovic has repeated today what the Federal Government is doing to encourage employers to take on apprentices. When this man applied for the rebate to assist him in the employment of these two apprentices in his small business he could not get a cent. I went to the Commonwealth Employment Service office to get a full list of all the occcupations for which eligibility under the CRAFT $1,000 rebate scheme may be established in South Australia. It is a massive list which deals particularly with the motor industry. It lists motor fitter, motor cycle maintenance, motor mechanic, motor mechanics-diesels, and all these types of things, but nothing is mentioned regarding an employer who runs a panel beating business.

With the massive increase in the number of motor cars on the roads-although the number is rapidly declining in South Australia because of the new registration procedures enforced by the Tonkin Government, about which I will speak later-and with the very poor drivers we have and the massive increase in the accident rate, I should think that the first thing the Government should do is to look at giving some assistance to people who conduct panel beating businesses so that they can train apprentices. But no, it has overlooked that. Yet it gives money to employers in other areas which, in my view, although they may be important in the Government's view, are not as important as panel beating. It gives money to employers to train locksmiths, brass finishers, coppersmiths, electroplaters, hand engravers and such occupations which a country, if it is in dire straits, does not need, but it needs people who are trained to service the motor industry in all spheres. This Government is not prepared to do anything to help such people, despite the fact that it has put out all these glossy brochures to fool the employers about the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training Scheme stating: '$1,000 now prevents skilled shortages later'.

This is what Senator Lajovic has been talking about. He says that the apprenticeship training scheme, under his Government, is in a mess. This Government has been in office for five years. The scheme needs a massive overhaul because the Government has done nothing about it since it came into office. I refer also to job training. The Government says to employers: 'You send employees to trade school and we will help with the Bill'. Is it helping the man about whom I have spoken? He would not be the only one in that position. I know about him only because he lives at Murray Bridge and runs his business there. He has run a successful business for over 30 years that I know of and has trained some very good people, but because of the recession some years ago he did not take on apprentices. Now, the people he has trained, the skilled people in his workshop, will reach retiring age in a few years. He wants to train young lads to take their places, but he cannot get a cent from the Government. The Government's policy is to let these lads go on the dole. For how long will they be on the dole before they soak up $1,000 of taxpayers' money? The Government has arranged nothing. This happened only a couple of weeks ago. The Government cannot be a bit concerned. Otherwise, why did this Australian, Mr Murdoch, who supports the Government in every election, take the Government to task? He wrote an article, from which the honourable senator quoted, about the apprenticeship training scheme's needing a massive overhaul. The Government has been criticised by its own supporters.
I wish to refer also to some comments made by Senator Teague. He spoke very gloatingly of the results in the recent by-elections. Anyone would have thought--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you speaking to the amendment, Senator?

—I think the amendment is very far reaching. I expect that I can speak about that matter, Mr Deputy President, but if you rule against me, I guess I will have to take cognisance of your ruling. I shall quote from Hansard the remarks made by Senator Teague when he spoke about some of the matters which concerned him. He stated that the Government was very successful in the recent by-elections and gave some of the figures. I think we all know the reason for the low turnout of voters. Two of the by-elections were for blue ribbon Liberal seats. A similar result would have pertained had there been a by-election in Port Adelaide, Banks, Sydney or any such electorate. There would have been a very poor turnout of Liberal voters because they knew that they had no chance and they would not have bothered to vote. We might see a difference if our case in the High Court to contest the electorates of Kingston, Lowe and another in in Western Australia, where the result was much closer, is successful. Then Senator Teague might have a different story altogether to tell. We cannot take much notice of what Senator Teague says in this place. I am reminded of his maiden speech when, in speaking about the brandy excise, he said that he would not be a credible Liberal if he supported what the Government was doing. Yet when it came to the crucial issue what did he do? He voted against the amendment that I moved on behalf of the Opposition to delete certain clauses from the excise Bill so that the brandy excise would remain at the same level.
—Hansard would prove that.

—That is in the Hansard. As a consequence there has been a massive increase in unemployment in the Riverland area in South Australia because the distilleries are not buying brandy grapes. It has had a repercussion through the Riverland in South Australia. The living standards of the families of many of the small grape growers has been reduced and is falling. That is referred to in part of the Opposition's amendment. These are some of the things that come home to roost when a senator speaks in this place about his principles and his standards. When he is put to the test he goes to water.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague also stated that he did not agree with his colleagues about their move to have no senators in the ministry. This is another illustration of the split in the Government parties that is becoming more evident every day. I remind the Senate that on 22 March 1979 Senator Rae gave notice of a motion-I will not read all of it because it is in the Notice Paper for everybody to see-that senators should no longer hold office as Ministers of State. We read in the speech of the honourable member for Wilmot (Mr Burr) in a debate on the same matter in the other House the other day that he supports Senator Rae, but he certainly does not support Senator Teague.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were sinister implications in what he said.

—There were. I will refer to some of them. Senators often speak in this place about the freedom in their party. They say that they do not have to abide by party policy, that they are free agents and that they can vote as they like on all issues. They criticise members of the Labor Party because we are bound by our policy, but they do not seem to understand that the policy of the Labor Party is determined by the rank and file of the party through its branches, its states councils, its state conventions and its federal conference. We all agree that once a majority vote is taken we will abide by the policy. That is the policy on which we go to the electors and if we are elected we are duty bound to support that policy. I do not think anybody in the Labor Party wants to depart from the policy on which we are elected. We do not make any claims to be free agents, but honourable senators on the other side continually claim how free they are to vote as they wish. Of course, that claim is completely false. I think Max Burr, the honourable member for Wilmot, exploded that myth in the other House. I shall remind honourable senators about that matter later in my speech. I return to what Senator Teague had to say in his speech. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that had we been better at campaigning our policy strengths we would have been better supported and perhaps my colleagues would not have lost their seats.

That is an admittance that even though a filthy campaign was conducted in South Australia, and no doubt in the other States, it did not benefit the Government. He said that the Government ought to be better at campaigning. I hope that he meant by that statement that the Liberal Party in the future will conduct a cleaner and more honest campaign and will not get no-hopers to sign election advertisements depicting all sorts of terrible things that would happen to the electorate at large if the Labor Party were elected to government, as did Mr Buick from Kangaroo Island. He is a non-entity, but he seems to have any amount of money to pay for massive advertisements. People in Kalgoorlie and all over Australia were authorising advertisements on behalf of the Liberal Party, frightening people away from the Labor Party. Senator Teague went on:
Another contributing factor was the very real success of the Tonkin Liberal Government in its first 12 months in office.

I do not know in which way he meant that that was a contributing factor. Perhaps he meant that it contributed to the fact that the Labor Party held all its seats in South Australia. We did not win any and we did not lose any. Neither did the Liberal Party, but one seat is in very grave doubt. That case is now before the courts for a decision. There may even be a by-election for that seat. I shall supply quite extensive quotations about the Tonkin Liberal Government later on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you will confine those remarks to the amendment.

—Yes, I will, Mr Deputy President. The amendment speaks about the high and worsening level of inflation, the record unemployment and the reduced and falling family living standards. All those things apply in my State of South Australia, under the Tonkin Liberal Government. I will tell the Senate all about them after 8 o'clock. I am sure that you will be very interested to hear about them.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague, further on in his speech, said:

But in South Australia there was a swing to the Government and Steele Hall's result in Boothby is, I believe, further confirmation of support for him as a candidate, for the Liberal Party in South Australia and for the Fraser Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I invite honourable senators opposite to turn back the Hansard record and to see what Senator Young, in particular, Senator Withers and Senator Jessop said on some occasions about former Senator Steele Hall and what Steele Hall said about the Liberal Party as a whole and about Senator Withers. It is all recorded in Hansard. If people care to read a speech I made here on one occasion they will find that I tabulated it all in that one speech. They do not have to turn back all the Hansard records to find a complete reference to that division between them. We have now heard Senator Teague say what a great bloke Steele Hall is and that he is welcome back into the party. I think the party members might rue the day they let him back, as they did in South Australia. That was one of the disappointments for Mr Fraser after the pre-selections. Another was the fact that his pea did not get up in the preselection for the seat of Curtin in Western Australia. He might rue the day that those things happened.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague went on to talk about an increase in the Liberal-National Country Party Ministry and said that in the not too distant future one-third of the Ministry could be members of this chamber. I do not think we will ever see that happen because if Senator's Rae's motion is ever brought back on for debate and is supported we will not see any Ministers here at all. That will also happen if Mr Max Burr has his way. In view of what Senator Teague said, it is very revealing to look at what was said in the other place by Mr Burr, the honorable member for Wilmot. I quote from page 158 of the House of Representatives Hansard for 25 February 1981 where Mr Burr is reported to have said:
Parliament is dominated by the all pervading party political interests and by the selfish ambition to have and to exercise power.

That is what we on this side of the Senate have always said. It was borne out by the actions taken by present Government members when they were in Opposition in 1974-75. All they thought about was power, not the good of the country or the welfare of the people-just power. Now we find that members of their own parties in the other place are actually criticising the Fraser Government for what it has done. Mr Burr continued:
I have suggested that all Ministers be appointed from the House of Representatives.

That is completely contrary to what Senator Teague said. It would be very interesting to be a fly on the wall in the Government's party rooms and to listen to some of the arguments members must have on these issues, now that they publicly vent their spleens on their colleagues. Mr Burr went on:

It seems incongruous that the Senate is expected to be a House of review while at the same time some of its members form part of the Executive Government. In reality, the Senate is not a proper House of review but rather an extension of the House of government and equally dominated by party allegiances. Surely the Senate could better fill its review role if none of its members were Ministers and there was no ambition on the part of others to become Ministers.

I have suggested also that there should be a one-line appropriation in the annual Budget for Parliament and that its expenditure should be controlled by the Presiding Officers. Parliament cannot properly scrutinise the Executive while the funding of parliamentary operations is controlled by the Executive.

How true that is. I will refer, firstly, to those last remarks. We have advocated in this place that there should be a one-line appropriation for the Parliament. There are many reasons for that; they are to be found in the reports of the Estimates committees of this Parliament. I hope that before I leave this place I will see the day when there is a one-line appropriation so that the Parliament can control its own destiny and run its own affairs, and not have severe monetary and staff ceiling restrictions placed on it so that members are unable to get sufficient staff to carry out their duties.

The matter with which I am mostly concerned is this: I have been ridiculed by honourable senators opposite for saying here on many occasions that this is not a House of review when the Liberal Party is in Government. Of course it is not. When it has the numbers here it is a rubber stamp. It was a House of frustration when we were in government and the Liberal Party had the numbers here. It would not let us govern. Yet we heard Senator Lajovic, back on his hobby horse, trying to make excuses. He is a good pupil of Senator Carrick who, every time he is in trouble, blames all the ills of the country on the Whitlam Government. It is now five years since the Whitlam Government went out of office and it is taking this Government a jolly long time to rectify those ills, if in fact they were ills. I have yet to be convinced that we created any ills. What we did was to create better living standards for everybody who needed help. We were not neglecting the underprivileged and handing out massive amounts of support for the wealthy.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.
General Business taking precedence of Government Business at 8 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINES AND ISLANDERS (ADMISSIBILITY OF CONFESSIONS) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Bonner) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to the Admissibility of Confessions made by Aborigines and Islanders and to related Matters.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Honourable senators will recall that on 15 September 1976, and 26 October 1978, I introduced this Bill into this chamber and that, as a result of the Parliament's being prorogued, the Bills lapsed. Now I again present it in its original form without any amendment. It is sufficient to say that since those dates a lot of water has passed under the bridge and, to the shame of this nation, a lot more Aborigines and Islanders have gone to prison. Their only crime, in the majority of cases, is ignorance-ignorance of a judicial system which they do not understand. It is a judicial system which is based entirely on European values, customs and culture; and one which is heavily weighted against my people and my Islander brothers and sisters. Therefore, it is my belief, shared by countless thousands of caring white Australians, that this present imbalance within our society must not be permitted to continue. It must be excised, like some deadly cancer that is sapping the very life blood of my people.

For the many years that I have been privileged to sit in this chamber, I have listened attentively, if somewhat cynically, to the many debates concerning my race. This cynicism has of late, I believe, been reinforced by events with which all honourable senators should be familiar and concerned. However, I now call upon honourable senators to do some soul searching, to exercise their minds, to put their fine words into some definite, direct action. This chamber has been deluged by noble words and sentiments which have hung heavily on my ears and then dissipated and blown away on the winds of indifference. Today I am issuing a challenge to all senators to put these thoughts and expressions of concern for the Aboriginal and Island people into positive and effective action.

Do we, as senators, have the necessary intestinal fortitude to initiate innovative and far reaching legislation, or are we to give truth to the fallacy that we are a chamber of stoic old men and women, deaf to the voice of the people, a mere rubber stamp of that other place? I look around and see youth and vitality on both sides of the chamber. I see the wisdom of years, and I pray to God that I also see men and women of principle; men and women of vision, men and women who are not the mere minions of government and bureaucracy, but men and women who are now prepared to stand up and be counted, and are in tune with the song of freedom that is presently resounding throughout this nation. I trust that I have gained the Senate's attention, rattled a few skeletons in the closet and extracted some emotion from honourable senators. I do not care whether it be sympathy, resentment, or criticism, as long as it is some emotive force. For I believe that for far too long the welfare of my people has been treated with mere apathy within this chamber.

Not long ago in this chamber, I echoed the plaintive plea of that great Aborigine and Australian, Albert Namatjira. They were words which embodied, I believe, his utter despair and disillusionment with the dominant white society and its judicial system. It was a cry which even today is applicable to my people and one which demands to be answered in this very chamber today. Those prophetic words were not delivered from the pulpit, or from any public forum, but from the very source itself-the steps of a white man's much vaunted hall of justice, after Namatjira had felt the cruel barbs of his white brother's brand of justice. Sadly, the position remains unchanged in this so-called enlightened era of so-called reform. The indigene still finds himself today an outcast and pariah in his own land, a land which was given him by Almighty God at Dreamtime, which is creation.

I am aware that perhaps I have traversed this ground before, and although it needs to be reiterated time and time again, perhaps I can condense this with the words of two white scholars to whom my race will be eternally grateful. Firstly, I quote C. D. Rowley's The Destruction of Aboriginal Society from the Australian National University Press 1970. At page 23 these words appear:

What were left were not conquered tribes, but dispirited remnants lacking in the kind of leadership with which an administration might negotiate. Lacking even a place of their own, which from the European point of view, was an axiomatic basis for any kind of civilised or ordered life.
Secondly, I quote Emeritus Professor W. E. H. Stanner's After the Dreaming from the 1968 Boyer Lectures. These words appear at page 46:

In a hundred patterns they drifted into a vicious circle of poverty, dependence and acceptance of paternalism. Every act of paternalism deepened the poverty into pauperism and the dependence into inertia. The situation was self-perpetuating and self-reinforcing.

If honourable senators choose to ignore this lone Aborigine's words, dare they cast aside the words of these two men of learning? To further reinforce the need for the provisions of this Bill, I quote directly from Aborigines, A Statement of Concern prepared by the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace, for the Catholic Bishops of Australia. I quote from page 14:

The Law and the Police. Not only does our legal system reflect values and priorities alien to Aboriginal culture, but it has by and large sanctioned the dispossessions of Aboriginal people of their land and violence that accompanied it. Many laws discriminated against them. Indeed, the Australian Government was for a time unable to ratify the 'International Convention on the elimination of All Forms of Discrimination' of the United Nations because of the Queensland Aborigines' and Torres Strait Islanders' Acts.

The law has offered little protection to Aborigines. Rarely have they sought justice through civil courts. In the criminal courts, they have been disadvantaged at every stage of the proceedings-the chances of being arrested, the nature of charges, the granting and the level of bail, having legal representation in court, the chances of conviction and the severity of sentence.
The end result is that Senator Bonner has been able to claim that Aborigines are the most imprisoned people in the world.

My claim, which is mentioned in the report, is still as valid today as it was then or when I first introduced the Bill. I would like to record some further figures which are now available. In 1974 Aborigines comprised between 6 per cent and 9 per cent of the prison population in New South Wales. Their rate of imprisonment was at least 17 times that of non-Aborigines. Each year from 1973 to 1975 magistrates courts in Western Australia sentenced more Aborigines than non-Aborigines to imprisonment. Aborigines comprise 2.1 per cent of the population of that State. In July 1972 Aborigines made up 15.3 per cent of the total daily average prison population in South Australia and 51.33 per cent of the female prison population. Only 0.75 per cent of the State's population are Aborigine.

To give some indication of the validity of the consensus of the objections, with the concurrence of honourable senators I incorporate in Hansard a letter to the Right Honourable Malcolm Fraser, Prime Minister, from the Queensland Police Union of Employees.
The letter read as follows-
269 Main Street, Kangaroo Point, Brisbane 4169 28 January 1977 The Rt Hon. M. Fraser Esq.,
Prime Minister of Australia,
Parliament House,
Canberra 2600
Dear Sir,

On behalf of the Queensland Police Union of Employees I bring to your notice details of Private Member's Bill as proposed by Senator Bonner such Bill being entitled 'Aborigines and Islanders (Admissibility of Confessions) Bill 1976'.

My members have at considerable length examined the contents of this Bill which seems to restrict alarmingly Police powers in the State of Queensland and would render virtually impossible the upholding of law and order amongst the coloured members of our community.

An examination of statistics available to this Union indicates that in 1976 the present situation existed with respect to the population of coloured people in the various states of the Commonwealth of Australia. It will be seen that in each state the numbers of Aborigines are recorded together with the percentage of the total population added to which are figures in respect to the Torres Strait Islanders who also may be found amongst our coloured community.
The following table illustrates the figures:

We earnestly request that you as Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Parliament should ensure that this Bill does not become Law until every aspect of the Bill is thoroughly and conscientiously examined and that the continuation of justice to all should be viewed with paramount importance.

Far too frequently in recent years Queenslanders have been described as being racist and oppressive of the Aborigine community, a statement which is completely lacking in fact and totally and completely unacceptable.

Over a long period of time the Queensland Police Union has had considerable dealings with the coloured community of this State and we have always found that the Law as it is presently framed particularly with respect to the 'Aborigine questioning' leaves nothing to be desired in guaranteeing the community of Queensland a proper and complete law enforcement program.

I am taking the liberty of forwarding a copy of this communication to each of your Cabinet colleagues, to all members of Cabinet in Queensland and further to all members of the Police Federation of Australia who will be discussing this problem at their Federation's Conference in Adelaide from 13 March onwards.
We would appreciate receiving advice from you that you will delay if possible the passage of this Bill until a complete inquiry may be carried out in respect of the contents of this letter.
