M. J. CALLAGHAN, General Secretary
I particularly draw honourable senators' attention to the sixth paragraph, which reads:

Far too frequently in recent years, Queenslanders have been described as being racist and oppressive of the Aboriginal community, a statement which is completely lacking in fact, and totally and completely unacceptable.

I feel that perhaps it would have been more correct to attribute that statement as reflecting the opinion of the Queensland Government, and we all know that it is not truly representative of all Queenslanders. Honourable senators will also note that this letter was written prior to the criminal law inquiry held in Queensland, and this inquiry did in fact vindicate my argument that my people and the Islanders need additional protection in the investigatory process. The report of this inquiry, which boasted as its members a senior judge of the Supreme Court, a senior counsel and a retired police inspector, has been ignored and is no doubt gathering dust in some State archive-along with other such reports which dare to challenge the omnipotence of the Queensland Government. This report also recommended the use of tape recorders, but this proposal was rubbished as being too complex for the police to operate, and readily subject to falsification. The report made the following recommendations in relation to Aborigines:
(a) Tape recording must be used when interrogating such persons for an indictable offence; failure to perform this duty will render any evidence so obtained completely inadmissible;
(b) Administrative directives should be drawn up clearly indicating to the police the manner in which such persons should be treated.

On the one hand the Government praises its inforcement officers, and than as quickly denigrates their competence, intelligence and integrity. As an example of its double standards, the Government has given the officers the right to operate breath analysing equipment which, to my way of thinking, is as equally difficult to operate and more open to abuse than a tape recorder.

Another major objection to the use of tape recorders and compliance with other provisions of this Bill was that such would be expensive and time consuming. We are dealing with the rights of the individual and matters such as expense and inconvenience should never be given consideration when the liberty and good name of the individual is at stake. I, for one, respect the integrity and intelligence of the Queensland police force and would give to its members the duty to use tape recording devices. Another example of duplicity is that the Queensland Government can readily reel off figures for its Aboriginal and Islander population, but cannot give similar figures on their incarceration. I have been told that to differentiate in this matter would be racist and discriminatory. I leave it to honourable senators to guess the real motive behind the Government's reticence to keep these statistics.

I ask honourable senators again to read my second reading speech delivered in this chamber on 26 October 1978 which, together with what I have said today, reinforces the urgency of this Bill becoming law at the earliest possible time. I submit that we have the power to enact this legislation-in fact I believe we have the duty to do so. The power was given to the Commonwealth in the referendum in 1967 by 89 per cent of the Australian voting population. Therefore, I demand, on behalf of Aboriginal Australians, that honourable senators be fearless and forthright and move to enact this legislation, and not let us have another Dunkirk, as occurred at Aurukun and Mornington Island.
I leave honourable senators to ponder a statement made by an unknown Aborigine man:
The Bible said God made us in his own image and likeness, but the white man tries to make us in his image and likeness.
For this reason alone, I commend the Bill to the Senate and submit that it merits universal support of all senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Durack) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: WESTERN AUSTRALIAN ABORIGINALS (RIGHT TO ELECTORAL ENROLMENT) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Walsh) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to ensure that Aboriginal Electors of the Commonwealth in Western Australia are not prevented from enrolling for elections for the Western Australian Parliament.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
Mr Acting Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

It is necessary in speaking to this Bill to summarise the events which led ultimately to its introduction. Always Aboriginal people have faced impediments to exercising effectively the right to vote. Adult franchise as it has applied for all other Australian-born citizens, at least for the lower houses of our parliaments, has never existed for Aborigines. Sometimes discrimination was overt-Aborigines had to be granted citizen rights before they could enrol. Even now under Commonwealth law and the law of most States Aborigines, though entitled to enrol and vote, are not compelled to do so as are other native-born or naturalised Australians. Even without deliberate legal impediments, the economic and cultural gap between many Aborigines and the mainstream of Australian society imposes a barrier between them and the effective use of the franchise. Other minority groups, as the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Chaney, mentioned on 6 June 1979, may face similar difficulties.

This Bill applies only to Aborigines, not because we are indifferent to these other groups, but because the only Commonwealth power relevant in this context is a restricted power-restricted, that is, to making laws pertaining to Aborigines. The Bill's scope is further restricted to enrolment to vote. It does not encompass actual voting procedures. The reasons I will detail later. The absence of overt legislative discrimination, though a prerequisite to equality of opportunity to vote, does not of itself guarantee equal opportunity.

Difficulties in oral, written or physical communication arising from a different cultural and geographic background constitute an impediment for some groups even if the letter of the law grants equality. Specifically, complex or restrictive enrolment requirements present greater problems for people whose background and experience is outside the mainstream of our society.

Amendments to the Electoral Act of Western Australia, in 1979, imposed more restrictive enrolment procedures than those of the Commonwealth or any other State with which Aborigines, especially, will have problems in complying. Whether that was the intention or not, that is the result. This Bill seeks to exempt Aborigines from complying with these restrictive procedures. It will require the State electoral registrar in Western Australia to enrol all Aborigines who are on the Commonwealth roll.

The chain of events leading to this Bill's introduction starts from the Western Australia State election in February 1977. Polling day in the electoral division of Kimberley was turbulent. I will not detail those events, but ultimately an appeal was lodged with a Court of Disputed Returns by the Australian Labor Party candidate, Ernie Bridge, who had been defeated by 93 votes. After prolonged hearings, judgement was given in favour of Bridge with costs against the defendant, Liberal candidate Alan Ridge, then a Minister in the Court Government. Justice Smith ordered a new election. When the appeal was first lodged the Court Government was asked to cover legal costs. It refused. Shortly before the judgement was given it magnanimously offered to pay the costs of both parties. By that time it was apparent that judgement would almost certainly be given in favour of Bridge. In such partisan manner was and is the law administered in Western Australia.

Justice Smith found that 96 people had been improperly deprived of their right to vote for Ernie Bridge and for that reason declared the election void-the winning margin having been only 93 votes. The Premier, when confronted with the judgement, dismissed it as 'one man's opinion'. The improprieties found by Justice Smith were those of a group of Perth lawyers who were briefed by the Liberal Party in obstructive scrutineering tactics to be used in polling booths. The objective was to prevent Aborigines from recording votes, or if that failed, from recording valid votes. In one instance, the Liberal scrutineer told the presiding officer that he had telephoned the returning officer, who had told him that 'how to vote' cards were not to be accepted as evidence of voting intentions. The court found that the alleged conversation did not occur.

Numerous allegations were made by Western Australian Government members that Aborigines had been manipulated by Ernie Bridge or his supporters. One of those allegations, in the form of a letter by John Tozer, MLC, to the West Australian, was the subject of a libel action by Bridge against Tozer and the newspaper. Judgement ultimately was given in favour of Bridge and $20,000 damages were awarded. The Smith judgment explicitly noted that no evidence of manipulation or malpractice, other than on polling day, had been presented to the court. Notwithstanding that fact, the State Government proceeded with a program based on the assertion that Aborigines were being manipulated and that irregularities were rife in postal voting.

Amendments to the Electoral Act were brought into the Western Australian Parliament's 1977 spring session. So discriminatory against Aborigines were these amendments that they were opposed in the Legislative Assembly not only by the Labor Opposition, but by half the Country Party, and a Liberal back bencher, and were defeated by the casting vote of the Liberal Speaker. The Government's next move was to establish an electoral inquiry under Magistrate Kay.

The rationale for that inquiry was alleged malpractice by the manipulation of Aboriginal voters. The allegations of manipulation were not upheld by Justice Smith, by the Kay inquiry or in subsequent court proceedings. However, undeterred by the dearth of evidence, Magistrate Kay found that the potential for malpractice did exist and made recommendations on changes to enrolment and voting procedures.

The Western Australian Government introduced a second Bill in 1979 which adopted most-not all-of the Kay recommendations. It was passed by the Parliament early in October. The major amendment which is the target of this Bill-clause 8 in the Western Australian amendment-is that which requires applications for enrolment to be witnessed by either a justice of the peace, a police officer, a clerk of courts or an electoral officer. Previously applications could be witnessed by any elector, the same as the Commonwealth Act. That amendment, for which we and evidently every other Government in Australia can see no need, is obviously irksome to anyone wanting to enrol or change enrolment. To people with language or other communications problems it is a difficulty. For Aborigines, especially those living in remote areas like the Kimberleys, it is a major deterrent. Except for electoral officers, all the people permitted to witness applications represent authority in Aboriginal eyes. The probability is high that an Aborigine's only previous contact with justices of the peace, policemen or clerks of the court would have been as a victim of the punitive or disciplinary arm of the law. It is no overstatement to say the Aborigines are apprehensive about approaching people in these positions. They are frightened of them. There are Aboriginal justices of the peace at some settlements, but that is far from ubiquitous.

The Court Government's motive for taking the action it did was telegraphed in a letter written by the then member for Kimberley, Alan Ridge, to one of his supporters, John Fletcher, after the 1977 State election. The letter read:

I am hopeful that at some time in the future the Electoral Act will be amended with a view to overcoming some of the difficulties which were experienced on polling day. I can foresee that unless this is done, there could be anything up to 4,000 Aborigines on the roll at the next election and, under these circumstances, the Liberal Party would probably be fighting a lost cause.

The Court of Disputed Returns in 1977 forced the letter to be made public. Needless to say, Alan Ridge had not intended it to become public. The Court Government complied with Mr Ridge's desire to amend the Electoral Act, hoping thereby to prevent Aborigines enrolling in sufficient numbers to defeat the Liberal Party in Kimberley. No doubt some Aborigines have been deterred or otherwise prevented from enrolling but Alan Ridge was defeated by Ernie Bridge in the 1980 State election.

The harassment of Aborigines at the direction of the then Police Commissioner with at least the tacit approval of Premier Court and Police Minister Hassell continued after the 1980 State election. Ninety charges for alleged breaches of the Electoral Act, relating to postal voting, were laid against three Labor Party campaign workers in Kimberley. These people were arrested and incarcerated on charges for which normally summonses would be issued-a procedure publicly defended by Commissioner Leitch on the grounds that the Western Australian Trades and Labor Council President had once refused to answer a summons. Ultimately all the charges were either thrown out of court or withdrawn by the Crown.

The three Labor Party workers were white but in an attempt to obtain evidence against them every Aborigine in Kimberley who had applied for a postal vote was interrogated by the police. Some were bundled into paddy waggons, driven to the Wyndham Police Station and questioned, inter alia, about how they had voted, in the presence of Alma Low, President of the Liberal Party's Wyndham branch.

Some charges were thrown out of court in July. Most were left in limbo till the end of September when Commissioner Leitch announced they would be pressed in court. Just before the 1980 Federal election he announced all charges would be dropped. There is little doubt that Leitch's late September announcement was designed to deter by intimidation, Aborigines from applying for postal votes. None of his partisan actions have been criticised by the Government of Western Australia, many have been explicitly supported.

The intention of my Bill is to remove the deterrents and impediments to Aboriginal enrolment imposed by clause 8 of the Bill amending the Western Australian Electoral Act in 1979. It effectively ensures that all Aborigines who have complied with Commonwealth Electoral Act procedures will be included in the State roll for the appropriate district and province. The first two clauses are formal only, and clauses 3 to 8 provide:
Clause 3 'Aboriginal' defined as in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Discriminatory Laws) Act 1975,
Other definitions taken from Western Australian Electoral Act.
Clause 4 Act binds Western Australia and Commonwealth.
Clause 5 states that an Aboriginal who is enrolled to vote in Commonwealth elections shall be entitled to enrol as an elector for Western Australian elections.

Clause 6 supplements clause 5 by stating that a Western Australian Registrar shall not refuse to enrol an Aboriginal for a Western Australian election if that Aboriginal is enrolled as a Commonwealth elector.

Clause 7. Is a machinery clause that provides that where an Aboriginal is enrolled at a particular address for Commonwealth elections then he shall be enrolled for State elections for a division and province appropriate to that address.

Clause 8. Supplements the general purpose of the Act by stating that conditions or restrictions other than those set out in the Commonwealth Electoral Act shall apply to an Aboriginal enrolling for elections in Western Australia and in particular states that no requirement as to witnessing shall be placed on an Aboriginal seeking to enrol in Western Australian elections unless the Aboriginal chooses to comply with any general provisions that may exist.

In summary, therefore, the Bill does no more than guarantee that Aborigines in Western Australia when enrolling for State elections will receive the same treatment under State electoral law as under Commonwealth law. It allows the State to continue to have its own electoral rolls and does not seek to interfere in the manner the State organises its own elections other than to the extent noted above.

An identical Bill was introduced in the Senate in 1979. Two weeks before it was introduced, I supplied a copy to the office of the then Minister, Senator Chaney. I spoke to his private secretary asking him to tell the Minister that if he or his Department believed the Bill had technical defects or was impractical, I and others who had helped to prepare it would change it accordingly.

The Minister did not suggest any changes. I assume the Bill is not technically deficient, and will not be opposed by Government members on technical grounds. Several attempts by the Opposition to take the Bill through its later stages during the last Parliament were defeated by the Government. I intend to take the same action during the Budget session this year, and hope it is not again kept on the shelf.

I have little doubt that many Government senators, including the former Minister, would support the Bill in a free vote. I also realise, given the condition of the Liberal Party in Western Australia, that overt support by Senator Chaney as Minister could have cost him his preselection. I would expect the present Minister to have similar views on question on aboriginal rights. He would therefore also be persona non grata to the cabal of Northern extremists and fast money men, hiding their sleazy objectives behind a smokescreen of States rights, who control the Western Australian Liberal Party. Senator Baume however, is not subject to their discipline.
On 6 June, 1979 the following urgency motion was moved in the Senate:
That Aborigines should have the same opportunity to enrol and vote in State Elections as in Federal Elections.
It received the support of the Government and was carried without dissent. In the debate Senator Chaney said:
I have indicated that the Government will support the resolution-it does, subject to the qualifications I am making in this speech.

The qualifications were of three kinds. Firstly, Senator Chaney said he separated what he called the 'general abuse' from the substance of the motion. The Government, he said, supported the latter but not the former. That qualification should not preclude Government members from supporting this motion. Secondly, he drew attention to a number of practical problems associated with voting and in particular the potential for malpractice associated with illiterate voters. All these qualifications, however, applied to voting practices. The Bill deals only with enrolment. Thirdly, Senator Chaney expressed a somewhat equivocal attitude to a question of Commonwealth power to control State electoral procedures. He said:
I do not argue that the power does not exist. I say that it is a matter which will almost certainly lead to legal disputation and about which I think one could mount arguments either way.

If the Commonwealth eschewed all legislation which could conceivably be successfully challenged in the High Court, given that court's notorious record of both political and capricious judgements, the Commonwealth would scarcely legislate at all. None of the qualifications added by Senator Chaney on 6 June provide adequate grounds for opposing the Bill. Indeed, apart from the general support he expressed on behalf of the Government, he pointed out that all disadvantaged people-and most Aborigines are disadvantaged-being without other power, have a special interest in the political power conferred by the franchise. He said:
But the Government is absolutely committed to the idea that it is of great importance to Aboriginal people that they should be able to exercise their vote;

These people, being in greater need of assistance, have a particular interest in who forms the Government of the country. For that reason, it is important that they have some say in who should govern the country, or indeed their State.

I hope that the Government support for the principle of Aboriginal voting given on behalf of the Government by Senator Chaney on that occasion and the hostility to racially based discrimination articulated abroad by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) will ensure that this Bill becomes an Act before the end of this year.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (HOLDERS OF OFFICES OF PROFIT) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Colston) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution so as to enable a person holding an office of profit under the Crown to be chosen as a senator or as a member of the House of Representatives.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to make an alteration to section 44 of the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia. The alteration will enable persons holding an office of profit under the Crown to be chosen as senators or as members of the House of Representatives. Before discussing the purpose of this Bill, it is pertinent to examine the provisions of section 44 of the Constitution. Under the heading of 'disqualification', section 44 reads:
Any person who-

(i) Is under any acknowledgement of allegiance, obedience, or adherence to a foreign power, or is a subject or a citizen or entitled to the rights or privileges of a subject or a citizen of a foreign power: or

(ii) Is attainted of treason, or has been convicted and is under sentence, or subject to be sentenced, for any offence punishable under the law of the Commonwealth or of a State by imprisonment for one year or longer: or
(iii) Is an undischarged bankrupt or insolvent; or
(iv) Holds any office of profit under the Crown, or any pension payable during the pleasure of the Crown out of any of the revenues of the Commonwealth; or

(v) Has any direct or indirect pecuniary interest in any agreement with the Public Service of the Commonwealth otherwise than as a member and in common with the other members of an incorporated company consisting of more than twenty-five persons:
shall be incapable of being chosen or of sitting as a senator or a member of the House of Representatives.

But sub-section (iv) does not apply to the office of any of the Queen's Ministers of State for the Commonwealth, or of any of the Queen's Ministers for a State, or to the receipt of pay, half pay, or a pension, by any person as an officer or member of the Queen's navy or army, or to the receipt of pay as an officer or member of the naval or military forces of the Commonwealth by any person whose services are not wholly employed by the Commonwealth.

The Constitution Alteration (Holders of Offices of Profit) Bill 1981 relates to sub-section (iv) of section 44. An effect of sub-section (iv) is that any member of the Commonwealth or State public service who seeks election to the Federal Parliament must resign his Public Service appointment prior to nomination. If the public servant does not resign, he continues, of course, to hold an office of profit under the Crown. Thus, if he is successful in the election, he runs the risk of being declared ineligible to sit in the Senate or in the House of Representatives.

Very few would argue that a public servant should be eligible to sit in either the Senate or the House of Representatives. Under the Westminster system, the holding of an office of profit under the Crown is a traditional form of disqualification for parliamentary membership. It is quite conceivable that employment in the Public Service could affect the independence of a member of parliament.

On one hand, the practice that a public servant should not be eligible to sit in the Senate or House of Representatives is a sound one. It prevents a degree of potential conflict of interest from arising. On the other hand, it does restrict the ability of the public servant to contest a Federal election. Other Australian adults enjoy the freedom of nominating for political office without being required, by virtue of constitutional provisions, to resign from their current employment. The public servant, however, is required to resign his position before contesting a Federal election. Thus one of the basic tenets of Australian democracy, namely, the freedom of the individual to offer himself for public service in the Parliament, is severely limited for public servants.

One important consequence of this situation is that there are probably many highly qualified public servants who could make a significant contribution to this Parliament but who choose not to seek election because of the possiblity of losing their livelihood in merely attempting to enter Parliament. It is all too easy to say that the public servant who desires to serve his country in Parliament should accept the risk of losing his employment. But responsibility tugs hard at the person with a family and spouse to support. The prospect of throwing away job security and all that means for one's family must be too daunting for many public servants even to contemplate a possible parliamentary career.

I have previously outlined in this Parliament the limited opportunities for re-appointment to the Commonwealth and State public services for public servants who have resigned to contest a Federal election. For a more detailed discussion of this topic, I refer honourable senators to the Senate Hansard of 29 May 1978, pages 2019 and 2020. At this stage, it is simply sufficient to say that in the Commonwealth Public Service or the Public Service of any State or Territory there is at present no right of re-appointment. Certainly the public servant in Australia who unsuccessfully contests a Federal election may be re-appointed but it is important that the word 'may' be stressed. It is clear that there is no automatic right of re-appointment. I am convinced that this Parliament is all the poorer because many highly capable public servants do not, due to the restrictions of section 44 of the Constitution, even consider the prospect of standing for Federal Parliament.

In a submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, the Commonwealth Public Service Board in April 1980 said that amendments would be made to the Commonwealth Public Service Act. These amendments, which have not yet been introduced into the Parliament, were to include:
Replacing the provision for discretionary reinstatement of unsuccessful candidates in the Public Service by a clear entitlement to reinstatement;
Amending Public Service General Orders to indicate the legislative position in respect of Commonwealth laws, and to advise public servants to ascertain the provisions of any relevant State laws.

The Board in its submission admitted that these amendments did not alter the position with regard to State public servants who nominate for Commonwealth seats. For that reason, even if the proposed legislation in relation to the Commonwealth Public Service Act is presented to the Federal Parliament and is subsequently passed, an amendment to section 44 of the Constitution is still necessary.

In terms of justice for public servants both State and Federal, it is necessary to do something about a system which fetters their rights to nominate for Federal Parliament. In terms of the contribution that Parliament can make to the democratic process, it is important that each person in Australia should, as far as humanly possible, be able to contest a place in the national legislature. Thus we must ensure that public servants are not deterred by unnecessary constraints from offering themselves for parliamentary service.

This Bill is aimed towards that end. It allows a person who holds an office of profit under the Crown to be chosen as a senator or a member of the House of Representatives. The Bill further provides, however, that a person who holds an office of profit under the Crown and who has been chosen as a senator or member is not able to receive any allowances or to sit in the Parliament. In other words, he must resign his public service appointment before becoming eligible to take a seat in the Parliament and to draw salary and allowances as a member of Parliament.

The question could be raised about what would happen if a public servant were elected and did not resign his public service appointment. It appears that sections 20 and 38 of the Constitution would cover such a situation. Under these sections, the place of a senator or member becomes vacant if, without the permission of his house of the Parliament, he fails for two consecutive months to attend Parliament.

The alteration of the Constitution as outlined by this Bill would require amendments to some existing Commonwealth and State legislation. These amendments will be necessary because some existing legislation is based on the assumption that public servants cannot be elected to the Federal Parliament whilst still holding their public service appointment. These amendments, however, may be made readily by the Commonwealth and State parliaments. No further constitutional changes are required to allow the necessary complementary legislative amendments to be made. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

He specifically attached those words to me. I find that offensive.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLaren, I will read you the part of the Standing Order which I think is applicable here. Standing Order 418, in part, states:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . all imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on Members shall be considered highly disorderly.
It might help the proceedings if you would temper your remarks so they will not be so emotional.

TALK.START.PARA: —I made those remarks because Senator Martin had been continually protesting and seeking to interject while I was making my speech. She has to cop it if she gives it. She cannot cop it, she has proved that. If I have offended Senator Martin I will exclude her from my remarks about the Government.
—Senator McLaren, you will please confine your remarks to the amendment to which you are speaking.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, you asked me to--
—Senator McLaren, I am asking you to apply your remarks to the amendment.

—All right, Mr Acting Deputy President. If you do not want my apology or a withdrawal I am quite happy to leave the matter the way it is. We will get back to the amendment. I know that I am getting near the bone with many people. They do not like the truth. Ten minutes of my time has already been taken up by frivolous points of order, some of which were taken before the suspension of the sitting for dinner and now.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter to which I refer is a matter of great concern to the people in South Australia and it is causing a lot of disquiet. On Tuesday when I was speaking to the tabling of the Australian Water Resources Council report I said that I would be making some further inquiries as to why the South Australian Minister of Water Resources had not raised the matter of salinity in the River Murray at the Council's meeting. I want to correct the record now and say that my inquiries have revealed that at the Australian Water Resources Council meetings it is generally accepted that the matters for discussion are to be of a mutual interest. Of course, it is only common sense to realise, after being told that, that the River Murray would not be of mutual interest to States such as Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory. I am informed that is the reason why that matter would not have been raised at the meetings, but there are other avenues at which the matter can be raised.

I am greatly concerned about the attitude the South Australian Minister has adopted to the proposed amendments to the River Murray Waters Agreement. He has whipped up some enthusiasm among some irrigators in South Australia. They, in turn, are writing to us. No doubt members on the other side, particularly South Australian members, have received letters from these organisations asking us to support what the South Australian Government is doing. I shall quote from a letter I received from the South Australian Murray irrigators at Waikerie. These people, unfortunately, are not very well informed. I would have thought that the Minister, who lives in that area and represents those people, would have informed them that public protests will not assist in any way to secure satisfactory amendments to the River Murray Waters Agreement. The letter stated:

At the present time the South Australian Government is engaged in a strenuous campaign to protect South Australia's rights under the River Murray Waters Agreement and at the same time to have the powers of the River Murray Commission extended to cover control over water quality.

This campaign is more likely to succeed if it has the full support of the Senators and House of Representative members from South Australia all of whom represent people whose future will be jeopardised if action is not taken immediately to protect their interests.

We therefore ask you to support the South Australian Government in its efforts to safeguard the State's water resources and that you impress upon the Minister for National Development and the Government the urgency and importance of the negotiations which are at present being conducted between the three State governments and the Commonwealth.

I am quite prepared to do that. As a matter of fact, I have done that. I support the negotiations, but I do not support what the present Minister has been doing. When he can he has been speaking on the radio, and he has been reported in the Press, criticising the New South Wales Government and stirring up no end of trouble. As I have said in this Parliament before, the only result he will get from those actions is perhaps the antagonisation of both other governments involved, the New South Wales Government and the Victorian Government, which stand to gain nothing at all from a River Murray agreement because those States have first use of the river. The people of South Australia stand to lose the most if he jeopardises these discussions. I have pleaded in the Parliament and I have written to these people and told them that he ought to back off and have a bit of common sense. I was informed today by sources which I do not want to reveal that he may at last be taking a conciliatory attitude rather than continuing his confrontation. I only hope, as I said in a speech I made in this place the other day, that he has not gone too far with his criticism of the other two States and that they will be prepared to sit down and renegotiate matters concerning the River Murray Commission in a rational way so that we in South Australia can be protected.

As I have pointed out to these people, Mr Arnold was the member for Chaffey when the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources conducted a public inquiry into Australia's water resources and the Commonwealth's role in that area. I told many people in the Riverland, and it was advertised in the daily Press, that public inquiries were being held. Nobody in the Riverland of South Australia made a submission, not even the Minister, who was at the time of the inquiry a member of the South Australian Opposition. Nothing was wrong. Everything was okay. That was a couple of years ago. About four years ago we commenced our inquiry and the report was tabled in this Parliament in 1978. Neither Mr Arnold nor any other people in the Riverland made a submission to our Committee about the problem of salinity which existed in the Riverland of South Australia. As I pointed out to them, we could have heard their submissions and probably said something about the problem in South Australia in the report. We did not hear a word. We had many representations from people in south-west New South Wales, particularly in the Wakool area. We were able to see at first hand the magnificent work that was being done there to try to control salinity and the massive amount of money that was being expended on putting down tube well bores to try to get rid of the salinity to help to give us better quality water.

The Dunstan and Corcoran governments were criticised by somebody in this place a while ago. The Dunstan Government, when Des Corcoran was Minister of Works, was especially criticised. He went about negotiating this new agreement in a very workman-like manner. He did not try to score political kudos from Mr Askin and Mr Lewis when they were Premiers of a Liberal government in New South Wales as Mr Arnold is doing now against Mr Wran. Mr Corcoran knew that there was no mileage in it. He treated those people fairly and talked to them in a common-sense manner. To try to score some cheap political kudos in the Riverland Mr Arnold is shouting from the roof tops that the New South Wales Government has to come to the party and give us better quality water. The New South Wales Government does not have to if it does not want to. Senator Jessop, a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, would know that. He would know that the only way to reach some agreement is to sit down and talk about these matters rationally and not try to score political points as Mr Arnold has been doing.

I have also had a similar representation from the Lower Murray Private Irrigators Association at Tailem Bend in South Australia. They are the matters that I wanted to mention. I hope that Senator Jessop will be able to tell his South Australian colleague that what his colleague has been doing is only doing damage to the negotiations that are going on and that he ought to cool his heels and have a bit of common sense. The proof is there that he was not concerned about salinity in the River Murray a few years ago when we were holding the inquiry, but he is very concerned now when he thinks he can score some cheap political points from the New South Wales Government.

I want to mention another matter. Honourable senators opposite might have thought I have been very critical of them tonight. I want to give some credit to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) for the letter I received from him today. I do not know whether he was the person who invented the little social security card I received, but whoever it was in his Department, I think it is a great innovation. Members of parliament can now carry this little card with them and when they are asked questions about the pension-whether it be the widow's pension, the aged pension, the invalid pension-or the unemployment benefit or whatever, they can just take out that card and see at a glance what the amount is. No member can keep in his head all the benefits to which people are entitled. I think Senator Chaney ought to be commended for circulating that card to members of parliament and making the statement in his letter dated 4 March, which I received today, that it will be updated in May. No doubt somebody in his Department has thought up this idea and, whoever it is, I give him due credit for thinking of that innovation.

The other matter I mention was raised in the Parliament today by Senator Lewis. It was raised in the other House last night by Mr Fraser. Of course, it was followed up in this place by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) denigrating the Soviet Union and implying all sorts of improper motives to the Soviet Ambassador in Australia which are quite unfounded. It is just a political ball game. Honourable senators opposite are engaged in trying to belittle the Soviet Union and saying what a great danger that country is to us. Of course, their memories are very short. If they looked back in history they would find that the Soviet Union and its people have never been an enemy of the Allies. In the last two world wars the Russians fought on the side of the Allies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just ask NATO now.

—Never mind about NATO. The honourable senator was not alive in the First World War and probably was not old enough to go to the second one. He probably does not even know that if it had not been for the magnificent effort of the Soviets in Leningrad or Stalingrad, as it was then, he might now be under the dominance of nazi Germany, or whoever took over from Hitler, and the Japanese. If those powers had linked up the honourable senator would not be living the life of comfort that he is living today.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that despite the fact that the Government continually criticises the Soviet Union it is prepared to trade with it. The trade amounts to large sums of money. The Government is interested in the Soviet Union's money and nothing else. All the Government wants to do is to criticise the Soviets. Woe betide the primary industry in this country if suddenly the Soviet Union finds another source of supply for wheat and wool and those other commodities which the Soviet Union buys from this country. The way members of the Government are carrying on under their leader it could well bring that about. I give the Government a warning that it ought to be more careful.

Let us have a look at the answer given yesterday, 4 March, by Mr Anthony to Mr Kerin who is our spokesman on primary industry. It related to the amount of trade between Australia and the Soviet Union which is in our favour by a massive amount. I refer firstly to mutton. In 1976-77 some $9,826,000 worth of mutton was sold to the Soviet Union. The latest figures which Mr Anthony gives for the year 1979-80 show that mutton to the value of $36,674,000-a massive increase-was exported. In 1978-79 some $15,261,000 worth of wheat was sold to the Soviets. The figure to the end of June last year was $432m. Let us take a look at rice exports to the Soviet Union. In the year 1977-78, the total value was $3,152,000. Last year, to 30 June, the figure was $37,282,000-a massive increase.

Let me now turn to barley, of which South Australia grows a lot. We are very interested in the welfare of our barley growers. A total of $9,126,000 worth of barley was sold to the Soviet Union in 1976-77. For the year ended 30 June last the figure was $139,738,000. This is a massive increase in the sales of barley to the Soviet Union. Let us have a look at wool. Most of the wool growers support the people who sit opposite. In the year 1978-79, $185,973,000 worth of wool was sold to the Soviet Union. The amount last year to June 30th was $203,886,000. How much of that wool was Mr Fraser's wool? The man who stands up in his place and denigrates the Soviet Union is quite prepared to sell Nareen Wool to the Soviet Union. He does his best in this Parliament to embarrass the ambassador who resides here in Canberra.

Let us have a look at the total value of primary products which are sold to the Soviet Union. The total value of agricultural commodity exports to the Soviet Union in 1978-79 was $221,521,000. To the end of June last year it was $897,837,000. So the figures are quadrupled. We hear talk about putting embargoes on the Soviet Union and that Australia can live without Soviet trade. Australia cannot do so. Not one person opposite, if he spoke the truth, would be prepared to stand up and say that Australia should cease trading with the Soviet Union. If Senator Lajovic, who is trying to interject, was prepared to do that the coalition would not have a country seat in the Parliament. As I have said, the Soviet Union's money is good but its socialist policies are not. That is the very thing Senator Lajovic hinged his speech on tonight. All Government members were talking anti-socialist. I have pointed out to Senator Lajovic that he is waxing fat on the exports of the primary producers of this country to the Soviet Union. He does not get up and protest about that. When he is prepared to say that we ought to put an embargo on the sale of agricultural products to the Soviet Union I will have a little more respect for him but will not agree with him. While he is talking with a forked tongue I have no respect for him. Government members can attempt to rebut me if they like. I will be prepared to hear their rebuttal. I fully support the amendment moved by my colleague, Senator Button.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been entertained as usual by a speech from Senator McLaren. It was tempered with the usual humour and reluctance to attack this side of the House. I am glad that in the dying moments of his speech he referred to the amendment that has been proposed by the Opposition. I think I should make one or two comments about the matters that he has raised. He suggested that members on this side of the House have not got the capacity to express an independent point of view.
—You are not allowed to.

—That demonstrates the total ignorance of the Australian Labor Party and its amnesia with respect to what has happened in this chamber on numerous occasions. I, for one, have had the temerity to demonstrate independent points of view on issues that my party has not necessarily followed. I am still here to tell the tale. I suggest that any Opposition members who dared to disagree with a caucus ruling would be expelled from the Labor Party. That has happened before. I guess that it will not happen again while the timidity of people such as Senator McLaren persists. They would not dare do so. People who sign the socialist doctrine have slavishly to pursue that course. If they do not they no longer enjoy the privilege of sitting in the Parliament to represent the electorate of Australia. We have that privilege. I will continue, if necessary, to exercise an independent point of view on matters that do not conflict with my political philosophy. Those issues that have some regard to the welfare of the electorate of Australia--
—And South Australia.
—And in South Australia in particular--
—Why don't you take Tony Messner's place on the front bench?

—I do not know about that. It is not for me to answer that question. I am pleased to stand behind Senator Messner and support him in any way I can. I refer now to one or two matters mentioned by Senator McLaren from South Australia. I think he referred to the record of the South Australian Liberal Government. I was very interested to see the results of a recent gallup poll in South Australia concerning an electoral assessment of the Premier of South Australia. His rating was extremely high compared with other leaders in this country. That seems to me to be significant of the regard in which he is held in South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The South Australian Government's development program, I believe, has encouraged people in South Australia to be somewhat more optimistic than they were in the last decade of Labor government in that State. All the Labor Government did seemed to me to be associated with the provision of arts and all the frivolous sorts of policies that we all enjoy but which contribute nothing or very little to the development of the State. Since the Liberal Party has been in government in South Australia there seems to me to have been a feeling of optimism. I suggest that this optimism ought to be encouraged even by the Labor Party because we have a potential for development in South Australia that is quite remarkable. We have mineral resources in the north eastern part of the State and coal deposits. Those resources give me and many other people in South Australia a feeling of optimism.

One of the things I regret is that the attitude of the Labor Party to mining uranium has tended to retard the progress of South Australia. I raised this matter in the Senate last week when I expressed some gratitute for and some sort of hope at a statement made by Mr John Bannon, the Leader of the Opposition in South Australia. He was reported to have said that the Labor Party had changed its attitude with respect to the development of uranium. In the Senate I learned by way of interjection or from some common opposite that this was not so. I regret that very much because, having studied the uranium mining issue, I believe it is as safe as, if not safer than, any other mining. All mining operations are hazardous. Coal mining operations have claimed the lives of far more people than most other mining operations in the world. It seems to me that the Opposition has some sort of veil drawn across its eyes when it comes to recognising the advantages of mining uranium in a State like South Australia. I believe John Bannon was right in what he was reported to have said. I think some members of the Labor Party believe that what Mr Bannon was reported to have said is quite right, that the party should change its attitude to the development of the uranium in Australia.

Another point I want to take up concerns the criticism levelled at Mr Peter Arnold, the Minister of Water Resources in South Australia. I am glad to say that Senator McLaren admitted that the Australian Water Resources Council was not really an appropriate forum in which to raise the question of salinity as far as the three states of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia are concerned. However, Mr Arnold at the meeting in question in Brisbane on 25 June raised a matter in an informal sense, with the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick). He got his message through on that occasion. The Minister is on record as commenting on salinity at the twenty-second meeting of the Council held on 23 November 1979. He identified salinity as a major problem in South Australia and stressed that an increase in the availability of funds for this purpose would allow greater effort in mitigating the problem. The matter did not arise on the occasion that Senator McLaren referred to.

TALK.START.PARA: —But he was only using the brief that was prepared for Mr Payne to use because he was not in government long enough.

—I must say that Mr Payne, a Labor Minister, and I, both of us from South Australia, made comments about the problem with respect to the River Murray on a nationwide program. We supported each other's views. I think that is what we ought to be doing.
—That is what I said.

—Well, I have done that. I hoped that the honourable senator would have made mention of the fact that Mr Payne and I appeared as South Australians on the same program expressing a mutual concern and a unanimous view with respect to what should be done. If Mr Arnold is following Mr Payne's attitude I think that is commendable. He has said that there ought to be a national approach to our water resources. I support that view. I want to use the Address-in-Reply debate to highlight what I regard as an urgent need that has failed to be recognised for far too long by Federal governments. I refer to the need for a national approach to our water resources. I have said that time and again and I repeat it here tonight. This matter has been the subject of several reports. Senator McLaren mentioned the report of Senator Thomas's committee.
—It is a Senate committee of which Senator Thomas is the Chairman. Get away from calling it your committee. That is your attitude-the Jessop committee. It is a Senate committee.

—I have never heard anyone refer to my committee as the Jessop Committee. I have heard other committees referred to by the names of colleagues opposite. I could mention the Senate Select Committee on Water Pollution which has been referred to time and again as the Davidson Committee. I am quite happy to do that.
—It was not the Davidson Committee.

—Well, the honourable senator's colleagues on his side of the House refer to the committee as the Davidson committee, with some sense of pride as a matter of fact. I cannot see anything wrong with that. I took over the chairmanship of my committee from Senator Keeffe. I believe that Senator Keeffe's committee-it was known as the Keeffe Committee in those days-did some valuable work. I do not regard that as being anything other than a compliment to the committee of which Senator Keeffe was chairman. Let me refer to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, of which Senator McLaren is a very hard-working member. I pay a tribute to him. Senator Thomas has told me how reliable Senator McLaren happens to be on that committee. I endorse that. I believe, despite the honourable senator's dulcet tones and his praiseworthy attitude that he expresses frequently towards honourable senators on this side of the House, he is a genuinely hard-working member of that Committee. The National Resources Committee presented a report which really endorsed the conclusions of the Committee chaired by Senator Davidson in 1970, as did the committee of which I am proud to have been chairman and on which Senators Mulvihill and Melzer were representatives of the Opposition. I pay tribute to their efforts because I could not wish for more reliable, more faithful or more earnest members of a committee than were those two honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: Our committee made the comment that it believed that the Government was evading-we did not use those terms but that is what we meant; I am sure that would be endorsed by the honourable senators on my committee-taking a national approach to water resources in this country. I have said time and again that our most important resource in this country is water. Without water we cannot develop our country properly. Without high quality water, South Australia and some parts of Western Australia would suffer because of an increase in salinity or because of a decrease in nutrients resulting perhaps from indiscriminate agricultural practices or some unfortunate forestry practices in some areas. We believe it is important that the national Government pay more attention to this problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bad irrigation planning.

—I intended to refer to that subject a little later but now that the honourable senator has interjected I will say something about it now. As a result of the visit to trouble spots along the River Murray the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment discovered that irresponsible irrigation practices were being carried out. I think that occurs largely because in many instances people are provided with an amount of water to use and they use it irrespective of whether they need it. I believe it would be wise, in the interests of responsible management of irrigated properties, for all governments to introduce regulations or legislation requiring people to pay for the water they use rather than give them an amount of water to use carte blanche. It is human nature for people to say: 'The water is here; let us use it'. The result of that action happens to be quite unfortunate to the neighbour who lives in a lower terrain. We saw evidence of this in Kerang-it was quite a case in point-where an irrigator was flooding his property to the detriment of his neighbour. I think that is a good point.

SPEECH.PARA: In the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment we stated that more attention ought to be given to more responsible irrigation management. I reiterate that our view was an endorsement of the suggestion made by the Senate Select Committee on Water Pollution, of which my colleague Senator Davidson was Chairman, that there ought to be a national approach. On page 9 of the report of the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment relating to the continuing scrutiny of pollution in the River Murray under the heading 'A National Approach' it is stated:
The Committee concluded that the whole task of water resources management could best be undertaken on a national scale.

I think that is the way we should approach it. It is quite unacceptable that the governments concerned with the River Murray Commission have been dilly-dallying about taking action to ensure that the River Murray Commission is given control over water quality. I believe people on both sides of this House would endorse that point. In this respect we made a point of mentioning that there was a need for a co-ordinated approach to management. The report states:
The Committee strongly believes that as a first step towards better management, the River Murray Waters Agreement should be amended to allow the Commission:
Power to consider, make recommendations and make representations in relation to:
Water Quality
Flood Mitigation
Flood plain management
Environmental and conservation matters
Recreation.

Until we do that sort of thing and until the States concerned recognise that this matter transcends individual States' interests and becomes a problem of national importance, I do not think we will get anywhere. I would advocate that the Federal Government ought to give some attention to the urgent requirement to establish a national water resources authority upon which the States could have representation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't tell us to try to get publicity. Get on to your leader.

—I do not want to talk to Senator Cavanagh. I am talking about something that I regard important. Senator Cavanagh wants to stop me giving some positive suggestions to the Government. He keeps interjecting.
—The recommendations were in the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources report two and a half years ago. What have you done about it? It is all in this report.

—I know. I am merely suggesting that there have been too many reports and it is about time for action. We have been going on since 1970 when the Senate Select Committee on Water Pollution report was put down and we are still messing around with arguments about the River Murray Agreement which should have been rectified a decade ago. We should be further along the road to establishing some sort of responsible attitude to water quality and quantity in Australia. I think that the amount of money that the Government has spent on water quality and conservation has been miserable. The matter ought to be rectified because without water we cannot do anything. I regard it as being a top priority. I suggest that the Government ought to move in concert with the States to establish a national water authority. It may well be that the River Murray Commission could be expanded to adopt that role. I do not know, but I am making what I regard to be a positive suggestion. Within that authority there ought to be gathered together a number of biologists, hydrologists, engineers and other people concerned with preserving the quality of water to form a centre of excellence with respect to salinity control and other pollution control. Until we do that and until we come to grips with the need for massive funding to achieve it I believe it will retard the development of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to raise another matter about which I have been worried. I know that Senator Mulvihill and other members of the Committee on Science and the Environment were also worried that the salinity level in many of the streams in Australia exceeds the World Health Organisation's standards for potable water. I am glad to see that Senator Melzer is in the chair because she has some concern about this matter. I have already referred to the way in which she supported the Committee so well. We are worried that insufficient research is being done in Australia with respect to the effects on hypertension of this high level of salt in our drinking water. What effect does this have on hypertension? Does Senator Cavanagh's blood pressure suffer because he has been drinking water in South Australia? Does my blood pressure suffer because of the high salinity level in the water that we drink in copious quantities in that State? What effect has this saline level in the waters of Australia on renal disease among adults? What effect does it have on renal disease among children? What effect does it have on the unborn child? If I were asked how much research has been carried out in Australia on those questions I would say: 'Practically nothing'. I believe there is a need for far more funding to be provided for research into these very important public health issues.

Another matter that would be of concern, I believe, to South Australians in particular but to all other Australians is the virus which causes amoebic meningitis. This matter has been given a lot of public airing in South Australia in recent times since the unfortunate death of a young boy in January after contracting a water-borne virus. I think we have to come to grips with the need to ensure that these water supplies are filtered and that they are properly chlorinated and dealt with in a way that will remove the fear and alarm that have been caused in recent times in my State.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are speaking to the converted. Why don't you talk to your Prime Minister?
—I hope that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) will read my speech with some interest. In fact, I will send a copy to him and ask him to give me some sort of reply to it.
—But he is in your party room. Why didn't you speak like this in your party room?

—I mention these matters. I make representations, along with other senators on this side of the House, and I consider that the efforts that we have employed have met with some success. I hope we will continue to see that sort of response.
—Just talk in your party room.
—It is the salinity in the water he is drinking.

—I am a little worried about Senator Cavanagh tonight. He seems to be interjecting with rather unusual enthusiasm. I am concerned about the salinity level in the water of South Australia, having listened to what he said tonight. I am merely stating that there are many people in my State who are quite concerned about it, not the least being a gentleman called Professor Williams, who was in my office recently. He is the Professor of Zoology at the University of Adelaide. In May 1980, at a symposium organised by ANZUS, he presented a paper entitled 'Biology Problems in the Management of Australian Water Resources'. I should like to refer to some passages of his paper, if I may. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Water quality in Australia as much as elsewhere, has become an important matter in water resource management.
We are abysmally ignorant in many areas of fresh water ecology. The miniscule extent of our scientific knowledge of the biology of the River Murray, for example, never ceases to amaze me.
Whole groups of the freshwater fauna-if not flora-have been badly researched, and remain so.

We lack any cohesive national organisation specifically charged to undertake water resource investigations in the broad sense. We do not have, as do the South Africans, a national institute for water research, or as do the Brits-
As he puts it-
A water research centre. The Australian Water Resources Council does not fill that niche, and nor has, at least so far, CSIRO.

Australian waters are different in so many ways-physically, chemically and biologically-from those on other continents, that the results of many biological investigations undertaken elsewhere cannot be directly used by us.
Our waters are frequently more turbid, more saline and more erratic-.
Therefore, we cannot derive anything from overseas investigations because our situation is different.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not need to read it into Hansard because Professor Williams made a submission to our committee.
—I just want to emphasise these facts. The Professor said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our waters are frequently more turbid, more saline, more erratic in flow, or inhabited by animals and plants peculiar to them.

If we ask the River Murray to serve as a source of domestic water supplies, as a natural sewer and drain, and as a biological treatment mechanism for wastes discharged to it, we would be wise to attempt to define its limits to perform these tasks adequately: We would be wise to learn more of its ecology than we have.

Another major water resource problem of a general sort which at least indirectly has a biological basis is that of rising salinities in rivers. That problem is of special concern for us in Adelaide, for about two thirds of our water comes from the Murray, a river which is becoming inexorably saltier.

A key factor implicated here is irrigation. The management of irrigated crops to minimise environmental damage is scarcely a problem for aquatic biologists, but it is certainly a problem for biologists nonetheless.
He goes on to mention other matters. We might even reincorporate that report in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is already on the record.
—I shall re-read it. It might refresh your memory. Professor Williams said:

SPEECH.PARA: South Australia has become increasingly concerned at salinity levels in the River Murray-

I notice that Senator McLaren mentioned that Mr Arnold made some reference to the New South Wales Government. I think it is very proper that attention should be focused on the dangers of increasing irrigation on the banks of the Darling River, the Yanco Creek and other areas in New South Wales, and, I think, in Victoria as well. I pointed out recently that the annual average salt load entering South Australia from upstream is 1.1m tonnes a year, the ground water inflows comprise 0.25m tonnes, drainage inflows comprise 0.25m tonnes, and tributary inflows comprise 600,000 tonnes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you get those figures?

—The figures were checked from the Maunsell report. It is an important issue for South Australia. It is one with which we have to come to grips on a national basis. It is very important that the Federal, New South Wales, Victorian and South Australian governments reorganise the River Murray Waters Agreement so that the River Murray Commission can be given authority over water quality. I suggest that they go further and adopt the recommendations that the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment has made with respect to flood plain management and recreational activities. I believe these things transcend State interest, although work ought to be done in a co-operative sense with the States. Until we do so I think the progress and the development of this country will be severely retarded. I support the Address-in-Reply motion which was so capably moved by my colleague, Senator Davidson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intended to direct the main thrust of my argument to our manpower policy. This was a theme which was raised by Senator Lajovic supplemented by my illustrious South Australian colleague, Senator McLaren. Before I refer to that matter, I wish to chime in on some of the remarks of Senator Jessop. I noticed that he rightly mentioned that the salinity problem of the River Murray is a national one. I think you, Madam Acting Deputy President, would agree that one cannot help making a contrast between our policy in this matter and the adventuresome policy of the post-war Prime Minister, Ben Chifley, when he threatened to use defence powers to create the magnificent Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Scheme. In subsequent years we have created the idea that 'centralism' in government is a dirty word. We have put too much of a premium on whether people are Victorians, South Australians, New South Welshmen or people from one of the other States. This is one of the reasons disunity exists in regard to the Murray River problem. Of course it is an enormous problem. I feel that one day a Prime Minister will use defence powers as Ben Chifley threatened to do. Otherwise there will not be improvements.

SPEECH.PARA: Each time I hear honourable senators talk about States' rights I look above your head, Madam Acting Deputy President, at that emblem with the kangaroo and the emu. I like to believe that it is ours; it is not a foreign emblem. But when I hear drivel about State flags and State emblems I know that States' rights disputes retard this country.

A fortnight ago I was with a number of people at a ceremony to pay tribute to the 119 men killed on the Snowy Mountains Scheme, the vast majority of whom came here from other lands to work. I like to believe that they were not working for New South Wales, Victoria or South Australia but for Australia. I believe that on this whole Murray question, the sooner we ride roughshod over every State Premier, irrespective of his political affinities, and use defence powers the sooner we will solve this problem. In World War I and World War II-independent of the war effort-and in the immediate post-war era there were major developments. I suppose Trans-Australia Airlines would not have been established if it had not been for the high morale boosting attitude of a new nation after World War II. There is a host of other projects I could mention.

I now turn to the manpower policy. Senator Lajovic referred to various overseas trade practices, and I agree with much of what he said. As a matter of fact about four years ago a tripartite mission went overseas. In fact, I think the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Cliff Dolan, was a member. One of the places that took top honours, as he would well know, was Litostroy in Slovenia, which provides excellent training for tradesmen and has well laid out workshops-everything. I do not think we can act as if we are wearing blinkers. On the other hand, many tradesmen from overseas have credentials. I do not have a racist attitude, but I know that all honourable senators have had people from overseas making representations to them. One fellow had a diploma from New Delhi or one of the other Indian cities stating that he was a fitter and turner. I do not doubt that such a person had some fairly good technical training, but when he arrived here he was not competent to go on a workshop floor. He would not have had the necessary training.

When we talk about our apprenticeship system it must be remembered that the first man to sound the tocsin about anticipated apprenticeship loss or wastage was none other than Mr Clyde Cameron in the 1972-74 era when he first advanced the theory of giving incentives to employers to take on apprentices. In New South Wales it was usually the railways, the Broken Hill Co. Pty Ltd and Qantas Airways Ltd that provided the bulk of the apprenticeships. Other firms waited until a person became a journeyman and then grabbed him. They ought to have woken up a little earlier. Senator Lajovic referred to the particular mix that we get among apprentices and gave statistics. I concede that it must be remembered that the facts of life are such that we have a fair mix of Labor and non-Labor State governments. I suppose that the Premier of the premier State, Neville Wran, and his Minister for Industrial Relations, the Honourable P. D. Hills, have played their part in encouraging apprenticeships.

One of the problems relates to the interval between two wards. That does not apply only in Australia. Some honourable senators have heard the famous story of the town that was murdered. The author was Ellen Wilkinson, a very fine socialist member of the House of Commons. She wrote the story of the town of Jarrow, a shipyard town, in the early 1930s. It was a dead town. By 1937 when Hitlerism was on the march the authorities suddenly tried to reconstruct the city. They tried to entice boilermakers, shipwrights and fitters away from their jobs in Britain. A similar situation has occurred in Australia. Many people, including my father, who was not a craftsman but who worked in the gas industry, although they were not sacked, were rationed to work for one week in six. It is that broad panorama that I am trying to sketch tonight to show why there was so much reluctance, and rightly so, to look at the long term. When we bring in people from overseas as tradesmen we have to consider our capacity to put them all into work and keep them there for their working lives. Rightly, Australia has never had a bar of the guest worker system. The fat cat countries such as Germany and Belgium bring in foreign workers and throw them out when they no longer need them. Yet they are the same countries that requested martial aid in the early post-war years.

My colleagues Senator Tate and Senator Bishop frequently ask questions at Estimates committees as to why Australia does not have an updated computerisation system that gives a proper picture of our actual occupation needs in the various categories. In the last three days there has been a series of articles in the Australian Financial Review by Rod Wise indicating some sceptical attitudes to the broad figures that are often pulled out. I do not doubt that there will be a sort of mini-bonanza in relation to the North West Shelf, but people talk in lofty terms of employing 4,000 boilermakers and 5,000 fitters. Even if a job lasts for five years, we must return to the theme that people come here on a permanent basis. We must look forward. I do not think this Government has fully appreciated that fact.

I took representatives of the Australian Railways Union to see Michael Hodgman the other week about the extension of a long term lease on a holiday camp. We discussed the economies of union members from the western part of New South Wales having cheap holidays at Jervis Bay. In relation to costs, they pointed out to the Minister, that as a result of the new technology the number of signalmen operating from Newcastle to the Queensland border will be reduced to 10 or 12 men. The total number of members of the union will be compressed from 20,000 to 13,000. That is the general situation confronting most unions. We can be quite overcome by the prospect of job training schemes.

The same situation would apply to an olympic training squad. I suppose I am pretty close to the truth when I say that some of our athletes train assiduously for three or four years, but they did not get to the Moscow Olympic Games. I will not canvass why some went and some did not. Generally there has to be something beyond the idea of a massive retraining scheme. That is why I take the Senate beyond these dimensions. A combination of attitudes and postures are presented by Mr Viner, Mr Peacock and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street). This is why I bring him in. Whilst this is not primarily a high wage area there are 50,000 jobs on the line and we dither about our relations with all these member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations. How much are we supposed to take from these ASEAN countries in relation to clothing, textiles and tyres in order to have stable relations? Politicians, particularly members of the National Country Party, talk about the relativity of wages between tyre builders employed by the Goodyear tyre company or the Dunlop rubber company in Victoria and somebody working in Hong Kong or South Korea. People try to argue that every job in that industry is subsidised. The fact is that a person, if he is subsidised-I do not accept the idea completely-is an Australian taxpayer. That is how the revenue is returned. People talk about slicing off, giving unlimited taxation and cutting back on government grants. The fallacy in this thesis is that the people in the Welsh valleys where the steel industry was cut back have become statistics. They become people receiving unemployment relief. The relief payments rise as a result.

I refer to Milton Friedman's theories and President Reagan's policy. President Reagan is hedging already. Let us take the shipbuilding industry. It is possibly true that Poland and Japan can build ships more cheaply than any other country can. The budget of the conservative Reagan Government does not interfere with shipbuilding subsidies on the West Coast. He realises that the industry there is different from the steel industry in Wales which has not got Mrs Thatcher what she sought. In the Australian context I am worried about the cost of 50,000 or 60,000 jobs in the industry being the price for alleged stability in Asia. We talk about peace in Asia. In South Korea there was a war in the 1950s. I do not argue with the United Nations policy; it was probably correct. I do not put South Korea in the same category as Vietnam. It is a different ball game. What have we got out of the Korean War? Can anybody tell me that there is more democracy in South Korea than there is in North Korea? We send aid to those people and what do we see for it? Some people say: 'Look at the communists. What are they doing to the clergymen of all beliefs?' The clergymen tell the worker on the workshop floor of the textile industry in Korea that he has been exploited, and he has. If he is not born in Korea he is deported. Can anyone tell me that the so-called parliamentary democracy in Pakistan, where Opposition leaders are gunned down, is any different from any country that has a totalitarian policy leaning to the Left?

As fare as foreign relations are concerned, Australia is so easy going in relation to United Nations relief. I make no apology for saying that countries of that character would receive no relief at all from me. I suppose that as Australians we are proud of the fact that we pay our dues to the United Nations. There has been a botch job. I have before me an article from the London Guardian by Victoria Brittain in Nairobi. She reports on the situation in Uganda where there has been a complete botch between the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and kindred organisations on logistics and their inability to provide lorries to take food to Nairobi. There has been too much of this sort of thing. There was another scandal in Cambodia. I just wonder whether our foreign affairs people who attend meetings of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and auxiliary bodies that deal with food supplies ever ask any questions about what rorts are going on.

The United States voiced a grievance at the International Labor Organisation-I did not agree with its action in any way-and did not pay any subscriptions for a few years. I wonder whether we should not do the same in relation to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. I say this for a different reason. About 12 months ago I had occasion at a seminar to talk to a Brazilian who was here as a representative of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. He was justifying to me why we had a prime responsibility to take refugees from South East Asia-the Vietnamese and other people. He said that there was no need for us to worry about Latin America. Then he said to me: 'Anyway, many of those Latin Americans are disgruntled trade unionists'. If ever a man had an ideological bias, he did. He was well paid for that job.

I can never get any worthwhile information in this area. With the change to our Estimates committees I will be awaiting with glee-and rolling up my sleeves-an opportunity to grill the Foreign Affairs people as to why we are so gutless when dealing with foreign aid.
