It is time we were a little more even-handed. We should reward our friends and punish our enemies, and I say that in the diplomatic sense. I am talking about some of these fascit and neo-fascist countries that we never admonish. Before Christmas my colleagues Senator Evans and Senator Chipp asked a series of questions in this respect, and I marry that matter to Senator McLaren's asking whether we should have admonished the Soviet Ambassador. Whether we did right or wrong in that respect, I do not know of any occasions when we ever took up with the various Latin American ambassadors. I speak with some feeling on that.

Two years ago there was the case of Anna Maria Mohaded who was in a penitentiary in Cordoba in Argentina. I took her sister to see the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs about this matter and, to the credit of the Government, we were told we would give her political asylum. Andrew Peacock said 'Talk to the ambassador', and I saw him. I did not go the Press. It was a reasonable approach. He said: 'Oh yes, you have made out a good case', and she was let out. She had 48 hours to get out of the country. After 46 hours, just as she had her bags packed, they took her off to gaol again. People can talk to me about those sorts of cat and mouse techniques practised by fascist countries or about Stalinism at its worst, but when we get down to the lowest common denominator, and if there is an infringement of liberty, is there any difference between those fascist countries in Latin America and some of those countries which are fairly much dominated by the Moscow line? Our Foreign Affairs people have double standards, and those are epitomised by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). He never takes on these people. Frankly, we could be militant with them because our trade with them does not mean anything. Senator McLaren made a point about trade in other areas, and I suppose that we have to pull our punches to some degree.

There is no question that our manpower policy is a very vital one. What hope is there for teenagers today in so many areas? Leaving aside the question of apprentices, the great danger is that in instrumentalities such as Telecom Australia or Australia Post fewer people are needed each year to fill semi-skilled grades because of new equipment which is brought in. I know that some people hope that by 1984-I am not thinking in terms of George Orwell's Nineteen Eighty-four-the number of school leavers will rapidly drop. But the working life is usually from age 20 to 60.

This brings me to a final tapering-off point. This Government has had a bit of a brawl with the Public Service unions about the right to retire at age 55. This Government has done a lot of exercises about our work force, but if it wants stability and wage agreements with the trade union movement there are many things it can learn from Europe, about which Senator Lajovic spoke. One of those things is that European workers have more stable health coverage schemes. Of course, I know that they are paid for by some form of tax. But if the workers of Australia knew that they were to pay 1.35 per cent-I just pluck that figure out of the air-of their annual incomes on health coverage, at least the process worker would not be paying the same amount as the production manager. The great rub today is that even if people get a wage rise of $10 or $15, every six months there is a dramatic rise in contributions to all the health funds. There is no reason why that component of the basic wage could not be stabilised, because people would pay that 1.35 per cent of their taxes every 12 months and would not have to pay a weekly slug. There would be a better understanding with the trade union movement. I hark back to what Senator Lajovic said: Right across Europe and Britain stabilised health coverage schemes are a vital factor in wages policy.

I come back to the dispute between the Government and the Public Service about possible retirements at age 55. Nobody has said what the bill would be as a result of earlier eligibility for the age pension of people who retire at 59 so that the slack can be taken up by younger people. I do not know the figure, but the Government has never come up with a figure in that respect. Another matter I wish to raise is the whole question of the 35-hour week. The 40-hour week came in only 1947, and 1947 to 1980 is a long span of years. We all see documentaries and read publications about all the technological changes that have happened in the interim. We can see the work that is done today by a forklift truck in a wool store. Previously that work would have been done by a group of storemen and packers. Yet the Government keeps resisting. It talks about trade unions and Luddites. Members of the Government know in their hearts that such agreements will come about when people get over the fear of the 40-hour week. They will probably work a nine day fortnight. It will not be the end of the world. I concede the point about productivity, and nobody runs away from that question. But I like to believe that promises will be kept.

I do not want to go over the past, but in this place there used to be a very aggressive honourable senator from Tasmania-Senator Wright. It used to be an annual thing for him to abuse the Waterside Workers Federation. His main enemy was Charlie FitzGibbon. Senator Elstob, who used to work in the industry, would know that Charlie FitzGibbon was a very long-serving official of that union. When the waterside workers struck agreements in relation to apples and perishable cargoes in Tasmania, of course they got a reasonable agreement; the union kept its word. But Senator Wright could not see that. If an agreement was offered to unions which had officials of the calibre of Charlie FitzGibbon, they delivered the goods. If we are to get this across-the-board respect, the employers must show manifestly that technical changes mean benefit to people in the workforce. Of course, it will be a race against time as to whether the lower birthrate after 1984 will make all those situations null and void. I cite the tragic example of a woman over age 35 in the non-trades section of the printing union who operates a small guillotine. She cuts up small pages of books and stacks them. I am aware of instances of a boss looking upon such women, when they get into their 40s, as though they are stock. If she has a few varicose veins on the calves of her legs she does not get re-employed in a few months time. When one talks to some employers they will say that when they go to the Mount Madeline administrative college to learn how to be a good manager and personnel officer they get points for showing how such people can be culled out. That may be a cruel assessment. I am not harking back to Jack London and the Chicago stockyards, but it is a highly competitive field. If we are to improve industrial relations we have to get incentive from the top.

I feel, first of all, that with the money we spend for defence purposes-and I am not completely against that-we should emulate Sweden and have a modern computer system which will tell us accurately what our labour demands will be. Secondly, if we want industrial peace we must have a good hard look at health coverage being a vital component of our wage structure. Thirdly, we can urge some employers to do a little more in relation to apprentices generally. In relation to our immigration policy, I simply say this: A component of overseas tradesmen will be needed but they will have to be people who meet reasonable conditions and not people from the bogus training colleges that I mentioned. Finally, of course, we must not bring people here as chattels which is what guest workers in the fat cat EEC countries are. I leave for the Government that wisdom which is embodied in the amendment which has been moved by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the amendment to the Address-in-Reply moved on 25 February by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Button. Senator Button speaks so well that I enjoy his speeches. He has a dexterous use of the language and a wry sense of humour and, as I say, I always enjoy listening to him. But, unfortunately, in his speech on 25 February he saw fit to, shall I say, regurgitate a number of Labor dogmas and shibboleths which, I think, it is about time were put to rest. So, I must respond to his speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button, in his speech, attacked a speech delivered by Senator Fred Chaney on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in Adelaide on 5 December of last year. The subject of that speech was 'Liberalism, The Philosophy that Shapes Government Policies and Actions'. Senator Button took that speech and, with his usual marvellous ability to speak, tried to pull it to pieces. His language was delightful but it was full of exaggeration, drew illogical conclusions and, in many respects, had all the hallmarks of the socialist left for whom, on that occasion, he appeared to be the reluctant spokesman. He said of the principle in the Prime Minister's speech:
I have a lot of agreement with the principle. I think it is a very sound one . . .
He then went on to say:
. . . it is absolute hogwash to say that this Government was bent in any real way on carrying out that principle in its legislation.

That accusation is totally untrue. The Liberal Party will continue to develop its policies based on that philosophy of liberalism. I think Senator Button knows that but perhaps he has been forced to lay a trail of red herrings in order to obscure the real issues of the Governor-General's Speech and Senator Button's amendment, both of which involve economic policy rather than the shibboleths to which he was referring.

Senator Button questioned the claim of the Prime Minister that 'private enterprise is responsible for unprecedented improvements in human conditions over the last 30 years'. He said that that proposition would be difficult to sell in the People's Republic of China. I agree with Senator Button that there has been considerable progress in China. Much has been done and certainly many of the ills of that nation have been overcome by its present Government. One must admire the changes which it has managed to make. But what of the human tragedy and the waste of the Cultural Revolution? Let us look at the growth of Taiwan which is inhabited by an equally industrious people of the same race. In Taiwan, under the free enterprise system, income per head of population increased from $US1,421 in 1978 to $US2,100 in 1980-a rise of 48 per cent in two years. However, in Communist China it is expected that it will take another 20 years before the per capita income rises to half that amount-to $US1,000 per person per annum.

Let us look at the communist system of the Soviet Union. It has failed to provide any comparable standards of living for either its own nationals or for people in those countries under its protection. Let us look at the standard of living in Poland. Apparently its standard of living is better than that of the Soviet Union but its citizens are still required to queue for basic foods such as bread and meat. Its economic policies have resulted in massive foreign debts that have required a moratorium-in other words, there is national bankruptcy. I refer to an article in the Canberra Times of Friday, 27 February of this year by Gay Davidson, not a supporter of this Government. Accompanying the article is a photograph showing Polish women queuing for food in Warsaw. Under the photograph, there are these words:

. . . in the opinion of one Western diplomat the Poles do not really appreciate that, in order to pull the country out of its economic difficulties, 'they must accept a reduction in their living standards, which are certainly higher in Warsaw than in Moscow'.
Senator Button said of the Prime Minister's speech:
There are thinly veiled references to the grey socialist societies of the Northern Hemisphere.
Later, he said:
. . . the social democratic societies of the Western world are completely ignored.

I ask: Is it appropriate in a speech or document dealing with liberal philosophy to argue the merits or otherwise of social systems? Of course it is not. Senator Button raised the red herring of Sweden. Senator Mulvihill also raised the question of Sweden in his speech tonight. It has become dogma for the socialists of Australia to tell us what a great country Sweden is, so I think it is time that we had a good look at Sweden. I will not talk about the matters Senator Button raised as an aside to Senator Puplick about the suicides and the problems in the social sphere in Sweden brought about by Sweden's policies; I will just look at the economic situation in Sweden because the socialists keep pouring Sweden down our throats. I think it is about time the rose tinted glasses were removed so that we can see what a disaster has been the Swedish socialist laboratory of the 1970s.

What is happening in Sweden at present? Income tax is running so high that further increases would raise no extra revenue, but just push the economy backwards. Government spending has been rising by 6 per cent to 7 per cent per annum in real terms for most of the decade, pushing the Government's share of the economy from 43 per cent in 1970 to 66 per cent in 1979. Sweden's Budget deficit for 1980-81 was equivalent to $A12 billion or 11 per cent of national output. Even in Mr Whitlam's most extravagant years Australia's deficit did not exceed more than about 5 per cent of national output. The low productivity performance of Swedish industry has been exacerbated by labour support schemes. Sweden's much vaunted industrial policies have put on to government subsidised jobs three workers for each two workers officially counted as unemployed, thus keeping unemployment figures at an apparently artificial figure of 2.1 per cent.

Sweden's doomed shipbuilding industry has been gobbled up by costs of $A80,000 per employee. Morale is sagging in the Swedish work force, which is plagued by absenteeism. Industry still has not digested the 21 per cent real wage rise of the 1975-76 period. The private sector as a whole has been suffering losses since 1973 after allowing for the inflationary effects, with shareholders getting a negative return for their investments since 1974. Between 1970 and 1978 public employment rose by 414,000 compared with an increase in totat employment of only 261,000, implying a net fall in private employment of 153,000 people.

I think it is about time that some publicity is given to these figures so that these people, these socialists, who keep throwing at us this 'great economy of Sweden' can have a look at the facts. What in fact has happened to the Swedish economy? It is simply that the socialist policy makers failed to realise and recognise the fact that there are no free lunches in the economy. They failed to recognise the implications of the energy crisis and by increased deficit budgeting back in the early 1970s they in fact slowed up the adjustment process and they sucked into the public sector the resources of the nation that could and should have been used in the adjustment of the private sector. The growth in the size of the Budget deficit, the associated acceleration in inflation, a large current account deficit and private capital outflow are now major problems. Economists both inside and outside Sweden agree that to retrieve the economic situation there should be a reduction in private and public consumption.

I notice that Senator Button has left the chamber because he does not want to hear the facts about Sweden. Simply put, the people of Sweden got used to handouts. They got used to industry being propped up by the Government and they got used to the nation living beyond its means. No government can go on spending more than its revenue. It is like entering into an overly expensive hire purchase agreement. I notice that Senator Button has returned to the Senate. He may have had a legitimate cause for moving out of the chamber; I do not doubt that. As I said, no government can go on spending more than its revenue. It is like entering into an overly expensive hire purchase agreement. Payments cannot be maintained and the goods are repossessed. The great socialist laboratory of Sweden is in the process of collapsing. Britain went down a similar path--

TALK.START.PARA: —Under a conservative Government, of course.
—I will come to that.
—And still has the highest standard of living in the world.
—Not at all.
—Yes it has.

—It has fallen to pieces. Britain went down a similar path with a similar philosophy and that nation, once the world's greatest trading nation, is now reeling under the excesses of the social democratic system. Britain has an ailing motor industry losing about $A2m a day, and uncompetitive nationalised coal and steel industries that are neither economic nor competitive. Fortunately both countries now have governments that have been given the task, as we were in 1975, of trying to repair the damage done by the thoroughly discredited economic philosophy of social democracy. Yet Senator Button criticised the Prime Minister for not comparing Australia with Sweden. We are so far ahead that there is just no comparison. What better case could be put for the Liberal principle than the following quotation:

SPEECH.PARA: It rejects the notion that the relationship between the people and the State should be like that between customers and the supermarket-that because something is considered desirable it should be assumed automatically that the States should provide it.

The Government rejects that notion for two reasons: First, the State is likely to be in many ways an inefficient and wasteful provider and because many services can be better provided in other ways-by voluntary action on the part of individuals joining together freely, and by mechanism of the market.
Second, and fundamentally, the more you ask of the State, the more power you must give it. If your demands on it are unlimited then you must logically give it unlimited power.

I do not understand why a person who believes in freedom, as Senator Button professes that he does, should also follow a philosophy which gives to the state more and more power. Surely he must realise that the more power given to the state the more freedom is taken away from the people. Many years ago President Woodrow Wilson said:
Liberty has never come from the Government . . . The history of liberty is the history of the limitation of governmental power, not the increase of it.

I am sure that Senator Button is well aware of the history of the free movements throughout the world being the limitation of governmental power. If he cares to look at the history of the Soviet Union he will see that with unlimited power, freedom is taken away from the people. I do not understand how philosophically he can reconcile his desire for freedom for the people with an increase in the power of the government because an increase in power must reduce the people's freedom. The Prime Minister's speech also stated:

It follows that as part of its liberalism, the Government is fundamentally committed to a private enterprise system . . . a system which, while recognising the necessity for restraint and a degree of government intervention, is premised on the belief that what produces the best economic and political results is an economy based on private property and income, in which normal economic activity consists of commercial transactions voluntarily entered into by individuals and groups.

By abolishing the handout syndrome and paying our way, Australia is again becoming prosperous. The December 1980 edition of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development publication Economic Outlook, in relation to Australia, said:

. . . the forecast is dominated by strong growth in business investment associated with the development of resource-based industries. This in turn is expected to lead to a strengthening of employment, personal incomes and private consumption. In total, GDP-
That is, the gross domestic product-
Is expected to accelerate from 2 1/4 per cent in 1980 to around 4 per cent in 1981. The unemployment rate is expected to fall, unlike that of most other countries.
Compare that statement with the views of the OECD on Sweden. It said:

During the second half of 1980 private domestic demand and exports recovered from the effects of earlier strikes, but thereafter the prospects are for a substantial weakening of the economy. The inflation outlook is unfavourable, even though external cost pressures are forecast to ease substantially. Sweden's competitive position is likely to deteriorate.

Clearly, Sweden has failed to control inflation. After all, how could it control inflation with a budgeted deficit of $12 billion? If you keep on spending more money than you have got, if you keep on spending more money than you collect in revenue you must go bankrupt. New York went bankrupt when it spent more money than it received in revenue. It kept spending money it did not have and it kept trying to borrow money to meet future bills. It ended up borrowing money to meet the interest charges on the money which it had borrowed. Unfortunately governments are able to print money. Therefore, their bankruptcy is not so obvious. But if governments go on budgeting for deficits of the like of $12 billion inevitably they will go bankrupt. That is the sort of policy that these people in the Opposition promote to us all of the time. All that the Leader of the Opposition in the other House, Mr Hayden, could say about the last Budget Speech was: 'Well, the Government's policy was not too bad, but if I had been the Prime Minister I would have increased the budgeted deficit'. As I have said, all that does is to lead to inflation, unemployment and the destruction of the economy.

In Australia the consumer price index increased by only 2.1 per cent for December 1980 and by 9.3 per cent for the year-a significant achievement. There was an increase of 169,600 in the number of employed people over the 12 months to December 1980 and employment growth remained strong. Both retail sales and new passenger vehicle registrations showed strong growth in the December 1980 quarter; private dwelling approvals rose further and the combination of a steady current account deficit and stronger private capital inflow resulted in an overall balance of payments surplus of $288m in January this year. These figures speak for themselves. They demonstrate the wisdom of not adopting stop-gap solutions that have been suggested by the Australian Labor Party which only add to inflationary pressures. Certainly I do not deny that unemployment remains Australia's greatest single social problem but it will not be overcome by deficit budgeting; on the contrary that will increase it. All the evidence overseas points to the soundness of the Government's present policies developed from Liberal philosophy. The Liberal philosophy is summarised by the Prime Minister in that speech which was so criticised by Senator Button. He said:

The Government is concerned to maximise the degree to which people have control over their own lives and their own resources, to ensure that it is their choices which are decisive, not those of politicians, of bureaucrats or union officials or corporations.

The Government is concerned to limit the role and reduce the power of the state, and as part of that to restrain taxes and to contain public expenditure. The state must remain the servant, not the master, of the Australian people.

One could only wish that the Opposition would look at some of the facts instead of regurgitating knee-jerk dogmas. For example, Senator Button criticised my colleague Senator Jessop for his admiration of the United States. That is a typical knee-jerk reaction if ever I have heard one. The simple truth is that the free enterprise system of the United States has produced the highest material levels of living ever known in any nation of the world and it keeps doubling those levels every 40 years. That is a fact which cannot be denied. I ask honourable senators to compare that with the communist systems of the world and the social democratic systems of the world and to acknowledge that there is nothing to compare with the United States and its free enterprise system.

I am glad that my other Victorian colleague in the Opposition, Senator Evans, has been so involved with his party in trying to discover a new philosophy for the Australian Labor Party because clearly the principles of socialism have, in fact, defeated themselves. I commend to Senator Button and to Senator Evans the principles of liberalism so ably expounded by the Prime Minister. I oppose the amendment moved by Senator Button and support the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented. I was misrepresented about 400 times by Senator Lewis in the course of his speech but there is a particular misrepresentation to which I wish to refer. Senator Lewis, early in his speech, having insufficient capacity to read Hansard lucidly apparently, said that I had, in the course of a speech made last week, said that I approved the principle of Mr Fraser' speech. What I in fact said was that I approved, in that speech, the enunciation of what was described as the principle of conservatism. That is a very different thing from saying that I approved the principle of the speech. I approved the principle of conservatism and I then went on to point our how the principle of conservatism, described as it was as a principle of order and continuity, had at no time been applied by this Fraser Government. I single that out as the most vivid misrepresentation in Senator Lewis's speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address myself to the Address-in-Reply-I have not spoken to it before-and to support the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Button). In my comments as usual I will stress those aspects of the Governor-General's speech which had particular reference to the Northern Territory. Speaking of the Government's foreign policy, the Governor-General said:

SPEECH.PARA: The foreign policy priorities of my Government are clear. It is very conscious of the need for a strong and united Western stance towards the Soviet Union and to this end it will work to maintain its already strong ties with its traditional allies, and in particular with the United States. It should be clearly understood that it will do so out of an appreciation of Australia's needs and interests and for no other reason.

The maintenance of this strong tie has particular relevance to the Northern Territory. Firstly, it means that we will allow Pine Gap-that is the Joint Defence Space Research Facility-to continue to operate. That is the first obvious corollary to the maintenance of these strong ties. We will allow it to continue even though we know that the Joint Defence Space Research Facility is controlled by the Central Intelligence Agency. This is despite the rather surprised stance taken by Senator Carrick recently. It is common knowledge that this is so and it appears in published documents. It also means that we will support and allow Pine Gap to continue although the Government is not aware of its real purpose. I quote from a book written by Ball. At page 22 it states:

More directly, three of Australia's last four Prime Ministers-the only ones to address the issue-have specifically stated that, at the least, they were ignorant of major aspects of the operations of the satellite ground stations in central Australia. In December 1978, John Gorton stated: 'I don't even know what Pine Gap is all about. I didn't then (1969). I could have asked but it didn't arise. I didn't ask about it'. In May 1977, William McMahon stated that although he thought he knew the true functions of Pine Gap and Nurrungar at the time he was Prime Minister, he was not now so sure: 'I have increasing doubts that the Australian Government knows the entire truth'. And Whitlam has revealed on a number of occasions that there were several critical aspects relating to Pine Gap and Nurrungar that he was never told about.
We will allow Pine Gap to continue operating and will support it although we know that private information gathered by it is given to the United States commercial organisations. Ball continues:
Whitlam told parliament on 4 May 1977 that the Australian government had been unaware-
I quote from Hansard:

that the information obtained by these facilities would be shared with, or made available to, private corporations (under CIA contract) such as TRW Systems Incorporated. Knowledge of that company's access to this information has emerged quite fortuitously because one of its employees has been convicted of espionage. What other contractors to the CIA, who may or may not employ Russian spies, are privileged to receive/analyse and transmit data from facilities on Australian soil?
That is the end of the quote taken from Hansard. Ball continues:

Whitlam had not even been told that the American officer-in-charge of Pine Gap, Richard Stallings, was an employee of the CIA, or that Pine Gap was in fact a CIA operation. Certainly the United States has not kept Australia informed about all activities at these and some of the other installations.

We are going to allow Pine Gap to continue even though the activities there make it a prime nuclear target in the event of any conflict between the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. This maintenance of strong ties also means that we will be offering Darwin as a stop-over base for B52s. There has been a good deal of opposition to the establishment of a stop-over base for B52s. Again, it will make Darwin a prime target. That means that the two major centres of the Northern Territory, Alice Springs and Darwin, will be prime targets.

The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) this morning addressed himself to comments made by the Soviet Ambassador. Let us recall that the Soviet Ambassador warned that Australia could become a nuclear target because of its close friendship with the United States. Dr Soudarikov said that the decision to upgrade United States bases and to allow B52s to pass through Australia could make Australia a target in any nuclear war. I have further objections to the basing of the B52s there. I will run through these fairly quickly. The first is the possibility of an accident if nuclear weapons are carried. The other objection is that it ties us into American policy and removes our independence. Let us look at each of those in turn. Let us firstly consider the prime target aspect. If Darwin becomes a fuelling place for B52s then Darwin would obviously be knocked out in any conflict between the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

Let us look at the scenario for the possible use of B52s. They are based in Guam. They would leave from there, go to Diego Garcia and pick up their warheads and then go on to Darwin to refuel. Then, because the line is direct, they would move to the Middle East. That is the scenario if there is a conflict. It is quite clear that one does not have to know a great deal about foreign policy to see that that will be the area of conflict should there be conflict between the two major powers in the next few years. Let me remind honourable senators of what Mr Bowen said in the other place. He said:

Far from being delighted all Australians should be alarmed that the Prime Minister intends to allow Americans to use Australia for a base for their B52 bombers. B52s carry nuclear weapons and if B52s are based in Australia these bases will be certain nuclear targets. This will be the first time that nuclear weapons will be stationed on Australian soil.

The proposals . . . pose the same sort of risk to Australia's capacity for independent action and control over its foreign policy as the earlier request this year by the United States that Australia should provide troops for a rapid deployment force intended to operate in the Middle East oil fields.

Some Government members who have spoken on this matter outside the chamber and made public statements have said that everything will be okay as long as the B52s are not carrying nuclear warheads; of course we will know this because the United States will tell us. This is naive in the extreme. Firstly, of course, the B52s will carry nuclear warheads. They are designed to carry them. They are too expensive to use as surveillance aircraft alone. Let us be quite honest: We cannot trust the United States to tell us what it will do. It did not tell Whitlam in 1973 when all the bases in Australia were put on red alert. It made no comment to the Prime Minister of Australia that all the American bases in Australia had been put on their final alert. The United States deluded successive Australian governments over Pine Gap, North West Cape and other bases in Australia. I have already made some reference to this matter which was mentioned in Ball, and there is ample evidence elsewhere.

The other point that concerns me particularly relates to the sort of people who are now in the White House and who are advising people in the White House. I do not believe we can rely on those people to exercise a good deal of caution. Honourable senators will remember that Haig, when he was in front of a Senate committee-this is the man who is now Secretary of State-said to the Senate committee that it was not immoral to have bombed Cambodia for five years without telling the legislature. He felt that there was no necessity for him, as a General, to tell the legislature that for five years America had been bombing Cambodia. If he will not tell his own legislature what he is doing he is certainly not likely to tell us. This man is now Secretary of State to Ronald Reagan. This same man blew his cool in front of a Senate committee because the questions became a bit hot. I challenge whether he or the President of the United States at present would not plunge us by this sort of action into a conflict in which we should not be involved.

The second area I wanted to mention was the possibility of accident. We know that nuclear accidents are referred to as broken arrows. Although the details of any of these incidents or accidents are obscured we have some detail-not a great deal because the United States policy is that it will neither confirm nor deny accidents or broken arrows. Let me give a few examples. Firstly, in January 1961 a B52 dropped a 24-megaton bomb in North Carolina. When this 24-megaton bomb was found, five of the six safety catches had been triggered off. There was one left. Had that safety catch been triggered off the whole city of Goldsboro would have been wiped out. Five of the six safety catches had gone and it was purely by chance that the last one had not been activated. In January 1966 a B52 and a refuelling tanker collided in Spain. The B52 crashed and four bombs separated. The first one landed inactive in a river bed. The second and third released radioactive material in a populated area. The fourth was retrieved from the sea after an intensive search lasting for three months.

In January 1968 a B52 crashed in Greenland and all the four bombs on board were lost under the ice. To the best of our knowledge, they are still there. In September 1980 a B52 caught fire. This matter has already been mentioned in this place. The bombs did not detonate, but there was a good deal of concern that they would. Nobody knew whether the bombs would actually detonate with the heat of a fire of the character which would be produced when a B52 crashed. We can do without these sorts of incidents. I have a deal more to say, but as it is 10.15 p.m. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BOUNTY (POLYESTER-COTTON YARN) AMENDMENT BILL 1981BOUNTY (NON-ADJUSTABLE WRENCHES) BILL 1981COAL EXCISE AMENDMENT BILL 1981

Motion (by Senator Peter Baume) agreed to:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the questions with regard to the several stages for the passage through the Senate of the Bills being put in one motion at each stage and the consideration of such Bills together in the Committee of the Whole.

Second Readings

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
Bounty (Polyester-Cotton Yarn) Amendment Bill 1981

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the Government's decision to extend the operation of the Bounty (Polyester-Cotton Yarn) Act 1978 until 31 December 1981. The existing Act expires on 31 August 1981. The Bounty (Polyester-Cotton Yarn) Act 1978 provides assistance to the manufacture in Australia of polyester-cotton yarn by means of a bounty scheme. This scheme provides for the payment to eligible manufacturers of a bounty of $1.15 per kilogram on the bountiable yarn which during the period to which the Act applies, is spun at registered premises for use in the knitting or weaving of textiles in Australia. There is a current annual limit of $600,000 on the amount available for payment of bounty.

The extension of the operation of this scheme is being made as an interim measure pending commencement on 1 January 1982 of new bounty arrangements for polyester cotton yarns. The new arrangements form part of the Government's proposed program of assistance for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries beyond 1981. From 1 January 1982 the bounty rate for polyester-cotton yarns will be calculated as 52 per cent of factory cost value added. The amount available for payment of bounty during the extended period of the current scheme will be $200,000. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Bounty (Non-Adjustable Wrenches) Bill 1981

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the Government's decision to provide temporary assistance to the industry in Australia producing non-adjustable wrenches. This assistance arrangement follows the Government's consideration of the advice and recommendations by the Temporary Assistance Authority contained in its report No. 50 of 14 August 1980 entitled: 'Non-Adjustable Spanners'. The Government has accepted the Temporary Assistance Authority's recommendation that temporary assistance, in the form of a production bounty, be accorded to this industry in Australia. The Bill provides for the bounty to be payable at the rate of 11c on each bountiable implement having a local content exceeding 50 per cent. This scheme is to operate for a period of one year and bounty payments during that period are limited to a maximum of $620,000.

During its inquiry the Temporary Assistance Authority found that the local industry's overall activity has declined over the past four or five years while imports of competing products had increased. In the past three years the total domestic market share held by the major Australian manufacturer Siddons Industries Ltd, has declined from 25 per cent to 16 per cent. However in this same period the local market for the tools increased from 16.5 million to 20 million units and imports also increased from 12.5 million to 16 million units. In recommending the bounty assistance for this industry the Temporary Assistance Authority was concerned to ensure that the assistance provided will have an immediate effect but will only affect those areas of the market supplied by the local industry. The Government expects that the assistance as proposed by this Bill will restore previous activity levels and thus enable the local industry to more adequately compete against the imported products. An assessment of the need for the continuation of the bounty assistance beyond 12 months will be undertaken by the Industries Assistance Commission as part of its report on cutlery, industrial knives and hand tools due to be submitted to the Government by 30 June 1981. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Coal Excise Amendment Bill 1981

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Coal Excise Act 1949. The proposed amendment will extend to 28 days the period within which entries of home consumption may be made for coal removed from a coal mine during a period approved by a collector of customs. The Coal Excise Act 1949 contains the machinery provisions to enforce the collection of excise duties imposed on coal for the purposes of financing long service leave benefits granted to certain employees in the coal mining industry and for the funding of the Coal Research Trust Account.

Section 24 (2) of this Act permits coal to be removed from a coal mine during a period, usually a calendar month, approved by a collector of customs without entry if a deposit of money or a guarantee in respect of the duty on the coal has been given by the coal producer. However, section 24 (4) requires that an entry in respect of coal removed from a coal mine during the approved period shall be made not later than seven working days after the expiration of that period. The Government has decided to extend this period to 28 days as seven days has proven to be unnecessarily restrictive. This is particularly so in cases where coal producers do not possess their own weighing facilities and need to obtain production figures from accumulated weighbridge certificates issued by State railway authorities. Unavoidable delays also occur when centralised payments of duty are made by parent companies which have widespread subsidiary collieries. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the Currency Act 1965 to empower the Treasurer to issue a $10 silver coin. On 2 May 1980, the then Acting Treasurer announced that the Government had decided to issue three coins with special designs to commemorate the occasion of the XII Commonwealth Games to be held in Brisbane in 1982. He further stated that the 1982 commemorative coins would be a $200 face value 'collector' gold coin, a 50 cent cupro-nickel coin, and, subject to the passage of the necessary authorising legislation, a $10 cupro-nickel coin.

It has now been decided that the proposed $10 Commonwealth Games coin be struck in 92.5 per cent silver, that is, sterling silver. The Commonwealth Games Foundation had originally proposed that the $10 coin be in silver. At the time the very high and volatile price of silver suggested that a $10 silver coin would not be practicable and it was then proposed that the coin be in cupro-nickel. Since the announcement last May, the extreme speculative influences on the price of silver have been removed. In addition, the practice has been established with the $200 collector gold coin of setting the price of a collector coin well above its face value. It is intended that this practice will be followed in the case of the silver coin. It is envisaged that the $10 silver coin will have a diameter of about 34 millimetres-that is, slightly larger than the 50 cent coin-and that it will weigh about 20 grams.

If the Bill is enacted in the current sittings of Parliament, it is expected that the Royal Australian Mint will commence minting the $10 Commonwealth Games coin in the second half of this year. The special designs for the reverse sides of the Commonwealth Games coins have not yet been selected. Further details of these coins, including arrangements for their release, will be announced at a later date. In view of the ever-present legislative burden on Parliament, the opportunity is also being taken to provide in this Bill for greater flexibility in the types of coins that can be issued in the future without the need for additional legislation. Accordingly, the Bill provides for the issue of new denominations of coins and their standard compositions to be prescribed by regulation and will authorise the Treasurer of the day to cause any such coins to be made and issued. These amendments do not, of course, affect the Parliament's power to veto any such regulations that may be brought forward.

I now outline the main provisions of the Bill. Clauses 3 and 4 of the Bill will amend sections 13 and 14 of the Currency Act to provide for the composition of existing coins to be varied by regulation and for the denominations and composition of new coins to be prescribed by regulation. At present the denominations and standard compositions of coins are specified in the Act. These amendments will avoid the need to amend the Act each time a new denomination of coin is to be introduced or the composition of an existing coin is to be varied.

Clause 5 will amend section 14A of the Act to allow the issue price of the proposed $10 coin, that is to be issued in the first instance as a silver commemorative coin for the 1982 Commonwealth Games to be determined by the Treasurer in the same way as he is at present authorised to determine the issue price for gold coins. Because of the potential volatility in the price of silver and production and marketing factors it is not practicable to set in advance of the legislation the price at which the $10 coin is to be issued. For similar reasons, this amendment will also empower the Treasurer to determine the issue price of any new coins of a denomination exceeding $10 that may be prescribed.

Section 16 of the present Act provides that the tender of coins up to certain values is a legal tender in discharge of a debt. Clause 6 will amend that section to place a limit of $100 on the legal tendering of coins of the proposed denomination of $10 and, in the case of any new coin of a denomination exceeding 50c but under $10, a limit of 10 times the face value of the coin. Any new coin of a denomination exceeding $10 will be a legal tender for payment of any amount. This clause complements the proposed amendment of section 14 by providing for appropriate legal tender values to be accorded coins of any new denomination that may be prescribed by regulation without the need for a further amendment of the Act. Clause 7 will amend the schedule to the principal Act to provide for the introduction of the $10 coin and to specify its standard composition as 92.5 per cent silver and 7.5 per cent other metal. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Dairying Research Act 1972 in recognition of changing circumstances in the dairy industry and to conform with current practice in other similar rural research legislation. The Dairying Research Act established the Dairying Research Trust Account and the Dairying Research Committee. The Research Account receives income from the industry research levy, Commonwealth Government matching contributions and other minor sources. Expenditure on research is approved by the Minister on the recommendation of the Research Committee.

Three of the amendments proposed in the Bill have been sought by the Dairying Research Committee and the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation. These changes are expressed in clauses 5 and 6 of the Bill. The Dairying Research Committee is frequently referred to by name in international journals and research papers. Renaming it as the Australian Dairy Research Committee will clearly establish its national identity.

At present three members of the Research Committee represent producers of milk for manufacturing purposes and one member represents producers for the liquid milk market. In view of changed circumstances in the industry this distinction is no longer appropriate and the Bill provides for the four producer members to represent all dairy farmers. To allow casual vacancies on the Research Committee to be filled for the remainder of the term of the member being replaced, the mandatory three year term will be changed to a period not exceeding three years. Further consequential amendments are necessary to accommodate these changes. Clause 12 provides for transitional arrangements in respect of the renamed Research Committee and its members and their deputies. Clause 11 will amend the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Act 1972 to reflect the change in the Research Committee's name.

Other amendments have been drafted to bring the Dairying Research Act into conformity with recent rural research legislation and government policy. Clause 3 will have the effect of bringing the wording of the provisions for payments into the Research Account into line with similar recent legislation. The original intent of the Act is not changed.

In accordance with established practice clause 7 amends the arrangements for removal and resignation of Committee members and deputies, while clause 9 provides for the Remuneration Tribunal to determine the remuneration of members and deputies. Clause 10 will enable the Minister to approve fees, et cetera, payable to persons appointed to advise the Committee. Finally clause 8 of the Bill introduces the requirement that Research Committee members and their deputies shall disclose direct or indirect pecuniary interests. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DRIED VINE FRUITS STABILIZATION LEGISLATION REPEAL BILL 1981APPLE AND PEAR EXPORT UNDERWRITING BILL 1981APPLE AND PEAR STABILIZATION AMENDMENT BILL 1981AUSTRALIAN APPLE AND PEAR CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Peter Baume) agreed to:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the questions with regard to the several stages for the passage through the Senate of the Bills being put in one motion at each stage and the consideration of such Bills together in the Committee of the Whole.
Ordered that the Bills may be taken through all their stages without delay.
Bills (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) read a first time.
Second Readings

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
Dried Vine Fruits Stabilization Legislation Repeal Bill 1981

The purpose of this Bill is to terminate the operation of the present Dried Vine Fruits Stabilisation Scheme. The scheme, which applies to dried sultanas produced in the three seasons 1978, 1979 and 1980, provides for grower contributions to a stabilisation fund if the average return received by growers in a season is above the established seasonal base price plus $10 a tonne. If the average return for a season is more than $10 a tonne below the base price, payments are to be made out of the fund to growers.

Growers contributed approximately $1.2m to the fund in respect of the 1978 season, and it has been assessed that further significant payments would also be the ultimate result of the 1979 and 1980 seasons accounting if the scheme were permitted to run its full course. This would be of no advantage to the industry, and would in fact deny growers the use of substantial moneys, which under the legislation would have to be collected from them in due course for these two seasons, as grower contributions to the fund. Growers would then have to wait for the winding up of the fund at the end of the stabilisation term before these moneys would be refunded to them. Such refunds could probably not be made before well into 1982.

The Government has therefore accepted a request from the industry that legislation be introduced to terminate the scheme and to authorise refund to the contributing growers of the moneys presently in the sultanas stabilisation fund. The moneys contributed by growers in respect of 1978 season have been invested, the last maturity date of such investments being 1 October 1981. After consultation with the growers' organisation-The Australian Dried Fruits Association-the Government has made provision in the Bill for the investments to continue until their maturity. In this way a considerable amount of interest will be earned, and no risk will be incurred of loss of capital value through early redemption. After all investments have matured, all moneys standing to the credit of the fund are to be distributed among growers in proportion to each grower's share of the total contributed by growers. A formula is set out in the Bill for the purpose of establishing the amount payable to each grower.

The Bill also makes provision to enable the payments to growers to be made through the system already established for the making of stabilisation payments. It is expected that payments to growers will be completed about the end of 1981. In anticipation of inquiry by honourable senators as to possible on-going price support arrangements for this industry, I point out that discussions are proceeding with the industry designed to conclude mutually acceptable provisions for an underwriting scheme commencing with the 1982 season. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Bill 1981

This Bill provides for the underwriting of returns from all export market sales of apples and pears over the five seasons 1981 to 1985. The Bill, together with the associated Apple and Pear Stabilisation Amendment Bill 1981 and the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill 1981 implement the Government's decision to vary the market support arrangements for export apples and pears following the inquiry last year by the Industries Assistance Commission into the assistance needs of the apple and pear industry beyond 1980. The Government accepted the IAC's recommendation that continuing price support assistance for apple and pear exports should in future be related to actual price experience on export markets, but that the existing cost of production based price support under the stabilisation scheme for apple exports be phased out gradually to avoid undue disruption in the industry.

Honourable senators will be aware that the existing Apple and Pear Stabilisation Scheme was introduced in 1971. The then Minister for Primary Industry's second reading speech indicated that the intention of the stabilisation scheme was to give a measure of stability to the industry to assist it to examine and take steps to meet the adjustment problems then confronting it. In the ten years that the scheme has operated, payments to growers have totalled $22.6m of which the Commonwealth contributed $22.3m. Nearly all the assistance has been paid in respect of apples. It has always been acknowledged that the stabilisation scheme would not provide solutions to all the industry's problems. Honourable senators will also be aware that the industry had the advantage of the Fruitgrowing Reconstruction Scheme which operated from 1973 to 1978.

During the 1970s the industry has gone a long way to meeting its adjustment needs. Total Australian apple and pear production had declined by about 30 and 40 per cent respectively; exports now account for some 15 per cent of production instead of about 30 per cent; a bigger share of the exports go to the more profitable 'forward sale' markets in South West Asia and the Middle East; and there is less dependence on the relatively unprofitable 'at risk' markets in Europe. Further adjustment is expected to take place in the next few years. However, with the development of alternative export outlets outside Europe, continued growth in domestic demand and the development of processing outlets, future adjustment is unlikely to be as great or of the same nature as the adjustment of the past ten years.

Looking back, I can confidently state that the stabilisation scheme has met its objective of providing a measure of 'breathing space' to growers facing difficult adjustment problems. However, as observed by the IAC, the stabilisation scheme has also had the effect of distorting market signals for export fruit and continuation of the scheme on an unchanged basis could now prejudice the successful completion of the necessary adjustment process. The changes which the Government will be introducing to the existing stabilisation scheme will be dealt with in more detail in my second reading speech on the associated Apple and Pear Stabilisation Amendment Bill 1981.

There is one further aspect of the package of assistance arrangements which will apply to the apple and pear industry to which I should refer. In addition to the underwriting arrangements for apples and pears and continuance of the stabilisation scheme for apples on a phasing-out basis for four years to 1984, the Commonwealth is to continue to provide supplementary assistance on a dollar for dollar basis with participating States over that 4-year period. The Commonwealth commitment is for a maximum of $3m to be provided over this period in respect of apples and $800,000 for pears. The use of the assistance is to be flexible and available to fund orchard reconstruction and related adjustment measures for growers particularly affected by the changed market support arrangements for 'at risk' exports. It may also be used to provide additional 'at risk' export price support assistance for apples but not for pears. The Government has placed a ceiling of $750,000 of Commonwealth funds and a maximum pay-out per box of $2.20 that may be used to supplement export price support for apples in 1981, these maxima to be reduced by one-quarter in each of the three succeeding years. The Commonwealth is currently discussing with the States proposals on the form and the amount of supplementary assistance to be provided.

I should now like to deal briefly with the specific provisions of the Export Underwriting Bill. For each of the 1981 to 1985 export seasons, separate guaranteed minimum return levels will be established by this Bill for apple exports and for pear exports. The guaranteed minimum returns will be determined by calculating 95 per cent of the weighted average per box free on board return for all apple exports, and for all pear exports, over the immediately preceding four export seasons. At the close of each export season, the Bill provides for the determination of the average per box f.o.b. returns falls below the relevant guaranteed minimum return, then this Bill provides that an underwriting payment is made, such payment being the difference between the guaranteed minimum return and the relevant average per box f.o.b. return. Underwriting payments shall be made, in the case of fruit exported 'at risk', to the owner of the fruit at the time of export, and in the case of fruit sold before export, to the owners of the fruit prior to that sale. Unlike the Stabilisation legislation this Bill does not provide for payments into the scheme by growers; the underwriting arrangements are to be financed solely by the Commonwealth. As with the Stabilisation scheme, assistance payments under the underwriting scheme will be made through the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation. Mr President, the package of market support measures decided upon by the Government will provide a good basis on which the industry can develop to meet the changing marketing circumstances confronting it. As part of that package I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Apple and Pear Stabilization Amendment Bill 1981

This Bill introduces amendments to the Apple and Pear Stabilization Act 1971 as part of the package of market support measures for the industry that I have just outlined in my speech on the Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Bill 1981. The principal stabilisation Act is extended by this Bill to cover apple exports for the four export seasons 1981 to 1984. The stabilisation scheme for pears is not to be extended. Stabilisation assistance for apples will continue to apply only to exports shipped at some degree of risk to markets in Europe, including the United Kingdom. The maximum rate of stabilisation assistance for apples for the 1981 export season is to be $2.20 per box, the same as applied in both the 1979 and 1980 export seasons. In 1982 the maximum is to be reduced to $1.65 per box, in 1983 $1.10 and in 1984 55c. This maximum rate is to be payable on a maximum of 1.5 million boxes of apples in each session. In the event that more than 1.5 million boxes of apples are exported 'at risk' to Europe in any year then the maximum per box payout is to be reduced proportionately.

This Bill provides that in the event that both a stabilisation payment and an underwriting payment become payable then the stabilisation payment is reduced by the amount of the underwriting payment. The principal stabilisation Act is further amended to terminate the grower 'pay-in' provisions and to allow for winding up the varietal trust funds. The Bill also provides for the updating of the levels of penalties provided under the Act so as to bring them into line with those provided under the Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Bill 1981. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill 1981

This Bill introduces an amendment to the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Act 1973 consequential to the Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Bill 1981 to allow the Corporation to incur expenses in operating the underwriting arrangements. The opportunity is also being taken to bring the taxation liability of the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation into line with that of other statutory commodity authorities in the primary industry area, and to make a few technical amendments to the Corporation Act. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
