DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Closure of Post Offices in Queensland-Political Prisoners in Uruguay-Imprisonment in Argentina of Australian Citizen

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Peter Baume) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have spoken on a number of occasions in this chamber on the matter of post office closures in Queensland. The last time I spoke on this matter I mentioned the post office in the tiny township of Hungerford which is on the Queensland-New South Wales border. I am happy to say that following my mentioning that matter in the chamber that post office remained open. It is still in operation. On this occasion I wish to speak about the post office at a place called Acacia Ridge which is a Brisbane suburb. The Acacia Ridge residents contacted me about the possible closure of their post office and they were quite angry at this impending closure because of the difficulties that it would present to them. I was handed a petition by the people. It was signed by 461 residents protesting against the closure of their local post office. I was not able to present this petition to the Senate because the residents constructed the petition in an unsatisfactory way. I seek leave at this stage to table the petition that the residents handed to me.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the residents spoke to me I wrote to the State Manager of Australia Post. The letter that I wrote to him and the letters I received from him are pertinent. At this late stage I will not read them out. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter that I wrote to the State Manager of Australia Post and two letters which the State Manager of Australia Post wrote to me.
—Could I see them? Could you give the dates? When did the petition come to you?
—The petition came to me in early February.
—I suggest that the letters be given to the Minister and the honourable senator can seek leave later to incorporate them.

—The last letter I received from the State Manager of Australia Post, which is amongst those that I have sought leave to incorporate, contains an explanation of why the post office will close despite my request and the request of the 461 residents who signed the petition. I contacted some of the Acacia Ridge residents about the matter. They are not satisfied with the reply that has come from the State Manager of Australia Post. They point out that many of the signatories to the petition are pensioners and that those pensioners will face hardship if the post office is closed. In the view of the Acacia Ridge residents, Australia Post is not meeting their reasonable needs. I simply ask the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) to have the matter thoroughly investigated to determine whether the retention of Acacia Ridge North post office will fulfil a real need for local residents. If it does-the number of signatories on the petition that I have mentioned suggests that it does-I ask the Minister for Communications to take action to see that it remains open. I would be grateful if the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) who is at the table would be able to pass along my requests to the Minister for Communications.
—Do you request the incorporation of those letters?
—Yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIAThe Senate Commonwealth Parliament Offices Australian Government Centre 295 Ann Street Brisbane, Qld 4000 17 February, 1981
Mr R. M. Brown,
State Manager,
Australia Post,
GPO Box 6000,
Brisbane, 4001
Dear Mr Brown,

I have been contacted by residents of Acacia Ridge in relation to the proposed closure of the post office agency in Oxley Street. The residents have been informed that the agency is to be closed in March.

I am informed that the Acacia Ridge North Post Office is being shifted just across the street from its present site in the Elizabeth Street Shopping Centre. Local residents believe that the shifting of this post office will bring it within a two kilometre radius of the agency in Oxley Street and this fact will be used to justify its closure. However, the new position of the Acacia Ridge North Post Office in no way lessens the inconvenience which will be suffered by those residents who currently use the agency. I am informed that many of these people are pensioners and it will cause them great difficulty to travel to the Post Office in Elizabeth Street.

I am enclosing photocopies of some petitions from Acacia Ridge residents who are opposed to the closure of the agency. The original petitions are available for your inspection if you wish to see them. The number of signatories indicates the strength of feeling about this issue.
I would be grateful if you could have the proposed closure of the agency reconsidered and advise me in due course.
Yours sincerely,
Original signed Mal Colston
MAL COLSTON Senator for Queensland Encls.
State Manager GPO Brisbane, Qld 4001 20 February 1981 Senator Mal Colston
Senator for Queensland
Commonwealth Parliament Offices
Australian Government Centre
295 Ann Street
Brisbane, Qld 4000
Dear Senator Colston

I acknowledge your representations of 17 February together with a petition on behalf of the residents of Acacia Ridge concerning the proposed closure of the Acacia Ridge North Non Official Post Office in Oxley Street.
A new building is being constructed at a cost in excess of $85,000 at the corner of Amhurst and Mitchell Streets, Acacia Ridge, and the Official Post Office will be relocated there on 10 April 1981.

It is the policy of Australia Post not to provide Post Offices, except in special circumstances, within a distance of two kilometres from another. As the Acacia Ridge North Post Office is situated less than 1.3 km radial distance from the Acacia Ridge Official Office and less than 1.7 km radial distance from the Rocklea Official Office, it was decided to close the Acacia Ridge North Post Office in conjunction with the opening of the new office. Indeed, the closing of the nearby Non Official Post Office formed part of the justification for spending the capital on a new Post Office building.
However, in view of your representations the earlier decision is being reviewed and I will write to you again as soon as possible.
Yours sincerely
R M Brown State Manager
State Manager GPO Brisbane, Qld 4001 2 March 1981 Senator Mal Colston
Senator for Queensland
Australian Government Centre
295 Ann Street
Brisbane, Qld 4000
Dear Senator Colston

I refer again to your representations of 17 February together with a petition on behalf of the residents of Acacia Ridge concerning the proposed closure of the Acacia Ridge North Non Official Post Office in Oxley Street.

Under the terms of the Postal Services Act 1975, Australia Post is required to price its services so as to recover all of its operating costs and at least half of its capital expenditure from revenue. Against this background, Australia Post is continually reviewing its services and methods of operation to ensure that the facilities provided are adequate to meet the reasonable needs of the community and that the resources available are used to the best advantage.

I am sure you will realise that historically many post offices were established to cater for needs which no longer exist. Social security pensions, repatriation pensions and defence allotments were once paid in cash at post offices but now these are paid by cheque or into a bank account. Broadcast and television licences are no longer issued. In addition, the community has alternatives to many services previously provided only at a post office. For instance, the number of telephone subscribers is continually increasing and providing more people with an alternative to letters and telegrams. Additionally, private savings bank agencies operate in many areas where previously the post office agency was the only such facility. Cheque accounts are now used by a large proportion of the community as an alternative to money orders, parcel services are provided by other operators and many businessmen sell stamps under licence.

Community shopping habits have changed too. As motor car ownership has become more widespread, there has been a tendency to by-pass the local store for the greater range and cheaper prices of major shopping centres and people usually do their postal business where they shop.

The level of postal business transacted at the Acacia Ridge North Post Office is significantly below that which would justify the retention of a post office in an urban area and comprises less than 30 percent of the total workload. The remainder is made up of Commonwealth Savings Bank transactions.

Australia Post considers that when the Acacia Ridge North Non Official Post Office is withdrawn, residents and business houses in the area will still have reasonable access to postal facilities. Arrangements will be made for a stamp vendor's licence to be issued to the proprietor of a business in the area and the street posting box will be retained outside the existing post office. Also, the Commonwealth Bank has been approached regarding the provision of a Private Savings Bank Agency in the Acacia Ridge North area.
As promised, I have reviewed the earlier decision but having regard to all the circumstances it is proposed to proceed with the closure of the Acacia Ridge North Post Office on 10 April 1981.
Yours sincerely
R. M. Brown State Manager

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not keep the Senate long. I would like to give a couple of matters an airing in the chamber this evening. The first one concerns the situation in the South American country of Uruguay as it relates to political prisoners. I raised this matter some time late last year in this chamber and at that stage referred to a description by a United States congressional committee of Uruguay wherein that committee described it as being the torture chamber of South America. Before I spoke on this matter previously I wrote to the country's representative here in Canberra in civil tones asking questions and requesting certain information. I received no reply. I had occasion later on last year to write to the same gentleman again. Again I have not even received any reply or any recognition that I have even written to him. I do not quite know what he is afraid of, or whether he is afraid of something, but it is a little strange when representatives of other countries in our country are not prepared to write a letter in answer to a request for information made in a very civil manner. I make that point. The situation in Uruguay apparently has not improved despite the attempts that have been made by this and other governments and groups throughout the world. On 14 February the Committee of Solidarity with the Uruguayan People based in Melbourne wrote to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Hon. A. A. Street. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Minister,

There has been widespread condemnation of the regime in Uruguay and its abuse of human rights. This criticism has been world-wide. We enclose a selection of documents giving background information to the debate in Australia relative to this.

Indeed the Australian Government has also expressed its concern. Unfortunately the situation has not improved and we feel that the Australian Government has not done enough to promote the respect of human rights in Uruguay. We suggest that the following concrete actions, if taken at the Human Rights Commission presently being held in Geneva would be effective in reducing the abuse of human rights in Uruguay.
(1) That the Commision initiate an in-depth study of the situation in Uruguay and that a Special Rapporteur be appointed to document this.
(2) That the secret, confidential nature of the treatment of the Uruguayan case be lifted, and that the matter be debated in public (as was done last year for the cases of Bolivia and Guatemala).
We ask you to urgently contact the Australian Delegation to the Human Rights Committee to request that these propositions be supported by the Australian Delegation.
Yours sincerely,
Tomas Weisz Per CO.S.P.U.

I had hoped this week to raise this matter in Question Time but unfortunately, Mr Deputy President, I was unable to get the call. I wonder whether the Minister has taken the action that has been requested and whether or not he has replied to that group of people in Melbourne.

The second matter I wish to raise again has come to my attention in a letter addressed to me by the same people-the Committee of Solidarity with the Uruguayan People. The letter is undated but I received it about a week ago. That letter states in part:
Dear Senator Primmer,

We write to you to express our concern at the imprisonment in Argentina of Mr Alberto Marinelli during November of last year. Alberto is an Australian citizen, and up until October 1979, when he left for a trip to Argentina, he had been a resident of this country for five years. The information we have about the circumstances leading to his arrest are at present rather sketchy. We do know that he was arrested by the 8th Mountain Infantry Brigade in Las Quevas, Mendoza, on November 26th, 1980. The law under which he was detained was article 21460, the intent of which is to 'protect the state'. Under this vague and imprecise concept broad powers can be evoked. It is a law reserved almost exclusively for the detaining of 'political prisoners'.
I will skip the second paragraph which has no great bearing on the story. The third paragraph reads:

In each case such as Alberto's there is a sense of desperation, for he is one among thousands of political prisoners in Latin America. However, he is one of whom we know personally, and one who we believe can be assisted by concerned members of the Australian community. The fact that all political prisoners in Latin America are subjected to some form of torture adds to the urgency of our appeal.

In line with our concern about the rights of individuals, political, social, and economic, we are in the process of sending an Australian lawyer to Uruguay and Argentina. Peter McMullin is a member of the International Committee of Jurists, and he will accompany the President and two other members of that organisation to the two countries we have mentioned. During the time that Peter is in Argentina we hope that he will be able to see Alberto.

As I read the recent history of political action in Argentina it seems that the Argentinian Government has a great ability to pick up refugees fleeing political persecution in other South American countries. Argentina has a sorry record in relation to human rights. I am certainly worried by the fact that there is an Australian citizen in Argentine hands. I ask the Minister whether he can make some inquiries through the Department of Foreign Affairs as to what charges have been laid against Mr Marinelli and whether any of our consular representatives in that country have been in touch with Mr Marinelli or are aware that he is imprisoned somewhere in Argentina.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Two matters have been raised tonight by honourable senators. The first, raised by Senator Colston, refers to post office facilities at Acacia Ridge. As I understand the honourable senator's concern it is about the post office agency in Oxley Street, Acacia Ridge North.
—It is a non-official post office.

—I understand that the honourable senator's concern is for the fact that it is a non-official post office. I will, of course, pass his concern on to the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) in an attempt to get a detailed response. It is worth mentioning that there is soon to be the official opening of a new post office building at Acacia Ridge North. As a matter of fact, it will be opened at 3 p.m. on 10 April. I understand that all honourable senators from Queensland will be invited to the opening.
—I am no longer invited to those functions.

—I am led to believe that all Queensland senators will be invited. I understand that the building will be a new, larger and more modern post office for Acacia Ridge. It could be that these two events are linked together and of course the opening of the new post office may add a complicating factor. As I said, I will undertake to get the information which the honourable senator seeks.
—The matter of the new post office is mentioned in those letters.

—I take the honourable senator's point. The other matter raised on the adjournment tonight was raised by Senator Primmer. It concerns political prisoners and arbitrary arrest in South America. The first matter concerns Uruguay and letters written from Melbourne by the Committee of Solidarity with the Uruguayan People to which the writers have not yet had a response.
—I am not sure; I tried to contact them today.

—It is quite appropriate that we obtain an answer from the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Peacock) to the question which the honourable senator asked. I will undertake to refer the matter to him as quickly as I can. The other matter he raised concerned an Australian citizen, Alberto Marinelli, arrested in Argentina. The honourable senator asked two specific questions: What charges have been laid against this citizen and what action have our consular officials taken to contact Mr Marinelli and to look after his interests? I undertake to pass on to the Foreign Minister the concerns expressed and the matters raised so that an early response can be obtained for the honourable senator.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many letters were sent to members of the Sydney Greek community seeking information to assist the Commonwealth Police in obtaining evidence in relation to the alleged social security conspiracy case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 27 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister any knowledge of an environmental impact study associated with the uranium mining project at Mary Kathleen; if so, are any documents available for public scrutiny.

(2) Does the mining company have a properly planned rehabilitation program for the Mary Kathleen mining area generally, and does the plan comply with the Government guidelines in relation to the rehabilitation of mining sites.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The then Commonwealth Government did not require that an environmental impact statement be prepared at the time decisions were being taken to recommission the Mary Kathleen uranium mine. I understand that Mary Kathleen Uranium Ltd at that time submitted a document to the relevant Queensland authorities on environmental aspects of the recommissioning of the mine.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 2 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it illegal for an official of a religious organisation to open, read and/or censor mail addressed to a member or follower of the organisation who is living in premises occupied by that organisation.
(2) What power does the Government have to ensure that mail reaches those to whom it is addressed and that consent to its interception is not obtained by duress.
(3) Do the Federal Police or any officers of the Department or of Australia Post have powers of investigation and prosecution in relation to the interception of mail.

(4) Has the Minister, the Department or Australia Post received any complaints of acts of this nature: if so: (a) how many prosecutions have been undertaken: and (b) how many convictions have been obtained and against whom.
(5) Have any television programs broadcast in Australia on behalf of religious cults or organisations solicited donations and falsely advised viewers that donations were tax deductible.

(6) Will the Minister investigate or refer to the Broadcasting Tribunal the incidence of the use of television for fraudulent purposes by religious organisations for investigation, and if necessary, introduce regulatory guidelines to prevent the recurrence of misrepresentation and fraud.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Commonwealth legislative provisions on interference with the mail relate only to interference with articles in the course of postal transmission. The type of interference referred to in the Question would occur after mail had been delivered. State and Territory laws in the place of delivery could possibly be relevant in some cases of interference, depending on circumstances.
(2) Postal legislation does not require that a postal article be handed to the addressee. Such a requirement could be quite unworkable in providing a national postal service.
As stated above, there are no Commonwealth laws which relate to interception of or interference with mail after delivery.
(3) The Australian Federal Police, as a law enforcement agency, has powers of investigation and prosecution in respect of any offences against Commonwealth law, including postal legislation.

Australia Post's security officers investigate and prosecute offences against the Postal Services Act but, in relation to interference with postal articles, their involvement would be limited to interference occurring in the course of postal transmission.
Complaints involving interception after delivery would be a matter for State police investigation or for civil proceedings between the parties involved.

(4) Over the years, Australia Post has received occasional complaints of interference with mail after delivery has been effected. However, we have no record of any such complaints which related to matters within the jurisdiction of Commonwealth law.

(5) The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has no record itself of any instance in which a religious organisation or cult, when soliciting donations in a television program, has falsely advised viewers that these donations were tax deductible.
In response to the Tribunal's request, the General Manager of the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations has provided the following information:

'Of those Commercial Television Stations which televise programs on behalf of religious cults or organisations in which donations are solicited, only one Station has any recollection of a claim being made to the effect that a donation would be tax deductible.

The particular incident occurred within a program 'Good News' televised by GTV9, Melbourne on behalf of Full Gospel Businessman's Fellowship, Australian National Division. The program is recorded in the USA.

Management of GTV9 advises that it has since taken the precaution of editing the program, where necessary, to ensure that a similar situation will not recur. I am advised that other Stations take similar precautions.'

(6) I propose to discuss with the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal the incidence of the use of television for fraudulent purposes by religious organisations, and the possible need for some controls in this area.

The provisions of the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1980, which provided for partial self-regulation for broadcasters, are currently being reviewed in the light of public representations received. The need for regulatory controls in this area could be considered as part of this review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 3 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are there many telephone subscribers who, in the absence of STD, leave their telephone openly available to visitors, staff members, flatmates, etc. and are quite willing to bear the cost of local calls, knowing that trunk calls have to be booked with the operator, with a reasonable chance of identifying the persons concerned.

(2) With the advent of STD, are subscribers whose telephones are 'relatively accessible' running the risk of substantial losses from use of STD by people who take advantage of knowing that no record is available of such calls.

(3) If such subscribers decided to bar the service from STD, do they face the prospect of trunk calls being subjected to additional charges, which are so great in some cases as to represent a real deterrent to making such calls.

(4) Would a subscriber who considered it necessary to have STD barred and who regularly called a town to which the new 'Community Call' rate applied have to pay 79c for each call which by STD would have only been 9c, a surcharge of 777 per cent.
(5) If an STD barred subscriber who regularly made daytime calls which might cost, say $7.00 still be charged only 70c extra representing a fairly innocuous 10 per cent surcharge.

(6) If a subscriber accepts a reverse charge call from a person calling from a nearby town, who, say, may be stranded without any coins, would the charge be $1.19 instead of the STD public telephone cost of 10c and would this extra charge still apply if the reason the call was made 'reverse charge' was that the coin telephone appeared to be out of order and a Telecom operator suggested reversing the charges.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telecom Australia has advised that it has no data on the subject.
(2) Telecom Australia believes that most subscribers would take appropriate action to guard against unauthorised use of their services.

(3) An additional service charge is applied for a telephone trunk call booked with an exchange operator where the subscriber has access to STD facilities but elects not to use the facilities and day rates apply at all times.
(4) and (5) Yes. Standard equipment does not permit the barring of STD calls and at the same time allow community calls to be unbarred.

(6) The Reverse Charge Service is available on trunk calls only. In the case of a local call from a nearby town, the caller stranded without coins who required an urgent call would be connected without charge. Similarly, if the coin mechanism were faulty and there was not another coin telephone nearby, the caller would be put through without charge.
